content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												This game is 4 years old now, and I believe it is time for a new review. My standards for review scores are 10 starting points, and -1 point for everything done wrong. Before I continue, I need to state that I am not biased towards any particular gaming company or extended universe/lore. I review the game as it should be reviewed -- as a time waster. Things done right in this game are below:Great GraphicsLightsaber Combat and Force Powers Done RightMany Customization Options (Including several costumes [Just for aesthetics] and many lightsaber crystals which give you different upgrades)The game has done a good job with capturing the atmosphere of the environments, especially KaminoThings done wrong are below:The Story is atrocious, no debate. And with the story being a major point of any game, an extra point is taken off. -2 points.The player character is a mix of blandness and unoriginality, however, at times, you can feel like an indestructible god, choosing who lives and who dies which provides a fun experience. Not enough to keep a point, however, so -1 point.Finally, Quick Time Events (QTE's) are abundant, and repetitive. -1 more point.The final score for this game is: 6/10. While being a good Star Wars game, it still has enough flaws to put it at an average rating. In my opinion, if you haven't gotten this game yet, get it. Even though it doesn't have the highest rating, it can still be a lot of fun if you don't play a game for the story, but to waste time and have fun.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												It is fun to unleashed the force: stormtroopers are in air, AT-Ats get fed up with their own rockets and Vader is a nervous Sith Lord. The con of this game is that it doesn’t last long. This game is high quality. The cinematics are better than the movies, the art style is gorgeous, everyone looks better(except for Juno) your force power are higher and in turn, the havoc you’ll create. The story is simple and there are some very discreet subplots(the biggest one is unlocked in the challenges). Some people have reported bugs, but they have submitted fixes as well. I for one didn’t have a problem with this game. Except for one thing. It was too short. It was like sex with someone really hot, one a day when you’re so full of energy and into it, but for a reason, it’s so short it will strike you like the Death Star. A good question would be: “Is the game worth buying if it’s short?”. I’ll tell you what this game has and it will be your choice if you’ll take it or leave it. 


POWER! UNLIMITED POWER!!! 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™: The Force Unleashed™ II
By: F4rseeR




Fans of its prequel will notice that old moves are still there, many unlocked from the start. You have the typical force powers: force push, force lightning, force repulse, saber throw and a new one: mind trick. They all feel powerful when used, they’re designed to be enjoyed rather than used tactically. Whether you push, stun, impale them or make them commit suicide, it’s still the same, you are unstoppable. However, they are more detailed than you can see at first glance. Mind trick makes troopers attack the others or jump to their deaths in a humorous way, lighting will overheat the jet of a trooper, resulting in his flying around without control to an explosive end. Also new to the series, there is the body dismemberment, making the sword combat more satisfying. Having two lightsabers instead of one make the protagonist to fight in a more agile and aggressive way.  Force fury is an ability that amplifies your power for a limited time. In that stance, enemies are pulverized by your power. The game itself is not hard. Unleashed mode will present something that could have been old school challenge, but gaining full health whenever checkpoints are reloaded simplifies things too much. Skydiving is fun and has its place, there are three sequences anyway. The QTE’s are the type that can be failed, but most are optional, boss battles being the only ones that require them.  Boss battles themselves are well designed, as there are multiple stages with key moments that make the real differences. The gameplay itself is one of the best.


Join the light side and you'll get the girl! 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™: The Force Unleashed™ II
By: F4rseeR




The story is incomplete. Even if it doesn’t show, reading the novel(which proves the story’s potential) proves how much more there was to say. Even if you go through Kamino, Cato Nemoida, Dagobah, aboard a big rebel ship called the “Salvation” that will later engage in a space battle and facing Vader on your return to Kamino, it’s not enough. What is there is spectacular, but the canon end makes way for a sequel that will never be made.  In the story, you are the clone of Starkiller who inspired the creation of the rebellion. You are made stronger than the original to suit Vader’s more demanding commands.  As you retained the memories of the original, you’ll find yourself fighting the empire and looking forward for reuniting with your old love. This time around, Starkiller is the hunted one, but he has enough power to face whatever Vader is throwing at him. However he is delayed and at the end, Vader proves he can make him do his bidding. Vader is portrayed as the menace he is in the books: manipulative and hard to take down.  He has the intellect from the original trilogy and the fighting skills from the prequel trilogy. There are two endings, the light side one where the rebellion earns a major victory because of you and the dark side one, where you die, Vader stands victorious, with the perfect dark side clone at his side.  


First try 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™: The Force Unleashed™ II
By: F4rseeR




If you want to spend more time in the game, there are several challenges that make you use your force powers in certain ways, there are all kinds of outfits and skins to unlock(and they are worth it), holocrons to collect for getting new saber crystals(that change the sabers color and add an effect in combat), cinematics revolving around the dark clone subplot and that’s about it. If you look for more of the lore, there is a databank and concept art available. It’s a well designed game, high quality, but low quantity. Star Wars fans and gamers in general(casual and hardcore) should buy this if they have the money to spare.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												So last week I wrote my review on Force Unleashed 1. I was impressed with the story and how well it fit in the Star Wars universe and the only major complaint I had was that the controls sometimes felt clunky, that the game could have been a LITTLE bit more than it was.I finally got around to playing this, and it feels like my opinions flipped. You play as Starkiller again, and the introduction gives a good start to WHY you are there. If you didn't play the first game before this I recommend you do, otherwise you will be totally lost. Anyway, I'll go through each section.Story: 5/10The only reason the story is this high is because the first game did a magnificent job setting things up. You know your story from the first, although the Starkiller in this game doesn't remember much about his past (minor spoiler, don't worry you find this out in the openning cutscene, Vader tells you that you are a clone). You basically spend the game trying to get back to your beloved Juno's arms, that's about it. No major plot development like in the first one, nothing that helps you define yourself as a Sith or Jedi. In fact, Starkiller feels a little bit less of a badass and a bit more angsty than I would have liked. Graphics & Sound: 8/10The sound is easy, they did a good job with music, it fit in well, and the whole Star Wars lightsaber/force sound effects are amazing, exactly what you expect. The graphics are polished and the cutscenes are really well done from what I could tell. There are 2 very major reasons why I don't give this game a 10/10 (keeping in mind that the game was released over 3 years ago). First of all, most of the cutscenes actually involve your character model, thus including your dual lightsabers and the crystal color you chose, which is good. The problem? The fully CGI cutscenes that are videos, they just had him with dual red lightsabers. It felt really lazy and removed me from the experience a little bit. Other games make sure their full cutscenes include the specialized weapon and armor you are wearing, don't switch me back to the original, it is really annoying. I took 1 point off for that. The second thing, while the game looks great and everything, the characters look different than from the first. General Kota and Juno specifically, and Starkiller as well but not to the same extent. They just LOOK like different people with similar features. That bothered me slightly, yes they are WAY MORE polished than before, but it detracted from their original look.Gameplay: 9/10Gameplay is magnificent in this. They changed the combat system and leveling system, the menus are more fluid, fighting is more fluid, FORCE POWERS ARE MORE FLUID. This was my problem in the first game, not so in here. You basically have most of your kit from the first game, and as you gain experience you unlock more force powers along with being able to upgrade them up to a maximum level of 3. This is beautiful, and being able to rapid fire Force Push (even though I never used it) is amazing. Also, put a point into Jedi Mindtrick, it is the most fun part of this game. The game felt more fluid, and I died maybe a few times to mis-timed jumps, but never because the camera screwed me or things not being responsive. Overall: 8/10The story was kind of lame, and it was the only thing to take away from it. The game is short, it took me 6 hours (theres like 8 levels) and I didn't feel like it took forever. The action was amazing and the fights were fun. Everything else aside, I enjoyed this A LOT more than the first game.

number of helpful: 372 of 531 people (70%) found this review helpful57 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Starkiller is back and this time it is personal. Waking up from what seems to be a long sleep, the obscenely powerful force adepts finds himself on Kamino in servitude to his old master. Bereft of his friends, memories and purpose, Starkiller is left with questions and he goes on a rampage to find people who can help him. Now, with 100% more lightsaber and 400% more cutscenes and quick-time events the force is unleashed once again...to much less fanfare and considerably more issues. A video game sequel traditionally follows a particular pattern: More of that and then some. Not The Force Unleashed II. No. This game is much less than its predecessor. It is shorter, less interesting in terms of plot and story. Barely changes up its gameplay formula and feels generally cheaply made. Dissapointing is the core word used to describe the overal impression of The Force Unleashed II's content and gameplay. The original had issues, but instead of addressing them, the sequel just kept a lot of them in there and added some more. In this installment, we find a clone of the original Starkiller in Vader's service. Vader has managed to clone a jedi; something thought to be impossible. However, most clones succumb to madness from residual memories from their original self. Hellbent to not fall to insanity, Starkiller escapes to find the only two people in the galaxy left alive who can tell him who he is: General Kota, and his former love: Juno Eclipse. Starkiller hops between a few planets and even visits Yoda before finding his way back to Kamino to end up right where a started...dead. The very premise of the story, Starkiller's amnesia, is a massive turn-off. Where before the story involved intrigue, betrayal and rebellion; it now merely rests on goose chases and damsels in distress. A notable improvement though is Starkiller's broadened emotional spectrum. Instead of mysterious and angry, he can now express sadness, sarcasm and joy, as well as a range of angers such as irate, furious, enraged and vengeful. A nice change up, but it is too little and too late. By the time you witness the juicy plot twist, the game ends.To be honest, when I started the game I was biased against it. I had played it before on the PS3 and was sorely dissapointed in it. However, when I was making my way through the first few stages I noticed that the environments were signficantly more detailed, the physics worked better and the different levels of force powers were more defined. So the noticable improvements to gameplay and presentations are noticable from the start, and they capture you. John Williams' inspired score accentuates the action at the right moments and the voice acting is more convincing because the actors are a little bit more acqainted with their roles. However, the sound editing is spotty. Certain effects, such as Vader's breathing is superimposed over the score, making it an awkward ambient sound. Additionally, some hit effects were just cheaply taken from the stock sound pack and sound horribly out of place. While I was seriously considering forgiving the game for many of its flaws I couldn't overlook the glaring instability of the game. The game crashed on me more times than I care to count. Either during gameplay, or during loading. Regardless of the moment of the crash, the game would send me back to the beginning of the stage and let me do the whole thing all over again. Annoying, and sometimes infuriating, as some segments are not particularly enjoyable. The gameplay follows the same standard as the original; combat sections and the occasional force puzzle with some platforming. It is a tested formula; God of War has thrived on it. However, The Force Unleashed II lacks the variation and excitement. The sequel introduces many new enemy types that require a more distinct approch as opposed to simply slashing and shocking it, but once you find that shocking and grabbing is just as effective you quickly make short work of enemies that were supposed to make life hard for you. Boss fights do not fare much better. Mindlessly hacking away at them is the preferred method of dealing with them. When you're not hacking though, the game will simply let the cutscenes handle the action and force you to either press buttons on prompt or simply witness awesome stuff that you are not doing yourself. This becomes glaringly obvious toward the end where set-pieces, corridors, bosses and cutscenes appear back to back. The final boss, Vader (screw your spoilers, you saw this coming) is a joke on many levels. Not only is he a complete pushover, he is also not even remotely like Vader. This is purely speaking as an invested Star Wars fan, but the final boss fight just rains on the entire parade.When the credits roll after a measly four hours you can really feel the bad taste in the back of the mouth. The game is rushed. It is polished in appearance, but the content was cut; cut with a cleaver and left on the side because there was not enough time to fully finish it. Particularly the Dagobah stage shows signs of time constraint. It feels like there should have been a stage, while the only thing there is a cutscene. Other distinct ommissions include a battle with Boba Fett, who is set up to be fought. And the most startling missing element is probably the DLC. While the consoles got another what-if story; this version doesn't even get a single costume. The overal final product is just such a dissapointment it would incite buyers remorse within no time. Couple that with the crashes and the lack of DLC and you have a game that cannot justify its pricepoint outside of a sale. I can't reccomend it and I would even go as far as to completely dissuade Star Wars fans to play it, because it does such a poor job with Vader that it makes his appearance in Revenge of the Sith acceptable. In retrospect, I'm happy that I cancelled my pre-order all those years ago. A strong sign of the force. A sign that the force is weak with The Force Unleashed II.

Posted: November 1, 2014
												Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II is a third-person fighting game from LucasArts. Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II is a sequel to the first game Star Wars: The Force Unleashed.Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II has quite similar but enhanced gameplay from the previous game, yet I think its kinda simplified a bit too. Still good, you get to use the lightsaber and swing it on stormtroopers or AT-ST. But the whole story, the chapter is too short and I think it's somewhat repetitive. Using the same key combo to finish AT-ST and their kind, the boss fight, it's kinda boring. The challenge is not a good addition too for me. It's good to swing lightsaber on many stormtroopers, using force lightning and all, but the repetitive level kinda ruin it all.The graphics of Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II is good, great in fact, if only the gameplay are that good too. The frame rate are good, no lags so smooth and the textures are beautiful. But the game is not stable as sometimes the game like to crash to desktop, especially on newer operating system. But the compatibility mode should help.Overall, Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II is an average sequel, not bad but not that good too. The story is good, but too short. I recommend this if you're Star Wars fan like me.Rating 6/10

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												The Force Unleashed II showed much promise after the release of the first Force Unleashed, which was rather good. But no, they had to rush this one. Make money as fast as possible. *Shakes head in disbelief* Decent Star Wars games are hard to come by, so why not take a little more time to polish this one then ? I seriously can't answer that.I was impressed by the graphics. It has that certain Star Wars vibe, which is a definite plus. But there's not much variety in the environments (about 3 truly different areas/worlds), and as a result everything looks bland and boring, and doesn't make you want to explore. As far as that's possible, because it's mostly a linear game, with only one way to go forward.There's plenty of detail in the characters and the effects look great in motion. One thing that distracted me from the experience though, was the face of Starkiller himself. At times he seemed to show little or no emotion, while the scene led me to believe otherwise. It looked very awkward and weird, and happened at least 2 or 3 times during the entire game.The story, which is uninteresting but has a nice little twist in it, is still very decent for a Star Wars game. I'm not a die hard fan of the movies, but I do appreciate them and the fact that you can choose between a Dark and Light ending gives the game some kind of replay value. Which still isn't a lot, considering the game can be finished in 4 or 5 hours. But the story still feels rushed and you have the feeling that you missed out on certain things. Maybe because of time or money constraints, I don't know.The combat is good, with enough enemy variety that require you to use your different abilities and tactics. I've seen games where you have tons of abilities and in the end only used 2 of them, but not in this one. So, again, a plus.There's not much to upgrade this time. I'm not sure if I remember it correctly, but I thought the first game had much more things to upgrade and unlock. Still, it could be my memory.Star Wars The Force Unleashed II was made to make money (like pretty much any other game), but in the end it just feels rushed and incomplete. I wish they had taken more time to flesh things out, like the skills and the interface, but more importantly, the story. And despite all these flaws it's still not a bad game. Just a decent one.[Rating: 75/100]

content:
Posted: August 6, 2013
												Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II is an action-packed, over-the-top hack-and-slash game. If ever you wanted to slice right through an AT-AT with your lightsaber or fling Storm Troopers around with your force powers, then this might be the Star Wars game for you. Unfortunatley it does suffer many techincal problems, framerate issues, and does not play well with Radeon-based graphics cards.The game picks up where they first title left off. You play Starkiller, the apprentice of Darth Vader as he struggles with his own personal identity, and his place in aiding the Rebellion.There are multiple endings, but the game is short and at times frustrating, so the replay value is low. It only takes around five hours to play through the game and much of is taken up by repetitive boss battles that start off interesting, but become an exercise in frustration afrer repeating the same mechanic four or five times.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Personally, I only recommend picking up this game if/when it's on sale (I was fortunate enough to pick it up for $3 during the Summer sale). There's definitely fun to be had in this game; the force powers you receive and using your lightsaber are enjoyable and make you feel powerful. However, the gameplay is very repititious and the main campaign is shockingly short. I beat it on medium difficulty in around 5 hours, and the other modes do not add much replayability. This is definitely a one-and-done game.One thing worth noting is that this game is beautiful. I'm only running an HD4850 at the moment and I was able to max out the settings with antialiasing and a resolution of 1440x900 while maintaining a solid framerate. I found myself taking several moments in-between combat sections just to stop and enjoy the visuals.If you're looking for some quick action and some eye candy, wait for it to go on sale and pick it up. I don't think it's worth the $20 price tag because it's so incredibly short, but if you get it for less you just might enjoy the ride.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												TL;DR: Bottom line, it wasn't as good as the first one and felt a little rushed.So let me just start by saying that I am writing this review as a huge Star Wars fan and even as someone who loves this universe and it's lore, this game was not impressive. Pros:1. It has more graphics settings options than the first game, which basically only had one option: high detail or not.2. You use two lightsabers instead of one. I was a marauder in SWTOR so this really appealed to me.3. Improved lightsaber violence. I've played a few games as a Jedi/Sith but this is the first where you actually dismember and decapitate your enemies when you hit them with your lightsaber. Nice detail there.Cons:1. Short. I beat the game in only about 6 hours and I played the first game for almost three times as long. I have not yet nor do I really plan to try the challenges.2. It was choppy. I certainly meet the recommended requirements but I still had issues with screen tearing and just low levels of detail. I don't think it looked as good as the screen shots.3. The story wasn't all that interesting. He's a clone, wants to be with Juno and fights Vader. The end. I'm glad I never read the novelization for this. Based on the final cut scene there might have been a TFU3, but that'll never happen.4. The attacks weren't as detailed as the first game. I didn't get to buy various attacks like the first game.5. Dagobah was a huge ripoff. What was the point of it?6. WAY too much action. Seriously the game was non-stop storm trooper slaughter; you never got a break from it. Always moving forward and killing. It was like a bad action movie. No puzzles or side quests or explorable worlds. At the end of the day, I don't recommend you buy it and play it. If you got it as part of the Star Wars bundle like I did, feel free to give it a shot but don't expect a quality game.  You get to see Boba Fett, but never fight him :(

Posted: March 21, 2015
												I had to write a new an updated review about this game. I had only played 20 minutes of the game on pc since I never got it to run at over 30 frames per second. That is now something of the past. There is a crack that unlocks the game to be played at 60 fps or over with the steam game. Just look for it on Google!Since the Humble bundle sale there has been a large amount of bad reviews of this games some people not being able to run it at over 30 or not run it at all. Problems with the cutscenes etc.I installed the 60 fps unlock and played this game nonstop without any problem at all. Not one cutscene was less than 1080 quality and the game ran perfectly from beginning to end. The crack for the unlock might appear as a virus but that is also fake. The file is fine!I 100% recommend playing this with a gamepad!! Now to the game.I only had played the first forced unleashed (at 30 and with a keyboard and mouse) and loved it. This game TFU2 has everything improved. The controls are way tighter and respond top and the game just runs overall better.I played the game and it took me about 11 hours to finish it. I played it on normal dificulty and must have died maybe once or twice in a level. Maybe sometimes even more. I have read the game clocks 4 hours. That is impossible!Maybe playing it with cheats and on padawan. I went for all the upgrades and played at a normal pace.The graphics of this game are really amazing. everything looks super polished and the effects of this game are really over the top awesome. You can use the force in ways you have never seen.The music is really amazing because we have john williams score from episode 4.5and 6 and it was edited perfectly to fit to the story. The story is not the best but we cant really say any Star Wars story is a oscarworthy material. Its Star Wars and we love it!The gamplay can get somewhat repetative but in the 11 hours I never got sick of the crazy things I could pull off with my character. I recomend doing the challenges to learn some crazy ♥♥♥ movements and do them in the story. This game plays like your typical God of War, Devil May Cry over the top hack n slash. The game is great fun and should be highly enjoyed if you grew up with Star Wars.I give this game a 9/10 since its originally locked at 30. But overall this game is truly amazing and wont dissapoint.

												Oh dear...No, it's not as good as the predecessor. Really isn't.Best I tell you why, right? Let's start with the good.Two lightsabers. Yeah, pretty awesome, looks neat too. Graphics are a serious step up from the HQ edition of the first game. Lots of rain too. I like rain.The new levelling system is very simplified, which doesn't seem entirely good, until you realize the following problem with the game: It's considerably shorter.That's right. There's about four to five area's you go to, technically.You escape from the Clone Facility in Kamino, save your friend Kota from that dusty Arena, say hi to Yoda while you go to that swamp to get a vision, then defend a rebel ship that's part of the fleet attacking Kamino. Everyone abandons ship and you send the ship on a crash course straight into the cloning facility, where you go beat Vader's metal butt.THAT is IT. You get a Dark or Light side ending, which are both very unsatisfying. (look them up on Youtube)There's about four costumes you unlock through this. One isn't even automatically equipped, since it's only used in a cutscene.The others are unlocked by having a save from the first game, picking an ending, and playing the challenges.The acting... it's mediocre. Listening to Starkiller was much less enjoyable this time. He comes over as juvenile, maybe even arrogant, and seems to have a sort of grunt to him that just doesn't quite cut it. Not to mention his pain grunts in combat are simply annoying.The challenges are as fun as they sound. If you like practising using block to redirect missiles back at attackers and survive for as long as possible, then you'll like that challenge.Regardless, they're not a worthwhile replacement for the lack of story this game has. There's no extra levels. Just an unlocked difficulty in the end.This is one of those games where I wish it never existed. It's only a detriment to it's predecessor. A memory that should've stayed untouched.Too bad, really. If the developers had held the same standards as the first game had, this would have turned out alright. But there's just so much removed and so much simplified, it falls short in such a sad way. I'm really saddened by this game.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
												I think it's time to give this game a review. I will give a proper review, most of my other games that I review are short reviews. I will go over, Gameplay, Story, Voice Acting and Characters and Boss Fights.GameplayThe gameplay I found very fun, if you really dig physic games I really recommend you pick this game up. The way Force powers and enimies interact with the enviroment are really good, so if you are into enviromental destruction you will like this game. The Lightsaber, Force and Lightning combat I found really fun and funny at times, such as fully slicing your enimies to pecies, Forcing them to thier deaths or even throwing them sky high, but the best Is throwing them at each other. The Lightning powers are fun to use aswell, such as shocking the Jumptroopers until thier Jetpack goes out of control and colides with thier own. There are many combos you can do that make Lightsaber combat fun such as, Saber Slam, Lightsaber Throw, Grab Attack ect.StoryI found alot of people really hated the story, I found some parts really good such as the "Lightside Ending". The way Darth Vader says, "As long as she lives, I will always control you", really made me wonder what the next game would be like story wise. The "Darkside Ending" was decent the music for the cutscene really got to me and some sadness sunk into me aswell. There is a part in there that they just used as a fill in, the Dagobah mission which was pointless making you wonder for 30 seconds until meeting Yoda in a cutscene then your off the planet for good, they could have just made the level with something more to do and it would have made the game abit better. I know there are Holocrons there but again 'No Point', if they had made it longer It would make more sense to put them in. The original Force Unleashed had a better story overall.Voice Acting and CharactersThe voice acting in this game is Top Notch the cutscene after you defeat the Gorog aboard the Rouge Shadow you and General Kota get into a argument, the voice acting was so good in that part that It sounded like a real argument should be between two people, overall the voice acting is great in this game. You will meet characters from the original Force Unleashed which is nice, characters such as, Proxy, General Kota, Juno, Princess Leia and of course Darth Vader. The character modles are well down aswell, making them feel alive to you, and of course voice acting for all characters are great.Boss FightsThere are four boss fights in this game. The first one between you and the Imperial Gunship is short and repetitive, I didn't like this boss fight. The second one between you and the Gorog I thought was excellent, there are three parts to this boss fight. The third one between you and the Terror Droid is good, there are two parts to it. The final boss fight between you and Darth Vader is pretty good there are two parts to this boss battle.ConclusionTo be honest being a huge Star Wars fan I really enjoyed this game. I know alot of people out there really hated it but that is thier opinion. So if you like Star Wars or anything mentioned above, I do recommend this game.

number of helpful: 37 of 58 people (64%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II is the second instalment in the series. Being developed by Aspyr Media and published by Lucas Arts, taking place between the 3rd and 4th episodes of Star Wars. The game was released in October 2010 on PC, Xbox 360, PS3, Nintendo DS and the Wii. The game continues the story of you playing Starkiller, a student of Darth Vadar. The gameplay is very much the same as the first game, but we have some new additions to his force abilities, such as Mind Tricks, allowing you to mind control enemies to either fleeing the fight or fighting on your side. The second new element is the ability to use Force Fury; which is basically you enraged form that allows you to go crazy with lighting fast light sabre hits, fancy flips and electric force shots and all sorts of craziness.  The overall gameplay is essentially the same as the first game, though. Enemy fights throughout the level are very samey throughout your play through; with a few new enemies being added in which require a “rock paper scissors” way of thinking so only one of your abilities beat them, whilst the rest of virtually no damage. The boss fights in Unleashed II are a bit of a let down apart from the final scenes. Quick time events play a prominent part in any boss fight which is something I absolutely detest most of the time. It felt very cheap and showed a lack of innovation to force a key boss fight to be resolved by simply using quick time events. The only boss fight throughout the game that was anything at all compelling is the final fight with Darth Vader which is rather memorable in my opinion of being one of the better boss fights from the series so far.  The graphics are sadly very drab too; the low-quality textures and poor quality models ruin the game’s aesthetic. The game does have a few redeeming factors in that the special effects from lightning and the light sabres do look really good, though. The voice acting from the main characters just feel a little bit off; I couldn’t quite put my finger on what was different but it just felt very poorly executed in the final cut. Darth Vadar and Yoda have the best voice acting throughout but the main character, Starkiller just sounds so monotone that you’d find it a challenge to stay awake listening to him for any extended amount of time. Difficulty wise, Unleashed II is easier than the first game; there are no challenging fights or platforming scenes, you can ramp up the difficulty at the start of the play through but the lack of being able to change this on the fly once you have started is disappointing. Like I said, boss fights usually conclude in quick time events and regular enemy fights are nothing other than a time filler as they offer no challenge what-so-ever.  I finished the game in just under four hours; which is similar to the time it took me to finish the first game, so there has been no improvement made on the amount of content on offer. This was another huge disappointment for me as the story really could be explained and drawn out a little longer for the benefit of the player. You may be able to squeeze a second play throughout of this game but only if you didn’t finish the game the first time round on hard mode. There is a selection of collectables to find throughout the story mode which allows you to customize your light sabres colours but there isn’t really anything else other than that available. The game is also riddled with technical problems. The main one being the frame rate is capped at 30. This is an absolute disgrace even though it was six years ago – don’t cap frame rates.  Secondly is the huge amount of graphically tearing and no options are available for v-sync to fix it. I also had a number of crashes to desktop during my time playing too; these come just before you reach a save point on a level too which leaves you with the annoyance of having to replay the last checkpoint of the previous stage too. It’s also worth mentioning that I played the game completely using my 360 controllers, the mouse, and keyboard support is lacking so I wouldn’t even suggest trying them. Sadly Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II is a poor excuse for the second instalment in this series. The first game is a country mile better and being a fan of Star Wars I was hugely disappointed with the overall production values on offer here as well as an extremely short experience.  The technical problems and repetitive nature of the gameplay does the game no favours either. This game is nowhere near worth the price of £14.99 and it should not be recommended for anyone but hardcore fans of Star Wars, and even then it is with a huge caution.   Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Not Recommended3) Only recommended when on sale4) Recommended5) Highly recommended6) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here and checking out the TeamTom Review site[teamtomreviews.co.uk]

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												The game has certainly improved upon the graphics from the first iteration; however there are many negative aspects as to why you should most likely avoid this title unless the game is on sale for a lower price of $20. Pros:*Good campaign (Continues the story of “Star Killer”)*Greatly improved graphics from the first game.*Dual Lightsabers (Customizable colors with corresponding bonuses)*New Mind Trick Ability (Can persuade others to kill for your or they kill themselves in various ways)Cons:*Very short campaign (Beat in a little less than 4 hours)*Very little replay value*Not as many Jedi Duels (First game had a 3-5 good duels, where as in this game you only get one or two true duels with Darth Vader only)*Very little variety with grip combos (Always stab and throw, unlike the first game)*Story is not as strong as the last (Few cut scenes here and there, but story is not as compelling leaving you wondering why the characters are arguing in the first place in various parts of the campaign.)*Limited level design (Very little level variety, unlike the first game where you are on planets of various planet types)This is not a bad game, however for its little replay value and very short campaign it is not really worth the $20 price tag. Best to wait for this on sale, as the game is not worth more than $10

												Despite the fact I actually like this game and The Force Unleashed as a series, I have to give this a thumbs down. Why? There are two main reasons:1. The PC port is♥♥♥♥♥♥poor. Half the time the game won't even load up for me, and the other half it works perfectly fine. This is literally within seconds of closing it down once for freezing on the opening logo and then opening it up again using steam. Absolutely no changes were made to any part of the PC or any software on my PC, including steam. When you get in the game, there are constant issues. Clipping and hilariously bad rendering where sometimes the top half of the screen looks like it has been cut away from the bottom and slid to the side. This is on a GTX 560 ti, which is quite a powerful little card in itself. 2. The game is stupendously short. You can reach the end in two and a half hours on normal if you've played spectacle brawlers with platforming elements before. No, I'm not kidding: two and a half hours. Even for £5 on sale it's an absolute ripoff. There are a variety of other issues with the game, including:- Story being non-existent. It really does feel like a cash-in. No thought was put into it at all. Using the already lame clone excuse in order to pull the player in for another full-priced ride that has poorer combat and lasts only 20% of time it took to beat the original game is incredibly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ of the publisher and dev. - Repetitive enemies. Each enemy type has a particular way to beat them; a single weakness the game tells you the moment you meet them. The rest of the level is then you exploiting that weakness and meeting the same enemies again... And again... And again. - You meet Yoda. At one time I thought this would have been cool... Now it just feels forced. "Look how Star Wars we are! We're part of the universe!" Not to mention, the 'level' you meet Yoda in (yes, it's counted as one of nine levels) involves jumping up a cliff then running into a cave. There's no combat whatsoever. It's basically a five minute cutscene. - Plot holes and inconsistencies; general lack of an attempt to flesh out the narrative. They could have done a hell of a lot with clone Starkiller, but they didn't. They just used it as an excuse to bring him back for a sequel. However, if you really don't care about any of the above problems and don't mind the price and/or are a big fan of the first game, it might be worth picking up solely based on the cool-factor of a boss fight against an alien 1000x your size while plummeting towards a planet surface. That's about the only cool thing I found in this, though.If you want a Force Unleashed game, play the first.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												fairly fun game, im a bit of a sucker for the franchise and im pretty upset that there wont be a third one. i find these games to be an awesome AU, Galen Marek is quite an interesting character in a hell of a situation. anyway, ill try to piece some things here:the combat here in this game is both different and the same from the first game. now with 2 lightsabers in this game, Galen has a few more interesting attacks that are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fun to watch, but being a simple hack-and-slash game, they are all just done by mashing your attack button. the bad thing here is that the combat was SUPER simplified from the first game to here, there are very very few actual combos that were carried over. that bothered me a bit, but i do like that combat feels and looks a lot smoother. just wish there was more variety in attacks. unlocks for your upgrades have been made much more simplified. there are still 3 tiers to unlock, but now with using a point count instead of leveling and force spheres, and there are only upgrades for your sabers, push, lightning, repulse, saber throwing, and the quite useless mind trick power, i think that is it. no combos to unlock, nothing other than how good these things are to use, so relatively few differences. saber customization has combines unique effects with colors, so now there can be mixed and matched blade colors and effects, such as better healing and quicker force regen, or more points per kill, or more points for environmental destruction. there is a HUGE graphical difference in the game, this one is much more polished and easier on the eyes and it doesnt take a beefy♥♥♥♥♥computer to play it.since this game is a hack and slash kill em all, there is just a lot of button mashing, and a looooot of QTE's. the enemies now....most all of the range enemies in this game are simple fodder. they will just about never pose an issue, same as in the first game. there are more melee based enemies now, and a few more special enemies, such as one that resists your force powers and forces saber combat only, and several saber weilding chumps who will block near every attack you throw at them, force and saber alike, so you need to find your own ways to dispatch these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. there are a few enemies used a lot that are giant droids and GOD ARE THEY AGGRAVATING AS ALL HELL TO FIGHT. the large riot-like droids that use ice attacks early on and then get upgraded to fire of all things, as well as these Necron looking things about halfway through the game, are nearly impossible to take on in melee combat, forcing you to just widdle their health down with force lightning while constantly kiting them around, this will become very infuriating, VERY fast. you simply cannot fight them with sabers, they will knock you back causing ragdolling every single time. there are new missile shooting AT-ST things that are hilariously easy to defeat. there are a few others that feel kinda fun to fight, interesting mechanics and all. you will see what im talking about in the screenshots up there.the story was not nearly as long as the first one, and this game does feel like it was rushed, but there are signs here that the devs wanted to make an epic, story driven masterpiece. i dont know what happened, but it is a true shame because this game could have been amazing. now, i wouldnt call it bad either, i had fun playing it, even with a nearly 45 minute long boss fight with a huge ugly♥♥♥♥♥monster thing, and another with Vader at the end, which was by far the coolest and most badass part of the game, from start to ♥♥♥♥ing finish, the entire fight with Vader was the coolest♥♥♥♥♥♥ever, and i was HYPE when it was going down. but how he survived *that* is sooo far beyond me. maybe, when you see it, this is why he died so easily in the film?now, i will also say this: if you do play this game, please just pick the light-side ending because the dark side one is reeeeeeally disappointing and short. the light-side one is where its at, and was considered the "canonical" ending. it doesnt matter any more though, since FU3 was canned with no hope in sight for revival.all in all, i enjoyed this game despite its quirks, and i would probably play it again in the future when i have spare hard drive space. i definitely recommend playing it, especially for the story if anything.

												I got The Force Unleashed II from a Humble Bundle and the only reason I tried to play it was that the first game left at least some pleasant memories. Despite all the warnings that set my expectations extremely low, this was still a complete diappointment. The game feels rushed, is very short, has numerous technical issues (especially on PC - awful port once more) and the story is really not worth mentioning. The force powers don't offer anything new or interesting compared to the first game, the difficulty is pretty much a joke and there was not a single fight, cutscene or even setting that I found memorable. Although I wasn't a big fan of the whole Force Unleashed idea from the beginning, it just hurts to see a game with a good amount of potential like this being turned into such a mess.Bottom line: Only worth it if you're just looking to slice up, electrocute and throw around some troopers. Even then, rather get the first game. Preferably not the PC port. Oh, and don't bother with any of the DLC for either game.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												The Force Unleashed II, sequel to a flawed, but remarkable Star Wars game. Is it good? In a word - yes, it's great fun, but it has one or two glaring issues. Read on, maestro!The original Force Unleashed was an impressive reimagining of the OT universe, truly advancing the design to make the Empire look more evil and, importantly, more high tech than the prequels. The story was fantastic, not quite KOTOR good but certainly enjoyable. However, it had problems - until you unlocked every ability, you felt weak (though this did create a great sense of progression), the Force targeting was annoying, and some of the missions and bossfights were either pathetically easy or insanely hard. Both Force Unleashed games do many things entirely uniquely. No previous Star Wars game has ever given a character of such intense power. Starkiller in both games is considered one of the most powerful Force wielders in the entire universe of SW - and you can feel that.Now, the actual game... well, a lot is better. For one, it's much better looking and has aged better. Graphically, it's actually kinda beautiful, some of the costumes scream to be made in real life with a matched pair of sabers. The design is fantastic, and visually dual lightsabers is just great. Also, cutscenes are no longer horrible looking, where the PC gameplay actually looked better than the cutscenes, the animation is tighter and they look far better - much more cinematic. However there are notable, weird resolution problems like button tips and the menus being low res at 1080p.The targeting has been really tightened up, I hardly ever struggled with moving what I needed to, there are more enemies (and they're less spongey, more mechanic based), lightsaber combat is insanely fun and acrobatic, Starkiller feels more mobile, it feels like they've had time to go back and make it all better, which they have. It's definitely easier, and the boss battles are certainly nowhere near as hard. The original had an interesting balance where either you would utterly obliterate your foes or have to go on the defensive. This is pure attack. In this, Starkiller's at his clear peak - he has two lightsabers (Jar'Kai, hell yeah!) his powers are available far earlier and the game introduces Force Fury - what has to be described as the most insanely powerful use of the Force ever seen, effectively the same as simultaneously using all the Sith Holocrons in the original at once, and then some. If you want to know what it feels like to implode a hallway with relentless blasts of Force energy, look no further. Overall, it does play a lot better than the original! And it is remarkably hard to make a game world with such destructability and yet maintain the cohesive experience. So, giving that The Force Unleashed was really great, doesn't this make TFU II even better? It would, if not for a glaring problem - the game is far too short. And far too location sparse. I finished it in 4 hours and, giving the style of game, there's not too much replay value. It has the awkward feeling of only being a third of the full game - where The Force Unleashed would have gone into a new section of the story, TFU II just... stops. It's not like KOTOR II where it literally dumps you back at the title screen and leaves you confused, but it's close. The story is effectively to let fans who really care about happy endings - the outline of the story follows, it's not really inventive  you are a clone of Starkiller after he died on the Death Star, driven half mad by visions of Juno Eclipse, the love interest in the original, you attack Vader and escape the Kaminoan cloning facility and go to seek her, becoming reacquanited with General Kota and the Rebel Alliance Starkiller built in the original. That's the premise.. Once you've finished that, the game ends - it's clear TFU II was to be a part of a trilogy, but there will likely never be a TFU III due to Disney's takeover. Which is a shame, as the original was incredibly compelling and a very interesting set of ideas. Not to mention Sam Witwer as Starkiller (and bizarrely Palpatine) is very charismatic. This is maintained, although he sounds totally deranged in this (which makes sense) and Palpatine doesn't feature at all.  The game sequel baits HARD at the end too! .There are about four unique locations, against seven or more in the original. They are beautifully done and nicely used, much better level design than the original. However, four is far too few, and you will notice it. One of the locations only exists for a few holocrons and a cutscene, however art makes it clear more was intended - it's probable TFU II had an enormity of cut content. You cut through 'em fast too, giving how powerful Starkiller is, though that happened in the original too at a certain point. Levels do feel shorter too. This reaches the critical problem - length. The story and gameplay, hand in hand, make this an insanely short experience - fun while it lasts, though - which means it can't be recommended at full price. 4 hours for a good player like me is nothing. I lamented Dishonored as being 'criminally short' at 6 hours (however it has tons of replay and is a masterpiece), 7 hours on the original, the missing 3 hours are noted.Can it be recommended at less, like £5? Absolutely. Great game. It's a shame Starkiller's arc will never be completed, and a further shame that this game is so much shorter and story sparser than the original, but that didn't detract from my enjoyment of throwing Stormtroopers off bridges. I'm gonna miss this series...Oh, and a tip - if you can't get it it to run, run it in compatability mode - Windows XP SP3 - fixed a freeze on startup for me. Weird.Two things in the plot: 1. The 'clone' of Starkiller you play may actually be Starkiller all along. It is alluded to as this, we will never know... 2. In the lightside ending Boba Fett chases you at the end to Dantooine - it is explained he breaks Vader out after you capture him.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												[NO SPOILERS]I honestly can't say if I can recommend this game or not, so imagine that this review is Neutral.Story:The story is kind of all over the place, as if they wanted to throw in as many concepts and characters as possible, which, can, with enough time, work, however, in a 4 and a half hour game, there just is not enough time. Because of this, nothing feels fleshed out, everything is just a kinda' cameo, with little to no-reason-given. This is extremely saddening, because I love Star Wars for the storys, everything has meaning and a reason for it's existence...[SPOILER BELOW]For Example:  Boba Fett is in the game, and you see him Kidnap Juno, but there is no reason for him, once the game is completed, his ship comes out of hiding and he flys towards you, then the game just ends, really abruptly.[NO SPOILERS]On the plus side, the story captures your emotion, you feel for the main character and want his journey to come with success, you feel his pain and his reasoning behind all of his actions.Gameplay:The game plays pretty much exactly like the first, just with two Lightsabers... The same powers, the same combat and the same enemies, it gets dull very quickly. I mean, yeah, slicing StormTrooper's limbs off is fun and all, but after around 30 minutes, you've seen everything that the game has to offer. If you played the first game, then you know of the Rancor missions, in which you pretty much have to spam lightning until you can activate a quicktime event. This game also has these events, however, you will experience it behind every second door instead of it being 30 minutes apart as it was in TFU I. Graphics/Port Info:Graphically, the game doesn't hold up by todays standards, but, that's OK, because what it loses in texture quality, it makes up in Architecture... Every environment is beautiful, with awe-inspiring backdrops and planet design that just makes me want to slow pan and take hundreds of screen-captures. In contrast to the textures within the game, however, the cinematics are stunningly realistic, with faces that just look real and action that just bursts with excitement. But, as always, there are some drawbacks, the game is capped at 30fps, which just doesn't give it justice, so I would 100% recommend downloading the FPS unlocker online, it just makes the experience tenfold better. To add to that, the PC controls work horrendously, much as TFU did, so, I would recommend you play with a controller.Conclusion:The Force Unleashed II is a short, flawwed title that is repetative and suffers from too many Quick Time Events, however, underneath is a reasonably solid story with much power and emotion that is able to drive the player to continue to the end. The game didn't add much over it's predeccessor, however, my fondness for it enabled me to see through it's cons and focus on what is in the game, rather than what is not.6/10.[P.S. Vader's voice actor sounds more like Oprah Winfrey than Darth Vader.][P.P.S [spoiler]Dark Side Ending is♥♥♥♥♥♥ not worth at all, don't even bother.[/spoiler]][P.P.S Music was good, reminded me of that tram mission from JKJA.]

I'm looking at you MGS V. Not every game needs to be 50+ hours long, in fact I'd go as far as to say games with a short and sweet campaign are more needed. Much, muuuuuch better than the first one. So far at least. I'll update if I feel it necessary once I've finished it but I'm enjoying it a lot more than the first. The graphics are obviously better, the scope of the levels is bigger and more detailed, the combat is more fluid and looks better. It's just better. You start already quite powerful but not in a way that makes it too easy, just in a way that makes it fun right off the bat.The story seems very good so far, I've experienced only very minor issues. The very occasional and slight graphical glitches and the worst one, when I first loaded it up I struggled to change the settings because you can only do it by mouse and it was slightly out of sync with the actual cursor. It was fine after a reboot though. How the first one got a sequel: Understandably.How this one DIDN'T get a sequel: Mystifying. Or at least a spinoff.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												(possible minor/major spoilers ahead) Following on from an amazing game in The Force Unleashed, I came into this with mixed emotions. Given most track records with sequels, and what happened at the end of the first game, I didn't know what to think of this, and yet given how amazing the first game was, I thought they might just pull it off. However, as much as the gameplay was decent, the story lacked any sort of conviction, or plausability. This was a money sequel, just as I had feared, and added nothing to the first game. I didn't come away feeling any different, the ending of the first game was more than appropriate to answer most questions, about what happens between Star Wars: Episode 3 and Episode 4. Even though the gameplay was okay, the length of the main storyline is a joke. The first game spanned an epic variety of environments and enemies. Whilst this game I felt like I spent almost all the game just fighting regular Storm Troopers, who are the squishiest of squishies. In the first game, you visit multiple planets, and also revisit them several times, in a star spanning quest. In this, you visit a total of 4 different areas. Almost none of which you spend any meaningful amount of time in, such as 1 planet, where you spend 5 seconds walking around, and then about 2 minutes of cutscene. That's it. The only planet you do spend any reasonable amount of time on, you feel like you're seeing the same thing over and over again, due to how mind numbingly boring and samey the architecture is. So, if you like the gameplay of the first game, but don't particularly want any sort of meaningful addition to the story, or area design of the first game, then this is the game for you! Otherwise, don't play it.Edit: Also, about the only redeeming factor of this game, is that it had a first game.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Well, where should I start?Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II is a direct sequel of Star Wars: The Force Unleashed. (Pretty obvious, right?)I won't go into details about the story in order to avoid potential spoilers in case you're interested in buying this game. But, I'll just say that, although linear, it's pretty solid and not as bad as some people say. I'm a huge Star Wars fan and I really enjoyed it. After finishing TFU, I was wondering if the story could continue and TFU2 surprised me a lot, giving me some hours of fun.Let's start with the review, shall we?First of all, do not pay attention to the people that often speak bad things about this game. But, just in case, I'll take in consideration some points that most people complained aboutYes, is a pretty short game. Yes, it has abundant and repetitive QTE's (Quick Time Events). Yes, it's not a flawless port. Yes, it may be somewhat easy if you managed to finish the first game in Sith Master difficulty.But, let's look at the bright side. I have actually enjoyed the game.  The gameplay of the game is very similar to the previous one, but instead of one lightsaber, now you have two. It's still a great Hack N' Slash, indeed. New enemies, new threats, new combos and the possibility to test your abilites with the Challenge mode (Once you win a challenge, you unlock videos that give more information about the story).Despite that the port was not something out of this world, the graphics are beautiful and the evironments are beautifully crafted, recreating a gorgeous Star Wars atmosphere.As I've said before, I'm a big fan of the Star Wars universe and the replayability comes from two sides. Firstly, if you're interested in test your ability in Unleashed mode and secondly, if you enjoyed the story and would like to experience a different ending.If you ask me what I dislike the most about this game, I'll tell you two things. First, that the Endor DLC is only available for consoles. And, last but not least, the lack of achievements. I like to test myself with the achievements and, also, they enlong the playability of the game.Do you want my honest opinion? It's a good game, there's no doubt about that. But, perhaps you would like to wait until it's on sale.On the other hand, if you're a big Star Wars fun, wait no more and buy it right now. The fun is guaranteed.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
-Disclaimer- Ahh, the unpopular red "not recommend button", before you vote down my review because I'm not recommending your favorite game, hear me out: I personally enjoyed the game... my Q, E, and space bar are offended from all the button mashing, but as a whole I enjoyed the game.So why am I not recommending it? Because I'm thinking beyond my own view, most of my friends would rather play a star wars RPG, then this game. As far as console to PC ports go this one has many flaws that makes it annoying to play, I can overlook these and enjoy the time I spent in the game, but not everyone can; so that is why I'm not recommending it.-Quick Review-The Force Unleashed II is a third person hack and slash that implements various combo's that are all unlocked from the first game, and quick time events. If the second game is compared to the first, the Force Unleashed II; has better special effects, most constant action, a shorter story, but is still fundamentally similar in play style. -Detailed breakdown review- Story:  Welcome back to life Starkiller, that is... If you ARE Starkiller, we don't really know - and you (the player) don't either. The first level starts out with some dazzling special effects and action scenes, upon finishing that level I thought "well... good luck trying to make that any more exciting, developers. You hit the limit."I was more or less correct, the story just kind of sits there, Commander Rahm Kota just yells at you over the comm; while you ignore him and slice through stormtroopers... doing what he was telling you to do unintentionally. The layouts are usually very linear, at one time I confused myself, because I over thought the "puzzle".Serious answer: You are allegedly a clone of Starkiller, Vader as appointed you to take up Starkillers role in the destruction of the rebels. However, the clone is having flashbacks which are supposedly memories from the original Starkiller, distracting him and at times letting his enemies get the upper hand. Clone-Starkiller escapes Lord Vader and tries to assist the rebels and find "Juno" who is a shuttle pilot, whom Starkiller is obsessed with.  Game Play: The Force Unleashed II was designed for a console; but I played the whole thing with a keyboard and mouse. I doubt that this game NEEDS to be played with a controller, but you can tell from playing that the game was not designed for a keyboard and mouse.As was already mentioned earlier, The Force Unleashed II implements quick time events, which prevent me from being able to enjoy the exciting execution scenes, and always keep me on my toes (either you like quick time events or you don't... I personally don't, they're distracting).Mostly all of the combo's from the first Force Unleashed game, are already unlocked, so I was using force combo's right at the start of the game; which naturally I enjoyed. I've always liked using different attack patterns, often times to beat a group of enemies or a certain boss you would just need to find the one "perfect" combination to make them all a joke.There were four NPC's that broke up the fun hack-and-slash nature of the game, AT-ST's ("Walkers"), AT-MP's ("Missile-Walkers"), Carbonite War Droid's, and the notorious Incinerator War Droid's. Once you face one or a combination of the listed NPC's, brace yourself because you need to time your force catch, throw and/or block. Achievements: There are no Steam-achievements for the Force Unleashed I or II. This may change someday but at this time (02/10/15) there are no steam achievements. The reason I think it may change is because there are xBox achievements for accomplishing various challenges in the game.While there are no Steam Achievements, the extra's and unlockables are still available, including some mini games (challenges) that you unlock after playing through the game. The challenges generally capitalize on teaching you how to master a skill you learned from the main story... block, jumping puzzles, combo attacks, etc. Price:  The Force Unleashed II is priced at $19.99, I like to spend an hour's worth of time in a game for every dollar I spend; but I only spent 8.4 hours in the game before I had earned pretty much everything, except beating the game on the hardest difficulty, and getting platinum on each challenge.So my feeling on the price is, that it's high. I got my copy of The Force Unleashed I and II from a humble bundle. (for what it's worth, they're the titles that attracted me to the bundle most. Aside from "Star Wars Humble Bundle", just take my money already) Conclusion: Okay, I'll quickly compress the good and the bad of the Force Unleashed.Pros: * The game is a very fun hack-and-slash * The combo's in the game as very natural feeling *Excellent special effects *Nice cut scenes * Hey, it's star wars, I like that, I'm a fan, I can't help it * Force Lightning ( <<< Excellent reason!) *Many costumes to unlock (about 20 of them) * Challenges *Database entrees are amusingCons:*The story will be played through in about 7-8 hours, on easy mode it would be even more fast! *the Boss battles are dull repetitive sequences of telegraphed signs to dodge, followed by button mashing *Button Mashing, mash all the buttons *mediocre story (the extra's reveal they were going to have more! I assume they ran out of budget money... I blame level 1 being so amazing and taking up all the budget)You can definitely decide for yourself if you want to play this game. An easy way to know is to figure out your opinion on the first game: if you liked Force Unleashed I you will like the second. If you're not put out by any of the down sides of the game, you should totally get it! If you have any doubt at all about the game, you should probably should skip this one, buddy.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update April 10, 2015:Here's the URL to see my review for The Force Unleashed I

Posted: February 9, 2015
												Star Wars The Forced Unleashed II is a great game by Lucasarts, and it is really hard to believe that this game is now 5 years old. Now don't get me wrong, it has many flaws, but despite the mixed response to the game, I thoroughly enjoyed it.  The graphics in this game are great for it's age and an upgrade from the previous game. The cutscenes in this game also blew me away as well with how good they were. I also really enjoyed the gameplay. I thought that the lightsaber combat was amazing, but at times you will feel like a god anayalating everything in your path, I also liked the force and how there were different force powers and combos. I wasn't very fond of the lighting though, as it was sometimes randomly stop. To me, the storyline of the game wasn't great either. You start as Starkillers clone on Kamino, but after failing to overcome his feelings, you are to be executed by Vader. You then in a desperate attempt for your life, flee off Kamino. You then head to Cato Neimoidia, to save Rahm Kota from the arena. After this you go ahead to save Juno Eclipse, the original Starkiller's love intrest who you, the clone of Starkiller, still has feelings for.The game becomes very repetetive over time. As each level brings in new enemies and abilities, these become constantly repeated throughout the whole level, which becomes time consuming and boring. I also wish the game was longer. I bought the game along with 8 other Star Wars games, so I tried this out first. I ended up beating in in two days (or 15.9 hours) which was a shame because when the game ended, I was craving more.To sum it up, I really enjoyed this game, despite it's many flaws, it had great gameplay and combat, and was generally fun to play. So I am going to be giving this an 8/10

content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												Terrible, terrible, terrible. The entire game is a repetitive slog, especially the combat. If they had cut out the filler, the game would've been a fun 30 minutes. It has its spectacular moments, but they are few and far between and don't make up for the repetitive and boring gameplay. It's not just repetitive, though, it's also clunky and buggy. I had several times where I failed jumps and lost several minutes of progress because of the strange movement engine - I would jump and they would perform the jump animation but not leave the ground, then I would fall to my death. I also had cutscenes just straight up freeze on me several times. The worst case was the cutscene that plays when you finish the game. It just froze. I had to watch the ending on youtube. Combat is made even worse with the inclusion of quick time event kills. The same canned animations play over and over again when you finish off some of the tougher robot enemies. It's cool the first time only.Want an actually fun action game / brawler? Try Bayonetta, God of War, Dante's Inferno, or any of the many other games where they actually thought about the gameplay and fun and the experience of playing instead of just trying to make it a spectacle and cash in on the star wars IP. Want a good star wars game? Try republic commando (or, if you don't dislike RPGs, KOTOR and KOTOR 2).Don't buy this game, and if you do play it for some unfortunate reason, play it on easy. The difficulty scaling is stupid and doesn't make the game more interesting, it just makes it more frustrating and tiresome.

Posted: May 12, 2015
												TLDR - If you liked Star Wars the Force Unleashed 1, you should enjoy part 2. The game is much shorter but takes up much less of your hard drive space, and you may actually want to replay it, unlike its predecessor. - 7.5/10*Spoilers for first game*The Force Unleased 2 continues the adventures of Darth Vader’s former apprentice Starkiller who actually died at the end of the first game if you chose the “light side” ending. If you chose the dark side ending, well, you were in a whole new timeline that directly contradicts the Star Wars movies.  In part 2, you awaken in captivity and are told by Vader that you’re actually a clone of the original Starkiller, kind of like Milla Jovovich’s character in the Resident Evil movies. Basically Vader’s making a bunch of super powered clones so when one dies in training, he’ll just wake up another one. Fortunately for you, this clone is actually as powerful as the original Starkiller and can kick some♥♥♥♥♥with his dual lightsabres (twice as many as in the first game). Just like The Force Unleased 1, the game is played in the third person perspective with your main attacks being quick swings with your laser swords and your ranged attacks being force powers. There have been some refinements to the gameplay system so the sword attacks seem to flow better compared to the first game, both in combat and the way you upgrade your skills. You no longer have to navigate a long list of sword attacks that you need to buy one by one. Now you upgrade your sword skill just like any other force power and it automatically improves your sword combos. Speaking of upgrades, the game now uses a visible “experience” system where you can actually see how many points you have to buy skills with (similar to Darksiders). You don’t “level up” in the game, you just buy upgrades with the experience you earn. There are holocrons (treasures) hidden around the levels just like the first game that contain things like bonus experience and different upgrade crystals for your lightsabres. Most of the enemies you face are Imperial stormtroopers though there are a few new big dudes and annoying spider bots. Just like the first game, the large enemies have a ton of health if you try to slice them to death, but after you’ve done significant damage, you have the opportunity to kill them via quick-time events. You definitely should take advantage of this because unlike the first game, most of the big guys don’t get “stunned” by your force lightning. Overall though, I think you’ll find the game easier than part 1 because of a new auto-heal system where you can regen most of the life you just lost if you don’t take damage for a few seconds. Pros:+Hack and slash adventure in the Star Wars universe. The story is actually pretty short (lengthened by long battles) but it is decent. Most of the characters from the first game return in case you’re emotionally invested in any of them.+ The game is simplified compared to Force Unleashed 1, which is a good thing because part 1 was unnecessarily complex in some parts (such as the upgrade system). It also seems to be better optimized for the PC and doesn’t have so many damn loading screens. I played both games with mouse + keyboard by the way.Cons:-It’s nice to have challenging boss battles, but some of these fights are a pain because of how long they are, especially at the end. The boss has a ton of health and you can only chip away about a millimeter from their life bar at a time. And that’s if he’s not blocking all your shots. It’s not like he’s throwing out cool attacks either, just the same stuff repeated a few dozen times.-The game is very short compared to the first Force Unleashed, about half as long actually. And since this isn’t a Game of the Year (Force Unleashed 1 was “Ultimate Sith Edition” with included DLCs) there aren’t as many extras this time around. Overall the game is fun and you can beat it in a day if you want to sit down for 6 hours. There isn’t too much variety in skill paths, although I didn’t have enough points to buy everything by the end of the game. If I want to focus on “force persuasion” I’ll have to play the game again, which I probably will in the future.

For having to do that several times I am still pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥find the SWTF2.exe (whatever the name is) in it's directory, right click > properties > compatability:   -compat with windows xp   -desktop compat   -adminAlso I ran it in resolution native to the game which was really low rez for the initial intro. That allowed me to get into the game and not crash my computer. After letting the game save during game-play a few times I notched up the graphics to 1920 x 1080 and it finally started working. Not sure why it took a wind up but it did.Hope that helps someone. I was pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and many people who tried using this game never got it working. Good luck to you. Just keep trying stuff until it works.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												What would've been a decent game is ruined by its length.The Force Unleashed 2 has great graphics, an interesting story, and decent combat. But why do I not recommend it? This game is insultingly short.  About two hours into the campaign and I was reaching the climax of the game. I'm serious. The game sequel baits and sets up for the Force Unleashed 3. Unfortunately, it was cancelled due to Disney purchasing the Star Wars franchise. It's a shame too, considering this game really depended on there being a third installment.Oh, and this game is absurdly over-the-top. This is Star Wars, not God of War. I'm very glad that it's noncanon.I'd say give it a shot if it's on sale and you have about three hours to kill. Don't spend more than $5 on this game, and especially don't buy the DLC.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												Star Wars the Force Unleashed IIThis takes place a few years after the (good ending) events of Force Unleashed I, and through this time it is questioned but not ever officially told if the Hero, Starkiller is simply a clone of his former self, or the true Starkiller who somehow survived all this time. The past memories of Starkiller are starting to drive this "clone" mad, and he must try to finish what Starkiller started in the last one, and end to the Empire!This game is MUCH shorter than the first game, and after what you did in the first one, everything done here just seems...EH. True, in this game you do defeat a giant monster in an Arena, take down Darth Vader (again) but, in the previous game you killed MULTIPLE Jedi, brought a Star Destroyer down from space, formed the rebel alliance, etc. The combat, is an improvement, as well as the game graphicly. However, the game is just so short, the collectibles, are not really worth much, other than skins and SLIGHTLY different lightsabers.The story, isn't nearly as good, and many times the game feels cheap just jerking off for fan service.I GUESS I would recommend this game....on SALE. It can be fun, but only really good for 1-2 playthroughs at best.

content:
Posted: January 3
												Wow......a waste of money even though it came in a bundle. I completed the game in 3.5 hours on medium difficulty and then tried the challenges. The finishing moves on special enemies are scarce and look the same every time. No more sick costumes of jedi and sith that you had in the first game and no compressed or unbalanced saber crystals. Better graphics, but overall just a giant step down. There are no exciting enemies and every mission is basically "kill everyone, unlock the door to the next room and then kill everyone there". The bosses at the end of every one of the 4 missions just suck. Except maybe the big monster thing in the arena, he was kind of cool. Battling Vader is ridiculously boring. You just repeat the same thing over and over and over again until one of the two mediocre endings. The game had potential but ultimately failed to deliver. Do NOT recommend.4/10

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												I just finished this game in 5 hours.  Even despite the reality that the game is too short, that the story has a weak premise, and that General Kota brings back visions of the COs from the weaker Mega Man X games with his constant advice in boss fights and over acted lines.  I still recommend this game.  Why? The Unleashed series and its predecessor get one key thing right.  Powers.This game makes you feel like a badass Jedi.  Not just a Jedi like in the movie, but an actual powerful one.  Granted I'd say that the first game did this a little better, but it's still a fairly rare thing among the various star wars games.  Tthat said, the shortness of the game is a huge problem.  Don't pay more than 10 dollars for this if you can help it.   You can get much better value for that price even among star wars games alone.
