number of helpful: 24 of 47 people (51%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												     All do respect to my fellow Star Wars fans, but what I have to say is  "It's a trap." Enough said. Lucasarts had some issues with the first game and although I loved it I hoped to see improvements in the next. What did I get when playing, a game that just trolls you around in every direction. Here are the stats:Pros: Game has beautiful graphics.Button smashing is easier now, without any hassle.New force powers have been added and force usage per use has been decreased.Iconic heroes from the original movie franchise are present, such as Yoda and Boba Fett.Outstanding audio effects along with the original Star Wars orchestra.Cons:Enemies are pathetic and a lot less boss fights are present. The AT-ST,which is a boss from the first game, takes barely any skill to tear apart.Game is a horrible port from console to PC. The game has a slowmo lag no matter how good your PC is. This is fixable but not for someone without any experience, consider doing some research.Instead of adding elements to the game that excited players throughout the game, the developers turned the game from an awesome and action packed action-adventure game into a action-adventure/puzzle solving game that waisted a lot of people's time and money. Make a single mistake during a few of the more challenging puzzles and you'll end up restarting the checkpoint from a farther distance.Glitches do happen oftenly.Overall:     I own this game on both console (X360) and PC. What do I have to say, don't get it, because its a total waste of your time and money. This game ruined the Force Unleashed series, by turning this game into a trolling puzzle game. There are wayyyyyy less boss fights than the first game and enemies are super easy to take down with practically one swipe to a stromtrooper and a couple blows to a AT-ST. Yup you heard it, the thing that was a boss in Force Unleashed 1 is now and barely is something of a challenge. In the end, I'm glad that Disney bought Star Wars, because the saga seriously needs some fixing up to do.

												Речь в игре идет о безымянном клоне Старкиллера, протагониста первой части, тайного ученика Дарта Вейдера. Не сумев проткнуть мечом голографическую копию бывшей возлюбленной Джуно, Старкиллер сбегает от Вейдера и отправляется на поиски ответов. content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												3/10 It is bad but not terrible. Some good features - Graphics And AI. Bad features - Boring story, Very samey gameplay, no character development, Forces you down one path, Only 9 missions, Very easy even on the hardest difficulty, Very annoying boss battles that are not hard but just so boring and dragged on, Spawning waves and waves of enimies as filler when nothing is happening. Don't get me wrong i did enjoy the first couple of hours but it did just not feel the same as playing the first game. In the first game combat was so much better and the story was alot better. if you are a massive star wars fan "like i am" I would not pay the full price as you would be dissapointed. i only paid £5.00 and even i regret the choise slightly as the game is just dull and when i was playing it i was thinking of what else i could be playing all of the time instead of focusing on the game itself as it has yawnable gameplay and cutcenes. Do not get this game unless it goes on sale once again. i would wait untill at least 90% off to feel like i got my money's worth and even then i probally would not.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												I've only played this game for an hour. This game is so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ repetitive that it hurts my brain playing this for more than 10 minutes.  This is the most insulting game you could make for a hardcore Star Wars fan like me.  This is clearly a rushed out and really poorly made sequel to the original Force Unleashed, which at least  had some spirit to it. Can anyone explain to me WHY IS DARTH VADER CAPTURED AT THE ♥♥♥♥ING END OF THIS GAME? HOW DOES THIS MAKE ANY SENSE? WHY ARE THERE CLONING FACILITIES DEDICATED TO STARKILLER? WHO FUNDED THIS? There are too many glitches, there is an fps lock at 30 fps, the combat never makes you feel like you're hitting anything solid, force powers are boring and have nothing really special to them; you get your typical edgy-teenager force lightning ability and force pushing people everywhere with some more angry-teenager  desired forcepowers like a saber throw, pc  controls are garbage, partial controller support, literally no graphical customization, the art designs for environments seem really artifical and boring, Starkiller screams and moans like a hooker being ♥♥♥♥ed from the beginning of the story and uses that annoying and unrealistic  lightsaber form, which I guess wanna-be-sith-teens find 'really cool and unique'. Vader is once again really stupid and seems juvenile; seriously does he not have anything better to do than just ♥♥♥♥ around with Starkiller?Blah, blah, all of the characters I don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about are back; we're going to random planets again and then we're going to have mindnumbingly boring fights with throwaway stormtroopers and robots the empire is too rich to give a flying♥♥♥♥♥♥about until we defeat Vader in a cliche fit of rage.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												I would not recommend buying this game. In comparison to the first game, the developers have added nothing noteworthy that is new or even slightly different. The combat, skills and even level design is pretty much just more of the same. It would have been nice if (like most hack and slash sequels) they had added one or two new skills to unleash on unsuspecting storm troopers but sadly, even the kill moves (on larger enemies) are pretty much the same as the first game. The story is passable, but is not written half as well as the first game. (potential spoilers!) The real big dissapointment is that the ending really does not lead into the first movie (episode 4 A New Hope) at all as it does not explain what happens to Starkiller, General Kota, Juno, Proxy or even Darth Vader. There is a very small (even miniscule) implication that Boba Fett reclaims vader, but it is so vague it is unreal. Secondly, the game itself is tiny. I have completed the game in a matter of hours, even having to replay 3 of the levels twice due to constant crashing and movie skipping (more on that in a moment). If you take into account the level replays and deduct them from my play time, I would say that this game lasted no more than 3-4 hours tops. In comparison to the first game that took approx 9 hours. What is even more annoying is that several of the levels are based in the same areas of previous levels and so the scenery only really has 3 or 4 notable changes. Ultimately it made the content that is there to play feel very lacking too. The gameplay in general is largely generic too and there were several times wher I forgot I could even upgrade my force powers because in honesty, the "upgrades" didn't really feel like they upgraded anything at all. Aside from the colour of my lightening changing from blue to purple, the force moves seemed to be as potent at the end of the game (post upgrade) as they did at the start. In other words, they barely changed. Finally, the games stability is terrible. Now I played this on Windows 10 Professional, and to begin with I had no issues at all. About 1-2 hours into the game though, I would suddenly get a black screen where nothing happens. I could bring up the in game menu and even go back to the start menu, but the game itself would grind to a halt. If I tried to reload the level, the level would play with no sound. The only way I could fix this was to exit the game completely and restart it, replaying the level from the very beginning (cut scenes and all). This easily added 2 hours (possibly more) onto my overall play time and was extremely frustrating. Another frutrating thing for me was the camera on the jumping levels. Essentially these levels turn the game into a 3d donkey kongue esque platformer where you have to climb to the top, and more often than not I would find my character missing a ledge by a nat's whisker, either pushed off by an invisible air wall or simply jumping in a different direction to where the camera was facing. Again, multiple deaths here added to the games pathetically short play time and didn't add challenge, just frustration. I would say if you absolutely need to see what this game has to offer, then buy it on a console., This PC port is buggy as hell and really is not worth the money they want for it. The story is nonsensical and does absolutely nothing for bridging the first game to the original Star Wars Trilogy and so it is easy to just pass this game by and forget it ever existed. I would say, save your money and replay the first Force Unleashed. It is much better than this one.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												I am a Star Wars fan and even as someone who loves this universe and it's lore, I couldn't get myself to like this game.After playing the first of the two games on I felt compelled to finish the story. The first game had me with it's storyline and pretty fun gameplay. You play a secret disciple to Darth Vader who has a change of heart, but you quickly learn to realize that this storyline and gameplay didn't continue at all into this game. The gameplay does have a little fun to it, once in a while, but it's very lackluster even at the very start. It's very repetitive and just doesn't get you immersed into this character or make you feel very powerful. It feels very choppy and unenjoyable. There's even an instance where you have to bring down a huge Star Destroyer which makes you feel so damn amazing finally, but quickly puts you back to reality once you start trying because the controls and mechanics in which to do so are so obscure that the only way you can find out how to actually complete that part is to youtube the sequence. The mainstory is ridiculously short, I played about 5 hours and finished the entire campaign on Medium, and was easily forgettable.Pros:- It's a Star Wars game?Cons:- Gameplay is lackluster- Storyline is lackluster- Campaign is less than 5 hours long- There's an instance in the game where you must google in order to continue*********TL;DR*********Personally, I only recommend picking up this game if/when it's on sale (I was fortunate enough to pick it up for $3 during the Summer sale). This is definitely a one-and-done game, even for all the die hard Star Wars fans out there. It's just a bad game.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												If this mess had been fully realised it would have been unbelievable, in my opinion. Playing the earliest part of the game I was briefly thrilled. Briefly.All in all this game is one of relentless repetition - often of things that are stupidly easy to do, but impossibly glitchy at the same time. There are about 5 or 6 hours of the game if you don't include an hour or more of repeatedly seeing quicktime events break and re-doing a boss section, and at a rough guess those 5 or 6 hours would boil down to about ~30 minutes to an hour if you took out the repetition - and that's not an exaggeration.My guess is that they couldn't finish the game for some reason, and had to cobble together a game to match the storyboard, out of what they had. If the whole game was made to the standard of the initial encounters, it would have been frankly brilliant.Instead, it is agonizing.Graphics are mostly great (although FPS can be a bit weird), saber/force combat is not bad at all, story is great, I liked the ending. Overall gameplay experience, well they could use it at gitmo to make people talk.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												I bought this game on sale. It was a little bit over £5. After completing it, I felt like this game should never have existed. Where to begin?[THIS REVIEWS CONTAINS SPOILERS FOR THE FIRST STAR WARS: THE FORCE UNLEASHED]As a very big fan of the Original Force Unleashed game, what made the original game so great for me wasn't it's over the top gameplay, but how it played a role in the Star Wars Expanded Universe. It linked Episode III and Episode IV perfectly, detailing how the last few jedis were killed off, how the rebel leaders initially came together, and ended with a satisfying conclusion that perfectly set up "A New Hope," whilst also being conclusive so you feel satisfied with how it ended. However, the Force Unleashed 2 not only rips open that ending and drags out Starkiller's journey, which should have ended at the seemingly conclusive end of the Force Unleashed 1, but tacks on a story that doesn't add ANYTHING new to the Star Wars mythos. In the original, you spend half of the game hunting Jedi, which explains how the survivors of order 66 eventually died, and the other half uniting the galaxy against the empire, which explains how the rebel alliance was formed. In the second game, Starkiller spends it finding his lover. That is the whole story. He doesn't set up major plot events in the films; he doesn't even do anything meaningful in his own mythos. He spends the game looking for his girlfriend, and that's it. He even goes out of his way to stay out of any meaningful plot points; when asked to join the rebels and fight the empire, he basically gives them the finger. The only thing that could have added anything to the Star Wars EU is the ending, which obviously sets up a sequel, but that never arrives. As it is, the ending just breaks the entire lore of the Star Wars Universe.Next, let's look at the game's memorable moments. The original FU had a huge array of great video game and Star Wars moments, something that players and fans would remember for years to come. Hunting rogue jedi, bringing down a Star Destroyer, infiltrating the Death Star, beating the living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of Darth Vader and even fighting the Emperor in a 1 on 1 battle; you did it all. However, the FU2 has a grand total of 1 memorable moment, which is the first boss fight within the first hour and a half of the game. Not even the Final Boss fight against Vader (that’s not really a spoiler, we all knew he would be the boss), the most important part of a game, felt memorable. As it is, for 4 hours, you slice, stab and force your way through the same, (yet granted, interesting) enemies over and over again.Gameplay is up next. Gameplay is a hard one to talk about. Because, I'm gonna be honest, the gameplay was hella fun. The complaints I'm making against gameplay isn't because gameplay is bad, it's because I personally felt that the first game did it better. The thing is, even though the force powers in the first game were pretty insane, the new ones are even more unrealistic, with the player wielding 2 lightsabers and whizzing about the map firing out lightning and bursts of energy at will. And while it was both fun to and brilliant to behold, it just felt way too flashy and didn’t have any substance to it. There are a few more complaints about gameplay, but nothing worth bickering about; simplistic upgrade system, all combos from first game immediately unlocked, lightsaber duelling revolved around blocking the moment your enemy strikes and then attacking over and over again. In conclusion, it’s fun but too flashy for my liking and not as in depth as the first game. So, should you buy this game? Buy it if you really do not give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about the story. The gameplay is fun, enemies are samey but there's a lot of different varieties, there's not many levels and it takes about 4 hours to complete, but the gameplay alone is rather fast passed and fun. But if you cared about the original game's story, just forget this exists. They've recently announced that none of the Star Wars games are canon; however that doesn't mean that you can't have certain SW stories as head canon. So in my eyes, the first game is head canon, and the second game is just a neat little idea of what may have happened if Starkiller continued his journey after the first game, but it's not what truly happens after Starkiller's first game.

												I played through the game for about a week, and from what I picked up online is that many people whipped through this game in about 8-9 hours. It was a great experience but here's the pro's and con's.PROS- Sorta Kinda Maybe Possibly good graphics- Wide variety of customization options- Cool Combo's- Stormtroopers' aim still sucks- Darth Vader Fight is Cool- Force abilities are awesome- Plenty of easter eggs, secrets, and references- Decapitation is a thing.CONS- Darth Vader fight is about half hour to an hour.- PROXY is used in a dumb way- Juno needed more screen time.- General Kota's dialogue is a little bland - Han Solo and Chewie dies.- Doesn't really have a satisfying dark side ending-  Starkiller doesn't show up- The Sith Acolytes are a little too easy to kill.CONCLUSION: This is a good game if your willing to waste a couple of hours-days to playing it. It gets fun when you unlock so many force abilities that you just feel like a domination machine. Overall, I'd recommend this game for star wars fan's and SWTFU fans willing to drop 20 bucks. If your not the big of a star wars fan, I wouldn't buy it. But either way, if your looking for a good fun game with OP force abilities, this is for you.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												Had a lot of potential but needs some redesign and many more months of development to make it substantial enough. This was clearly no love project and just a hustle with valuable IP. Plays more like a tech demo than a full game.Good:- Force mechanics are much better than the first Force Unleashed- Graphics are much better than the first Force Unleashed (still not great)- Camera is much better than the first Force Unleashed (still not great)- There is a reliable tool to patch the game and disable the annoying intro- Also a good tool to unlock the fps limitBad:- Cannot disable Quick Time Events- Combat system is lackluster and mostly consists of button mashing - blocking and countering play little relevance- Surprisingly glitchy and crashy - expected a little less of that - crashed more times than I can count and a lot more than Force Unleashed 1- Camera still pretty bad- Pathing/Platforming is unenjoyable, repetitive, tedious- Cinematics are glitchy with artifacts/pixelation (with fps tweak)- Screen tearing even with v-sync- Annoying unskippable intro (without tweak tool)- Locked to 30fps yet still manages to screen tear (without tweak tool)- Crashes/freezes more frequently than one would like- Campaign is very short (finished in 7.0 hours)Bad Extra:- The boss fight when you are fighting the missile ship is impossible when playing > 30fps as for some asinine reason the missile behavior is linked to the framerate - ya - it's messed up - in a way it's an avoidance cheat (they will never hit you) but it also make it impossible to deflect missiles- This tram fight in noted above is extremely difficult unless you framerate is "just right" - 30 apparently resulted in the missiles arriving too slowly and the laser gatling gun always tore the tram apart before enough missiles could even hit the ship - ie impossible - 45-60fps makes it possible (or don't use the fps tweak tool)

												I'm a big fan of Star Wars series. I've read books, saw films and series and really doesn't get why people are so disapointed with this game. I really like it, the graphic is very good, full of details, fighting feels more like Star Wars Jedi Academy, then TFU I. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												I don't blame you FU2. I blame myself. I'm not entiely sure what I was thinking when I bought you. It was an impulse buy, I saw a sale and was like "Hey, why not?". Then i quickly came to the realization that I had just purchased a game that will be just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ without a controller. Oh boy was I correct. And you sure do love to remind me of that!I am writing this review after having just rage quit a couple of hours in. However I feel as though I have seen enough of this game in order to effectively speak about the quality of the game because most of the powers are unlocked at the beginning of the game and if the first game was anything to go off of, the combat won't take a drastic change 5 more hours in. And combat is the focus here really.Lets talk about the pros:- Despite the fact that I was playing on keyboard, the combat (for the most part) is relatively smooth and flows nicely.- Very Scenic. Beautiful level design- Collectables. Early on they just leave some out in the open to let you know they are there but those few entice you to look for the rest. They are all neat little this that are either cosmetic or change your stats somehow. Nicely done- Adequately challeging. Yes you are a walking tank and it isn't that difficult on the normal difficulty but enemies still do enough damage that you must pay attention in order to not die. That and based off of the normal difficulty, hard mode would actually be hard.Now lets talk cons:- The story is rubbish. I mean, you're playing FU2. What did you expect?- Remember when we had silent protagonists? This game made me miss those days.- While the combat flows very well, there is no personal style. The game gives a wide list of abilities to use but then forces you to use specific one to kill certain enemies (i.e. Jetpack troopers you must kill with lightning. Apparently they have developed the ability to dodge any attack ever. Lightning is the cure) and this is a huge detriment to personal style. Yes you can upgrade anything you want but it means nothing because you are always going to need every ability for at least one scenario. This make combat tedious very quickly- checkpoints- The AI is bad. Normally this is a complaint about coperative AI but not today. I spent a solid 5 min trying to go up an elevator before giving up to look for collectables only to find that the game had spawned two enemies on two corners of the map and they didnt want to attack me so i inevitably couldnt progress.- This isn't a huge deal but whenever I would change my lightsaber I would click "back" on the screen and it would tab me out of the game. Easy fix was just to use the escape key to go back. Kind of nit-picky but just something that should have been taken care of is all.All in all it isn't a terrible game. Actually, i will probably finish it over time. However I am torn as far as my recomendation for this game. Despite all the flaws it has the potential for a lot of fun. Yet, I will not recommend this. Only because it displays nothing note worthy that hasn't been seen before in better games. If you've got money to blow then go ahead and get this game. But if you are on a budget, honestly, you could do better.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												This game..... This game. Where shall I begin? Let's start with the story!..... It's Awful. Some how they made it worse than the first game. I'll refrain from spoilers but it really wouldn't matter since it'll take you the same amount of time to read this review as it will to complete the game. It's no longer than a 6 hour game with about 3-4 hours of that being gameplay the rest devoted to cutscenes and quicktime events. (I wouldn't care about the cutscenes if there was an actual good story to go along with them) The gameplay is basically the same as the first game. The only real improvements are mind trick and force rage. Mind trick allows you to turn enemies onto your side for a short period of time. (Or, if there's no else to kill, they'll commit suicide by jumping off a ledge or leaping into a sheild) Force Rage allows you to become the insane, saber-weilding, limb-chopping, force-throwing, Jedi you deserve to be!..... For a short period of time. But other than that it's just a copy and paste of the first games mechanics. One thing I actually really liked were the better boss battles. The first game simply had you fighting other Jedi or the occasional rancor. This game has you battling giant arachnid-like robots, Giant ships shooting at you whilst going at breakneck speeds on a tram, and my personal favorite. Skydiving after a 50ft tall, 4 limbed monster called the Gorog. Which brings up another thing I moderately enjoyed. Skydiving segments!..... To bad those only happen three times in the game. It's just you falling through the sky dodging objects and force pushing tie fighters out of your way. It may not sound like to much but I actually really enjoyed those moments. All-in-all this game isn't the worst game ever. It has it's moments that make you forget that you only have 3 more hours left in a game you just started. I'm giving it a down grade based primarily on these three facts1: The price. (Do NOT I repeat NOT buy this game at full price. Only buy it when it's on sale and if you liked the first game) 2: The amount of content ( Like I said about 4 hours worth)3: The first one is MUCH Better. I would strongly suggest to go and buy the first one, play it, like it (Or not) and buy this one when it's on sale for 6 bucks...... Actually, 6 bucks might be a bit to high.

I couldn't, in good consciousness, recommend this game to anyone.

												Overall, the gameplay is significantly better than the first one. No more clunky animations, or continuously being hit with no way of stopping it. content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												I knew the game was bad, but it exceeded my expectations.The port quality is as bad if not worse as the first game (which was already about as low as you can go), but even ignoring that, the game feels unfished in general.  There's an egregious amount of copy/paste level design with only 3 unique environments in total, and even then the game finds ways to have you backtrack though the same level on occasion.  On top of this there's a general lack of polish. Glitchy animations, ugly UI design, poor sound balance, an incredibly poorly executed and ill advised boss fight in the middle of the game, the list goes on.The game feels like it was hastily cobbled together in 10 months, not 2 years. I knew all of this going in and hoped to be surprised by setting my expectations very low, but nope, it's just bad.  I'll finish it (I'm less than hour from the end anyway - Steam playtime is not accurate because I was offline for a bit), but out the traditional single player storyline games I've completed in the last 5 years, this is easily the worst.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Even though I got this game on sale for 7 bucks, Its something I greatly regret. This game is one of the worst coded pieces of junk I have ever played. Its a horrible console port. Just getting it to run at all is a huge task. After 30 minutes of researching work arounds on the net, and finally tweaking my system enough to allow the game to even start without crashing, im then met with just absurd amounts of screen tearing (even with vsync), video stutter, flickering 3d objects and textures, and random hitching and slow down. Not to mention, the game is capped at 30 FPS, and the only unlocker hack is being distributed by people who package it with trojans.What a junk game. Do yourself a favor and find this game on the PS3 if you really want to play it. Lucas Arts deserved to go away if this is the quality of product they were putting out. Lucas should go and slap each and every one of the developers involved in this port.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												The core gameplay of TFU remains intact and works well (mowing down waves of Stormtroopers, and blowing things up using the Force in fun ways) and the Galactic Civil War is always a fun Star Wars era to play around in. However the tech glitches that plague the game really bring the experience down. Playing the game longer than an hour seems cause the techincal problems, so quitting out of the game every now and then seems to mitigate the glitches. Also if you hate quick time events (QTEs), then this game may not be for you as many enemies and bosses can only be defeated using QTEs. I used a mouse and keyboard setup to play, and many of the QTEs felt needlessly hard to pull off at first requiring frustrating rinse and repeat memorization. Recommended for Star Wars fans looking to wrap up Starkiller's story, but others may want to play the first TFU to see if the series is for them or simply move on.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												This was a severely disappointing game.It started off so good, which made it all the worse.  You start and instantly realize that the gameplay has gotten an improvement and that you feel just as powerful as your end-game Starkiller from TFU1.  Unfortunately, this is the only good part of the game- and you soon realize that it's terrible that you start so powerful.  You never get any stronger, or you never feel like you do.  This game lasted 4 hours at the VERY most and included a whopping 3 separate locations.  No, I refuse to count Dagobah as a location because you walk around for 45 seconds (I swear to God, I'm not even being sarcastic this time) and then watch a boring cutscene.  Then you leave.  The trailers promised a more personal, darker, grittier story line, but in reality it's a few hours of Starkiller running around murdering storm troopers and whining while Kota nags at him over the communicator.  Oh, and the pathetic 3.5-4 hours this game wastes includes an approximately 45 minute long boss fight.  It's not even difficult.  Literally the hardest part of this game was not slitting my own wrists while jacking off Darth Vader and watching his health bar move down slower than a dead snail in frozen molasses for the better part of an hourYeah, I know I'm being harsh. And of course it's always gonna be great fun to throw storm troopers out of the skybox over and over. But this game feels more rushed than deciding to finish wanking when you're already late for class.  And it's even more of a disappointment when compared to its predecessor.Oh, also on the second boss battle, the boss didn't load.  No, I don't mean the level loaded funky- the boss itself didn't show up in the level.  So congrats on another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC port, Aspyr.  Good to know you're always looking out for a third your consumers.

content:
Posted: March 25
												This game is a mess.  If you alt-tab, it crashes.  Gameplay is often frustrating, with many enemies that are immune to most of your powers and certain combinations of enemies that make each one incredibly annoying.  For example, you have to fight many enemies that are immune both to regular force attacks and lightsaber attacks.  You need to use a timed block or lightning-charged saber attack to break their guard.  Combine these guys with giant flamethrower droids that are immune to all kinds of stuns and barely take a dent from any attack you can throw at them, and you're just going to get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off rather than enjoy the difficulty of the game.  Finishing move QTEs are repetitive and unimpressive (especially compared to the ones in FU1),, and the button prompts often don't match the force powers and saber attacks that Starkiller is using.  Boss battles are frustrating and far too stage-based.  First block its attacks.  Next, grab and return its attacks.  Next, attack the boss directly for a very short vulnarability window.The fighting is also pretty bad, with no way to toggle locking on targets (you have to hold the button) no way to grab other things to throw at the targets while locked, no way to switch what target you're locked to without unlocked and attempting to highlight the correct target, etc.  FU1 had good, fluid, branching combos (though you did have to unlock them).  FU2 has very strict combos that are simple, unimpressive, and dissatisfying.  Your endlag on many moves is so long that you can't properly follow up on things that should be combo starters or links.  For example, in FU1, you could start attacking an enemy on the ground, continue with a force push up into the air, jump up after the enemy, hit him some more with your saber, and finally send him to the ground with your choice of push, lightning, or lightsaber.  In FU2, you can try to do that same combo, but it just doesn't work properly in many cases.  Also, all enemies are either immune to that combo or get killed 2-3 hits in, before you even go into the air.The campaign is short and nothing special.  Many sequences simply don't make much sense, as if there were cutscenes that got left out.  For example, at one point you finish a gameplay sequence in a hangar and see a giant droid in the background.  You go after the droid, and suddenly you're in some sort of reactor room for the fight, with no explanation of why the droid is so dangerous that you have to take it out.If you want to play the Force Unleashed II, get it on Wii.  The massive changes made by the devs of the Wii version make the game as a whole much more enjoyable.  They added a lot of gameplay mechanics and revised a lot of others, and the improvement is dramatic.  I do recommend the Wii version, but I can't recommend this one.To add insult to all this injury, the game is locked at 30FPS with bad motion blur.  The graphics good and bad in turns.  In some parts, the graphics look great and top-tier.  In others, you may as well be playing the game on the Wii, as the graphics there would be just as good.The menu system is poor (you can't even navigate it completely with a controller), the intro logos and such can't be skipped, load times are long... It's a bad PC version of a mediocre-at-best game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												What a pile of disappointment!The first game, abiet not perfect, hit the correct spots a hack-and-slash Star Wars game should've delivered. It had memorable locations, AMAZING, yes amazing bosses, and a slew of other goodies. The ending was also awesome, no matter which side you picked.This one though...It seems most of the funding for this game went into cinematics. Seriously the cinematics are gorgeous, but the gameplay? Pathetic. Right off the bat I felt overpowered. I get it, I'm a Jedi with a lightsaber and Stormtroopers and no match for me, but seriously? The first game did it right, how could the sequel mess it up? Here's a tip: Just use the grapple move. I swear the last 40 minutes of this game was just me grappling enemies until I faced the final boss. Force repulse? Meh. Force throw? Meh. Lightnight? Meh. Its like the devs said "Screw all those awesome powers, make grapple the most overpowered move!" The locations in this game were forgettable. Seriously Its like Kamino-->Nightclub-->Dagobah (More on that later) -->Some spaceship--> Kamino....As if everything wasn't bad in terms of locations, the biggest sin came from the fact that they let you play in Dagobah...made you come across Yoda....and then you just LEAVE the planet. What the hell? Poor Galen Marek, came face to face with an 800 year old Jedi master who saw the rise of the Empire....and mistook him for a "gatekeeper" of a lame old cave?? Give me a break. Completely made Yoda useless. Oh and wanna know who else they screwed over? Boba Fett! I thought it was gonna be a cool bounty-hunter sabotage plotline where Vader sends Boba to face off against Galen but heh....Boba is maybe in 1 cutscene and thats probably the last you see of him onscreen. What. A. Letdown.Oh and quicktime events GALORE!! Holy handbaskets. This game is a QTE fest, seriously. All those combos? Nah they're useless, just mash ur buttons until a QTE pops up. rinse and repeat. Honestly, there is just ONE boss in this game, and unless you've been living under a rock *SPOILERS* Its Darth F'ing Vader. Whaaaaa??? You might be thinking why I punished myself playing through this game. Does it have any redeeming qualities, it is REALLY that bad? Well my friend, I'm a Star Wars fan, and I really wanted to see if there WAS a redeeming quality, in the end..there wasn't. You KNOW you messed something up when I'm telling myself "Oh God when will this level be over with" in a Star Wars game. I've played them all folks, even those old 90s ones which had pixelated graphics, but you know what? They were challenging, they were fun. This? After 15 minutes it'll bore you. Stick to the first game, it is a complete package and I see no need why they had to release a crappy sequel like this. If you REALLY wanna play it though, pick it up on Sale atleast, this game doesn't deserve the $20-something pricetag it demands. As a Star Wars game 4/10As a Hack-N-Slash 6/10 but beware of QTEs and lackluster mechanics of combat.Phew.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												Short version:  8 out of 10 if you're a fan, 7 out of 10 if you're not, and maybe 6 out of 10 if you don't like action games.Why? [SPOILERS AHEAD]First of all, it's STAR WARS, so that has that going for it.  Even with the whole "Legends"/"Canon" thing, the story is enjoyable and engaging.  The final sequence before facing Vader in the end is incredibly well done:- cramped camera (normally a bad thing, but here it really highlights the stress and pressure that Starkiller feels, an outstanding cinematic technique)- the lighting (stark, clinical white in places, but it still manages to look dark and insidious; the blood-red lights at each of the abberant clone-tanks really accent the sinister operations there)- the Force energy (Starkiller's surroundings crumple and disintegrate, which provides a VERY visual metaphor at how he's struggling to keep from losing his mind.)While you need to have played the first one to really understand all the nuances of this game, the cinematics and dialogue fill in the blanks enough for brand new players to grasp the events and goings-on.The ability to customize not one but TWO lightsabers not only provides gameplay bonuses but can also serve as roleplaying tools if you so desire.  You start with red crystals but can find others as you play...RED: no bonusBLUE: lightsaber strikes replenish Force meterGREEN: more health pickups from defeated enemiesYELLOW: lightsaber strikes deal additonal lightning damageCHARTREUSE: lightsaber attacks deal additonal corrosive damageORANGE: lightsaber strikes deal additional fire damagePURPLE: take less damage from attacksPINK: Force Fury meter recharges faster from attackingLIGHT BLUE: Force powers use less energyLIGHT GREEN: health regenerates fasterLIGHT ORANGE: more experience points for collateral/environmental damageBLACK: lightsaber attacks have a chance to disintegrate enemiesWHITE: more experience points for defeating enemies(I may have missed one or two, there's a lot of them)Force powers make a comeback, and are more streamlined.  Plus a new one, MIND-TRICK, where you can make enemies flee the battle (often by jumping of a ledge to their demise) or even fight for you.The voice acting is well done.  You hear the unbridled power when Starkiller taps into Force Fury and the despair when Vader outmaneuvers him.  Rahm Kota speaks with authority on the starship Salvation and speaks out of weariness when he knows that Starkiller is the only one who can turn the tide.~~~~~The reason for the multiple scores is relatively simple.  Most people know that the game was rushed due to the Lucasfilm/Disney merger; and with this game being the second in a trilogy, the fact that the trilogy has been shelved indefinitely... that can put a downer on somebody.If you are a STAR WARS fan who enjoyed the films, the TV shows, and what else, then you'll enjoy this game.Put it on your wishlist, watch for a sale if you're worried, there's a decent amount of replayability and the difficulty can be whatever you make of it.If you want something that you can just button-mash through, then play on easy.  You'll still be able to enjoy the story.If you want to feel like every battle is like when Luke faces Vader in the second Death Star, then play on the hardest difficulty setting.Unfortunately, and as much as it pains me to say it... if you're not a fan of action games or combo systems you may not have as much fun with this.  If you're not a STAR WARS fan, then why are you even reading this?It's not a BAD game by any means, but as I said before, it's clear that there was more to be had but real-life events forced their hand.~~~~~SYNOPSIS:  At once engaging, enthralling, and haunting; the continuation of Starkiller's journey is made even more poignant by the fact that it is *not* canon.  You see the formation of a Rebellion that now never was against the machinations of an Empire that now never were.It's a bit like the work of an artist.  Once they're gone what they've made is now priceless.Even though Starkiller is no longer "real", his struggle is, and that's the soul of this game.

content:
Posted: March 25
												This game is a mess.  If you alt-tab, it crashes.  Gameplay is often frustrating, with many enemies that are immune to most of your powers and certain combinations of enemies that make each one incredibly annoying.  For example, you have to fight many enemies that are immune both to regular force attacks and lightsaber attacks.  You need to use a timed block or lightning-charged saber attack to break their guard.  Combine these guys with giant flamethrower droids that are immune to all kinds of stuns and barely take a dent from any attack you can throw at them, and you're just going to get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off rather than enjoy the difficulty of the game.  Finishing move QTEs are repetitive and unimpressive (especially compared to the ones in FU1),, and the button prompts often don't match the force powers and saber attacks that Starkiller is using.  Boss battles are frustrating and far too stage-based.  First block its attacks.  Next, grab and return its attacks.  Next, attack the boss directly for a very short vulnarability window.The fighting is also pretty bad, with no way to toggle locking on targets (you have to hold the button) no way to grab other things to throw at the targets while locked, no way to switch what target you're locked to without unlocked and attempting to highlight the correct target, etc.  FU1 had good, fluid, branching combos (though you did have to unlock them).  FU2 has very strict combos that are simple, unimpressive, and dissatisfying.  Your endlag on many moves is so long that you can't properly follow up on things that should be combo starters or links.  For example, in FU1, you could start attacking an enemy on the ground, continue with a force push up into the air, jump up after the enemy, hit him some more with your saber, and finally send him to the ground with your choice of push, lightning, or lightsaber.  In FU2, you can try to do that same combo, but it just doesn't work properly in many cases.  Also, all enemies are either immune to that combo or get killed 2-3 hits in, before you even go into the air.The campaign is short and nothing special.  Many sequences simply don't make much sense, as if there were cutscenes that got left out.  For example, at one point you finish a gameplay sequence in a hangar and see a giant droid in the background.  You go after the droid, and suddenly you're in some sort of reactor room for the fight, with no explanation of why the droid is so dangerous that you have to take it out.If you want to play the Force Unleashed II, get it on Wii.  The massive changes made by the devs of the Wii version make the game as a whole much more enjoyable.  They added a lot of gameplay mechanics and revised a lot of others, and the improvement is dramatic.  I do recommend the Wii version, but I can't recommend this one.To add insult to all this injury, the game is locked at 30FPS with bad motion blur.  The graphics good and bad in turns.  In some parts, the graphics look great and top-tier.  In others, you may as well be playing the game on the Wii, as the graphics there would be just as good.The menu system is poor (you can't even navigate it completely with a controller), the intro logos and such can't be skipped, load times are long... It's a bad PC version of a mediocre-at-best game.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												How I feel about "The Force Unleashed II"? Well...it's more of a "meh" situation. It retains the core concept of being overpowered with the force and now you can wield two lightsabers! Sounds fun and it is fun. On the graphics side of things it has improved quite alot - facial animations and character movement have been made to feel more natural. On the gameplay side it is all there - quick and fast button combinations result in making a badass jedi/sith action that makes your jaw drop. But that is pretty much it. The story is ridiculously convoluted - the whole prequel cloning idea brought in the original trilogy mythos. The story feels unfinished and sometimes forced (no pun intended). Grind your way towards becoming overpowered and while advancing the "plot" of the story, face a God Of War style boss battle. Press the right button prompts and you are done. The techinical and mechanical aspects of the game have been improved, but there is no narrative to drive the player to finishing the game. In the end I would only recommend the game if you could get it on sale, otherwise buy the original with tons of more content and better story.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												The torrented version I had years ago didn't crash. This is the CTD version I guess.TLDR; Get it in sale if you are a completionist, otherwise, don't buy it at all.My honest pro's and con's list.Pros:- I got it for real cheap in the star wars pack here on steam.- Dude Starkiller found another lightsaber (they had to improve SOMETHING right?)- Menu plus its navigation improved somewhat compared to force unleased 1Cons:- Gameplay is shorter than Force unleased I- Cutscenes are most of the times bugged, so you miss crucial information- Texture glitches, like walking through the air, though you are actually on a platform- Darth Vader was VERY easy to beat since pretty much the only thing that really works is spamming lightsaber attacks in combination with force lighting- Overall combat is very easy because each unit has at least one major weakness (which is mostly your sabers)- If you switch focus after launching the game but before it really starts, you cannot alt-tab or play the game. It just keeps focussing, leaving you about 250 milliseconds to search for the program in the taskbar after pressing CTRL+ALT+DEL- 20% off my gameplay time was due to CTD's and having to do area's again and again- Sometimes Repulse or lightsaber throw may leave the game hanging, alt-tab out and back fixes it- Story was really short- Story was really really really weak, you can see it as the final scene after the clifhanger (which is basically force unleased 1)- Only three levels really. Kamino, some dusty planet, space ship and... Kamino again? WTF? - Starkiller is suddenly an even more whiny kid than in part 1 (perhaps a side effect of the cloning process)- non skippable lucas arts intro, which is getting more and more annoying after each CTD

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												I somewhat enjoyed the first game, but this sequel was a mess. The endings don't make sense and the story was overall un-interesting. The enemies were boring and all the cutscene finish moves were exactly the same. One of the things that made the original game decent is the lighsaber duels with jedi and sith, as well as the variety of ways to kill an enemy. This game lacked all of that. There was virtually no content to the game; roughly 6 hours of play-time to finish and every level looked the same. On some planets, I could turn a corner and be in a room that looks exactly like the last room. What was crippling is that there wasn't really anything new after the first game. This felt like the graphics were freshened up a bit and a story was added as an afterthought to get people to buy this as a new game. This game did exactly one thing that I really liked, and that was a boss battle that happened pretty early in the game. I found that fight to be a fight worthy of the Star Wars franchise, and it is probably the only part of the game that sticks out in my mind. However, the story material for that boss battle is extremely borrowed and I have seen those same concepts in other video games and movies, which is only part of what limits that single fight from salvaging this game. Overall, I don't play a lot of video games, and I especially don't play a lot of bad video games, so take that into account when I say that this is one of the worst games I've ever played.

												Get the first game its far better than this one. The force unleashed II is a super dumbed down version of the first one. content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												This is a short game & i would be angry paying full price when it 1st came out.This 2nd edition feels the same all through out when it comes to locations & looks uninspired.The graphics level does look higher then sith edition but doesn't give you different looking worlds like sith ed does.Using the Default 30fps isn't bad other then the obvious frame tearing, otherwise it's fine for game play.I did try out the 60fps unlocker 1/2 way through the game & it clearly is more crisp so i advise any1 playing this to use it.Completing "tasks" are also Vague in this game, it's NOT clear always what to do but you have a "guide thingy" on D pad that shows you were to go next.Tutorials in TFU2 aren't as good as the sith ed, i found it more difficult & haven't completed them.Most games "usually" allow you to go back & explore further BUT with these 2 TFU games you are subjected to replay the entire level.For some ppl this maybe "OK" but for ppl like me i would rather do as MUCH as possible on my 1st run & then complete it on my next try. Games that allow you to venture unobstructed all throughout have been around for ages & so i think the dev's just cheaped it out so you replay it more often then needed.This game does not have much replay value because levels look too similar & it gets boring.This game is also more simplified then sith edition so you may or may not like whats been done here.Also i think the game play is smoother in this 2nd version. I score this game less then TFU sith ed cause there is less content & the locations all look the same.I score it about a 7/10 which is fair but if they had more varied/distinct locations it would score higher.

number of helpful: 39 of 80 people (49%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												In a few ways, TFU2 is a better game than it's predecessor - it has smoother gameplay, much better visuals, and a MUCH smoother menu system. It's also not quite as buggy as the first game, and despite having a horrendous release in 2010, it has been tightened up enough to seem quite polished in some ways. However, whilst the first game's weaknesses are this game's strengths, the strengths of the first are the weaknesses of this one. Most importantly, the story is at best lazy and at worst insulting. Instead of attempting the further the overall Star Wars narrative as the first game did, TFU2's story is a blatantly lazy attempt at reusing the established protagonist, in effect retconning the ending of the first game under a ridiculous premise, and nonsensically undoing all the traits of the character that made him such a joy to watch in the first place. So, much like the prequel trilogy, TFU2 retroactively downgrades the story arc of a great character and subsequently devalues the first game by convincing us that the character isn't as great as we thought. And before anyone decides to throw the 'clone' nonsense out there - regardless of the cheap trick the writers have used, it's the same character.And I suppose some could say 'what does it matter' now that the games' stories are no longer considered canon, but to that I say that despite all the flaws of TFU, its story was compelling enough to make it greater than the sum of its parts, whereas I found myself repeatedly failing to find the motivation to complete TFU2. This, coupled with the fact that the QTE's require so little effort or skill it's a wonder that they were implimented at all, and the repetition of certain gameplay elements, makes TFU2 definitively a worse overall experience, and a real disappointment if you, like me, were expecting innovation and expansion upon a title that had great potential. TFU2 is fun, in ways. But it's not a deep game, and it's rarely a stimulating experience. It's one of those sequels in which it's immediately obvious that the company was cashing in on the financial success of a previous successful titles. It doesn't need to exist, and it brings few improvements of great worth to the table. If you just can't get enough of TFU, and are looking for more sword-swinging, force-slinging action, then TFU2 has that in spades. But beyond the graphical improvements and various intuitive tweaks to the gameplay, there's not a lot here to recommend spending your hard-earned cash on.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												Oh boy where do I start with this? First I really like Star Wars though beside the videogames and a few books about Obi wan prior to the Phantom Menace I never really got into the whole Expanded universe. I picked up Force Unleashed somewhere in a Humble Bundle and played it through it in one sitting. Though it failed to deliver in whats the most important thing for me, the lightsaber battles (Jedi Knight; Jedi Academy still has the best actual lightsaber battles in my opinion) it managed to have some great moments just living on this premise that your character is "overpowered" in terms of his Forcepowers. (Still considering pulling out the Stardestroyer out of orbit one of my favourite Star Wars videogame moments)And then Force Unleashed 2 comes along. A horrible short 4-5 hours QTE ridden snorefest with no real story, no excitement and no real reason to exist other than to potentially cash in on the main character, the license or whatever. 5 hours on hard I must add. I guess you could easily breeze through this in 3 or less hours on easy, leaving you with no real further value beside some challenges. I wasn't even able to finish it because apperantly a GTX 750 is below the minimum requirement since today (could play without any problems yesterday). The cutscenes were also stuttering for whatever reason and the game is hardcapped to 30 frames per second.Don't waste your money on this turd. Either torrent it or wait for another HumbleBundle etc. The Devs don't deserve any revenue for this EFFFFF piece of software

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												I am a huge star wars fan and I loved the first Force Unleashed.PROS-The game has some of the most beautiful weather cycles and graphics shading I have ever seen.-The fighting animations are awesome and the new lightsabre physics (cutting arms of stormtroopers) make a nice new addition.-The stormtroopers are so weak... but it's fun to muck around with them.BADS-Similarly to most reviews, I have to say the campaign game time is horrendous. I have finished the game 2 times, and my steam time says 6 hours. -The gameplay is incredibly repetitive (like the first one), however, since the story is nowhere near as engaging as the first one, the gameplay is even worse as you feel there is no inscentive to see the outcome of the level.-As I said, the story is completely irrelevant to the star wars universe. As a true-fan, no matter what I love every star wars game (especially Jedi Knight series), but this one didn't do it for me.-There is no variation in enemies... ever!Overall 5/10. Not recommended unless you can pick this game up for under 10 bucks.This is a game where the graphics are incredible, but the story and gameplay drown beneath it.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												As a big Star Wars fan and after being impressed with the first installment of this game I decided to move on to the sequel. I was impressed with the beginning of this game. What seemed like a solid story, fluid gameplay and beutiful graphics, I thought I was looking forward to a good game. But in the end I was disappointed.I have completed this game in 3 hours, which for its price is ridiculous (I bought this as part of the star wars collection). It was so short. It may as well have been DLC for the first game. Even then you would expect a strong story, which it also failed to deliver. We were left with a repeat of the end of Episode 3 movie. Turns to dark side to save the women he loves but she still dies. Or the other ending where evrything is O.K. but considering what happens in the dark side endig does'nt make an appearence in the light side ending makes no sense.This game has litrally about 4 levels (5 if you include the fill in the dots mission on Dagobah). The levle themselves never offered much. "Do this force power to pass through this part. Now just to make sure you know it do it again." Then you will never do this again throughout the game.So with all this, you would expect the game to at least give us a strong ending. But sadly no. We are left with a sub par boss fight with Darth Vader with very repetitive sections that just ruin the emotion of the fight.So overll, I would not recommend buying this game at full price. Maybe if it were on sale and you are an adamnet star wars fan you may enjoy it. Some of the gameplay mechanics are amzing and very fun to play with. But at the end I was left with a sour tate in my mouth that has led me to not reccomend this game.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												If you’re looking for a great game, please stop here. This game isn’t great, it’s not even good. Mediocre would describe it best. Star Wars the Force Unleashed 2 is rather bland. Here is a breakdown of the game:•	Graphics: The game looks nice. Nice crisp visuals help make the game look good.  The rain on Kamino looks amazing, and the destructible environments make the visuals pretty. 7/10•	Framrate: Playing on PC is not recommended as the game isn’t optimized well. You’ll run into problems similar to the predecessor. Low framerate. The game tries, but ultimately fails to stay at 30FPS, with frequent drops to as low as 11FPS. As I was playing on the PC, not being able to make the game run at 60FPS, as I do most other games, with the constant drops make this a painful sore on my eyes. 2/10•	Gameplay: This is much like driving your first car. It feels amazing at first. You feel like you have all the power in the universe, but then you take a second to realize how boring driving really is. The game tries to throw a few curves your way, but by now you know how your car runs, and these curves really do nothing but slow you down a little. You fight the same enemies over and over again, with the only variation being the combination of the enemies. You can take everything down with your lightsaber. Very little thought is needed to mow down the enemies. You can spice it up using some combinations, but the X-X-X-X combination is really all you need. A few enemies are hard to hit, and you just have to throw a little lightning at them, but that’s all you need to do. The bosses are not much better. All you have to do is learn a simple pattern, and lather, rinse, repeat. They don’t change how they’re acting, and the get predictable really fast. 4/10•	Level design: The levels don’t really resonate well. They are long, and filled with the same waves of enemies over and over again. The platforming bits mix it up a little bit, and in my opinion, the best levels are the ones where you are falling. You have to dodge out of the way of incoming objects, or you can blast them aside with a force push. But that’s it. Platforming becomes a chore in this game, and sometimes it’s just rather frustrating. 3/10•	Story: The story jumps around, and all you ever seem to do is teleport to wherever the plot says you have to go with nothing really tying it all together. The jump between level one and two is rather Jarring. You escape from the cloning facility on Kamino when Vader is about to kill you, and then all of sudden you are trying to track down your old master from the last game. No explanation. The romantic side of the story is lacking, and feels half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 2/10•	Length: The game is short. Painfully so. You can beat this game in a matter of hours with no difficulty. You will get to the final level and feel like the game is half over at best. You can beat this game in about 4 hours, if you include the cutscenes. If you ignore the cutscenes, it ranges between 2 and 3 hours at most. The most replayability you get is from playing with a different costume, such as a Storm trooper or Boba Fett. 3/10All in all, this game feels like it shouldn’t exist. It adds nothing new to the lore, which as of this writing is non canon, but regardless. The game is short, doesn’t feel great, the story is lacking, but it looks nice. Don’t play this game, it will leave you with an empty feeling inside. Nothing is really of note. If you really want to play this game, then I suggest you get it heavily marked down, or like I did and get it in a bundle where you only paid a few dollars for. My final scoring of the game is a 3.5/10.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												This is quite possibly the worst game I've played this year.The game itself contains approximately half an hour of actual gameplay; its "longevity" comes in unashamedly repeating itself over, and over, and over, and over again. This is the pinnacle of minimalistic game development, where so atrociously little effort has gone into creating anything with an ounce of creativity -- just copy-pasted sequences mixed in with painful quicktime events followed by more copy-paste.Just to give you an idea of what I mean by mind-numbing repititon, this is how the "final, epic battle" with Darth Vader actually played out.You begin by battling him on a platform, your only recourse is spamming lightsaber attacks as he auto-deflects force powers.Once you eventually hurt him enough, a quicktime event will occur. Upon successful completion, Vader will jump to another platform, summoning some mini-clones of you, 10 or so in total, for you to fight. When you're done, you jump to his new platform.And then you repeat, lightsaber-attacking him until he takes enough damage to trigger the quicktime event, which is identical to the previous. When you finish, Vader jumps to another platform, and again, 10 mini-clones appear for you to fight. When you're done, you jump to Vader's platform.And again you "battle" him until taking enough of his health to trigger *the exact same quicktime event*. Upon completion, as before, he jumps to a different platform, and 10 mini-clones appear for you to fight.This went on and on and on 4 times before I finally gave up, as I felt my soul being drained, physically, from my body. Whatever mindless, empty husk of a person created this game has my infinite pity; I can only imagine what kind of horrible life they must lead, being so absolutely bereft of depth and creativity.I will not play this game again, and I heartily recommend anyone with a shred of self-respect steer very, very clear.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												A fun game with many technical problems that unfortunately makes it unplayable in my opinion. Had I bought this at the full price of 19.99 euros I would have been more dissapointed, but I didn't expect much as I launched it as the first game also had problems similar to this one.  (recieved this as part of the autumn star wars bundle) Having originally played this at release on the 360, I was cautiously looking forward to playing this at a higher resolution and framerate. After cranking up the graphics and setting the resolution I launched the game, being greeted by a, what seemed like black screen with the classic Star Wars music playing extremely choppily. Fraps reported 2000+fps in the cutscene, but the screen was black. After a few seconds, the classic Star Wars text intro played, equally choppy. It went from being 2 fps to a freeze frame before jumping to another freeze frame. Deciding to save myself a headache, I skipped the intro, being greeted by another slap in the face. The game is locked to 30fps. After playing for a couple of minutes, another cutscene played, as broken as the intro. It played fine for the first few seconds before the audio imploded and the screen froze again. After waiting a couple of seconds, it put me back in the game, this time at 5-10 fps which lasted for about 20 seconds before struggling its way back to 30. After it reached 30, it was as steady as a rock though, which is a plus I guess.After playing through the first level and skipping yet broken cutscene I looked online for solutions to my problems. I downloaded a 60fps exe from the pc gaming wiki (awesome site, check it out) and it played fine until the next cutscene, which instantly crashed my game. After that, the game refused to start, so I removed the modified .exe and repaired my game, switching my resolution temporarily to 1680x1050 just to get the game to start again. Switching back to my normal resolution and getting to the same spot as before instantly crashed the game. I gave up at this point. I'm not going to play a game on the pc at unsteady 30 fps without functioning cutscenes and intermittent crashes. I don't enjoy playing a ticking time bomb, where every second the game might crash.It's a shame because this game would be a blast to play at 60+ fps @1080+ resolutions. The gameplay is a faster, more fluid and fun version of the first and it really makes you feel powerful.Save yourself a headache and don't get this game if you can't live with the aforementioned problems. The cutscenes give the levels context and without them you're just running around killing stuff, which is fine for some people, but not for me as a Star Wars fan and someone who cares about the story, no matter how bare bones.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												Force Unleashed series to me is the second worst thing to happen to the star wars franchise since Jar Jar binks. It's not loyal to the lore any way, and infact tries to make the star wars lore adhere to its poorly written story. That aside, the game play is pretty boring. I find it reminiscent to a play station 1 platformer, with sort of flashier graphics. If you're a brain dead drooling zombie that gets a woody from seeing flashing lights, then yea I suppose this game is for you. That or you can spent $5 bucks paying someone to jingle a shiny set of keys infront of you. For what ever reason, you're a god in the game, not a jedi, not a sith...you're unstoppable. There is no challenge, it's just you versus things that want to die. The only challenge I had, and the only time I began to die was fighting the last boss. It turned into this sort of platform jumping fight, but it was incredibly buggy, and often ran into invisible walls that forced you to die in order to create this illusion of a "epic" battle. Of course that's not to mention how generic the main character is, he's the vanilla Shepard/Assassins Creed/Cole MacGrath. tall shaved head and white character. Who knew the neo nazi look was something we could all relate to. Also it's absurdly short, took me something like 5ish hours to beat.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												The last time I played the first Force Unleashed game was some years ago, and I vividly remember it as being the Jedi/Sith power trip that Star Wars games were missing until then. It had fun and easy to use force mechanics, the best I'd seen, with a passable story and decent brawler gameplay to boot. Outside of a few frustrating segments and glitches, it was an amazing experience, which held my attention for a good 20+ hours.With that in mind, I was excited for the sequel. Unfortunately, The Force Unleashed II pales in comparison to its predecessor. Its 4-6 hour length is probably its greatest weakness, and this game certainly has weaknesses. Perhaps by itself it's not that bad of a game, although I can't help but compare it to the first game, an adventure which saw you flying around the galaxy, from jungles to lava planets to imperial ships, fighting various rancors, robots, Jedi and Sith. It was amazing! This game, however, barely innovates at all on what the previous title had to offer; the combat system remains largely unchanged, the story this time around is decidedly boring, and the enemy and location variety seem to be worse than before. Strangely enough, even the menu graphics stand out as outdated and clunky.Bottom line, play the first Force Unleashed instead. The only thing this game does better is graphics.

Has no frame rate cap, so it pushes over 4500 frames per second, yes the four thousand five hundred, which causes it to constantly crash during the opening cinematic. Followed some guides posted by other players to do things like force enable VSync via my graphics driver and force other options like Triple Buffering, but those settings cause the audio and video to skip like I'm playing from a scratched disc.I'm very thankful for STEAM's recent refund policy, but games that are this broken should be removed from the store by Valve.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												This game is worth at best 1£/hour. Seeing as it clocks in at 4 hours in a fairly avarage run, I'd say avoid it like the plague. Usability:This is also because it has numerous issues running properly on my win 7. To actually get it to start you need to change the compability settings of you .exe, an .exe which you must first download online if you actually want to play your figther game at 60fps instead of 30. Add to that the long, unskippable start up movies (which you can fix with another download).  Of course you also have some random crashes ( i counted 4) during playtime, and a few glitches while plaing. All in all it's not a very good port. Though i will say it actually does present graphical options, unlike it's predesessor.Combat:The gameplay is very much the same as one. You have you're similar attacks, lightsaber throwing, litghtning firing and normal saber combat basically. Where it changes is in the speed of combat. Your dash ability from 1 has a shorter cooldown, you wield 2 lightsabers instead of one, which basically means you hit faster, but you're comboing abilities are if anything increased. Unlike the 1st installment, you have little ability to change hit quickly, so you mostly end up doing a quick few slahes on normal enemies, and spam the normal 4 hit combo on more tough ones. There are two new installments. Those are mindtricks, the ability to turn a weak enemy to your side, and rage. Mindtricks replace the sheild from 1, but offers little useability to make up for this. Since you dispose of enemies so quickly, and the effect last such a short time, it barely sees any use. Rage on the other hand works as you would expect. you kill enemies, build up ragem, and get a damage boast for a short amount of time on use. All in all it is an allright mechanic, if a bit underused.Tha min issue with the combat lies in it's overreliance of quick time events. Any enemy stronger than your common lightsaber uer or stormtrooper is finished using the same qte, with minor variations in buttons. This means since you have the same animations and enemies throughout the game, you end up repeating it for atleast 50 times over the course of playing. Add to that the stronger focus in bossfights. where earilier the main combat was indeed swordplay and force use, with qte's being used as finishers, here almost the entirety of the bossfights are qtes.Upgrades:As in 1, you have your lightsaber upgrades. These are colloected as holocrons, which are fairly easy to find as you progress through the game. They are cosmetic and gameplay effects rolled into one, where you can pick one crystal for ech saber, having effectssuch as drain health, You also have your powerupgrades as in 1. In 2 these are instead "streamlined" or perhaphaps simplu dumbed down, into one page. Previously you could upgrade your powers, your combos and your player strenghts (hp, energy etc9 with different points earned by lvling up and completing challanges. Here you get all your points based on enemy death (as in bulletstrom). Your upgrade all your swordplay (damage, combos) in one, and the rest upgrades your indivudual forcepowers. The problem with this way is you loose the sense of progression of 1. Since you have all the useful combos from a fully upgraded jedi from 1, you dont actually receive any interesting new combos with upgrades. This leads to all upgrades essentialy being damage buffs, something which isnt very exciting for a quick, combo based combat.Aesthetics:Immidiatley you can see they put a lot of effort into making this a beautiful game. The scale of the eniroments, and graphical fidelity are much better than 1, and are enjoyable throughout the game. The only gripe i have is that they removed the enemy healthbars, making fairly difficult to know the damage required to actually bring down enemies.Story: This game picks up a year or so after 1, and it follows a supposed clone of good old Starkiller. He keeps his old memories, and becomes obsessed with finding the (very) brief love interest of 1. That's it. That's the story. You find Kota from 1, assualt the cloning facility you were created, and fight Vader. Game over. This in a game where half the time (atleast) is spent in qte's and cutscenes. Needless to say it doesn't offer enough.Conclusion: It feels like this game was horribly rushed. The potential lies to have the game stretch atleast another 4 hours, both story wise and gameplay. If nothing else they could have reused enviroments and enemies from 1, albeit graphically updated. As it is, the game ends up feeling like watching an anime, as the game grabs every possibility to wrestle control away from the player at every turn. The little combat there is isn't varied and enjoyable enough to carry the game either, mainly taking place inside corridors and buldings, inlike the vast fauna of felucia in 1 or burning buldings from the wookies homeland. In other words, dont play this game. It isn't worht the wait for the download.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Force Unleashed II fixes all the problems I had with the first game. The gameplay is far more fluid, the controls are simple and easy to remember, the force powers feel useful, there are enough enemies to keep the game interesting, and not too many to overcomplicate things. The menu, while still an obvious console port, works far better, with fast access to your force powers, and a simple menu to change the color of your lightsabers. One noticable change to the game's formula is that now you have two lightsabers instead of one. Also, you'll notice slowdowns whenever you land successive hits on enemies similar to how the God of War series works which I really like as it allows you to more easily plan your next move. Quick time events are unfortutely still very much present. All of the big enemy types that you fight throughout the game have an optional quick time finisher move that got boring to watch so fast, I tried to avoid pressing the quicktime activation button and just finished off the enemy by slashing it instead. One nice addition is the ability to use the force to see where you needed to go next. The first game had a problem with instructing the player on what they were supposed to do next. I also liked the ability to use mind tricks on weak enemies so they would do things like kill themselves or attack their allies. Now here are the problems with this game. I have never in my life played a shorter game. 4 hours. That's right... 4. There are literally only 3 levels in the game: Kamino, some Cloud City like place, and a spaceship interior. The pacing feels way off, as if I was missing the first 3 levels. After the initial tutorial level, you go to this Cloud City place and fight through room upon room of increasingly difficult waves of enemies until you reach a huge colliseum where you're faced with a gigantic boss. This boss goes on FOREVER. So long, I was afraid I was already facing the end of the game. But no, this is just some overly drawn out filler that takes up a majority of the game. I'm not sure why the developers thought it important to draw this out as it isn't necessarily a fun boss that let's you use your skills to their full potential. Another major problem is the story. It's not nearly as good as the first one. You barely interact with any of the good characters established in the first game, and your charater's motives are purely to save the damsel in distress this time which just does not feel as powerful as the motive of the first game's character. The storyline overall just feels rather uninspired and doesn't seem to add anything to the overall arch of the Star Wars universe. The cool thing about the first one was that it helped to link the prequel movies and the original trilogy together. Force Unleashed II does no such thing and feels like that awkward straight to DVD movie that nobody ever watches unless they buy it by accident. The graphics look incredible, especially for a game that's already a couple years old. Very nice lighting, nice soft edges, and some smooth framerates. The cutscenes are also looking fantastic, almost movie quality. The sound is a big improvement, though the music is still a bit hit/miss. The voice acting of most characters is decent, but not nearly as good as the first game. The main character's voice acting is horrendous this time around, with really awkward pubescent screams when he gets angry that just give you that awkward embarassed feeling. I just want Darth Vader to be like "..whoa.. calm down you big baby." All-in-all, this game is a better GAME than Force Unleashed I. But Force Unleashed I has a better STORY than Force Unleashed II.
