number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
												Didn't think it would be worse than the first game, but I was wrong.The game is ridiculously short, it took me a total of 4 hours to beat the campaign, and I was not speeding through it (I find it funny that my playtime includes watching the entirety of the credits). The amount of bugs in this game is also insane, even in game cinematics have very obvious bugs. Stormtroopers heads shaking around, Darth Vader walking through the ground, etc. When you see a pre-rendered cinematic having ridiculous bugs, just turn off your pc. There is no vertical sync option and the screen is always tearing so much so that its strange when there isn't a tear. Story is pointless and tacked on, nothing that happens is important, honestly can't even think of anything to say about it, but you will get a few laughs out how awkward it can be. The gameplay isn't even as good or tight as the first (which wasn't good or tight at all), the lightsaber pausing everytime you hit an enemy for a second drove me insane.The only positive thing I can say about this game is that if you are a Star Wars fanatic like myself you will get a bit of enjoyment out of this. The music of John Williams is never disappointing, and a lightsaber always is fun.This game is nowhere near $20 value as there is story based DLC for other games that are of more quality and longer than The Force Unleashed II. I honestly feel bad for anyone that paid $60 for it. It's pretty clear that the developer signed a contract saying they needed to make a sequel and had no idea what to do. There are plenty of fantastic Star Wars games that you should spend your time with such as the Jedi Knight or Knights Of The Old Republic series. Even if you have already played those games you will enjoy playing them again for four hours more than you will enjoy beating The Force Unleashed II's campaign.Still not convinced? Okay lets try this **waves hand** you will not buy this game.Edit: Just found out that this does not include the DLC for the game, making it even less worth your time & money. :)

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												The first Force Unleashed was by no means a perfect game. On just about every count, Force Unleashed II is worse.While this game continues to let you play a god-like Jedi who tosses aside armies with a swat of his hand, that's about all it really gets right.Controls: Stiffer and less natural than before, with limited mobility on your character. You can fly through the air, but can't walk faster than a hurried trot. It's been a while since I've played the first one, but in this one my movement felt hamstrung.Enemies: Just as in the first game, enemies eventually cope with your god-like powers by being magically immune to some of them (though this is usually less annoying than it is the first time around). I wonder where Vader's armies of secret Force-immune warriors and missile-toting robots went by the beginning of A New Hope.Boss fights tend to have incredibly simple patterns, and yet drag on endlessly.Level Design: There are a few interesting set-pieces in this extremely linear game, but too often the design slows you down with endless and very dull jumping and locking mechanism "puzzles" that really do nothing but delay your progress with pointless tedium.Overall art direction is OK, with a fair amount of work put into some levels and not so much into others.Story: Anyone who played the first game knows that the Force Unleashed story is totally ridiculous but serviceable, given that they're just trying to write some kind of plot around the fun gameplay gimmick of being an ultra-powerful Jedi. Despite what a cheesy tie-in it was, it felt epic in its own way. This time around, though, the writers completely phoned it in. Nothing is explained if you haven't played the first game, and makes little sense even if you did. The plot is extremely lazy--your character doesn't even really talk for the first two levels or so, and there's a lot of pointless cameos. Yoda shows up, says two lines to the protagonist, and then disappears before either character asks the other's name.In terms of storytelling depth, it feels like a half-baked DLC add-on for the first game at best. That may be a generous assessment. The game is noticeably short, even compared to the fairly short first game.Music: About the same as before, with an OST consisting of exactly one musical sting for your character. All other music is recycled John Williams score, even if it wouldn't be terribly appropriate for the given moment in the game.Character Customization: There's still a paper-thin leveling system (your choices here don't really matter). Your lightsaber provides you different bonus stats based on the color, but the advantages from color to color are not terribly significant. There doesn't appear to be much in the way of other cosmetic options.Technical Aspects: I could forgive this game's shortcomings if it weren't for the problem that it's a classic example of a bad console port. Most of the graphics settings are completely locked--including the framerate and refresh rate--and it appears that it's impossible to change them. The options menu is clearly blown up from a lower resolution--it looks terrible on 1080. Many users report severe problems on their systems, though I didn't have any.At $6, I felt like I broke even on this purchase, and I've had a better experience than many, likely due to a computer that can handle this game's overly demanding specs easily. If I paid $50 for this, I would be enraged.Rig:Intel i5 @3.4 ghz8 GB RAMGeForce GTX 760

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												This dissapointing sequel to the original Force Unleashed once again follows Starkiller(or is it Starkiller's clone?) as he rampages across the galaxy and inadvertantly starts the rebellion that made star wars good in the first place. Through visits to a series of forgettable, repetitive locations and a boring cliched story that makes no sense you will once again slash, burn and electrocute anything that moves. Rule of thumb, if it has appeared in star wars in the last twenty years then you can kill it. A forgettable tale of revenge with the end game being a showdown with Darth Vader in which you literally beat the truth out of him. This game is shallow on content, its about five hours long, and it is oh so glitchy. Do not pay more than five dollars for this game, it is not as good as the original by any stretch of the imagination. The only good parts of this game were the voice acting and motion capture which as always were top notch, and the physics engine which lets you grab tie fighters out of the air with the force. And the ending, light or dark, won't answer your questions.

												I cannot stress enough how poorly Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II is coded and optimized for PC play.  It is abhorrently, horrendously ported from its console iteration, to the point of true unplayability.  This is not a game.  This is a semi-interactive slideshow if its FPS count is anything to go by.  I'll be clear:DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR PC.I can't vouch for its console iterations, as I haven't played them, but save your money, PC gamers.  This was the first Steam purchase after which I felt truly, criminally cheated.  There is no reasonable way to make use of what I bought, and that's not right.  For record, yes, my computer meets and exceeds the minimum specs for installing and playing this game by a longshot, so it's not a user issue.  It's a coding issue, and a damned unforgivable one.

												DO NOT BUY FOR WINDOWS 10

Posted: November 26, 2015
												Okay, SIZE MATTERS. TFU 2 is too damn short - completed it in under 5 hours - one day of not-that-intensive playing. But if you have to choose during developement process between long, meh-game and short and awesome one - answer is obvious. Well, maybe not really, but LucasArts picked the right one. I will complain a lot, but still, it was awesome 5 hours.The Force Unleashed 2 continues the story of Darth Vaders apPrentice - Starkiler. In the end of first game, he was believed to be killed. TFU2 starts from this point - reason for protagonist being alive is introduced pretty nicely - Starkiller we are playing as is one of clones of original Starkiller - with all his memories and skills. As Vader prepares himselft to kill the student after failed tests, Starkiller escapes cloning facilites in Vaders own TIE Advanced. Then follows the piece of information that Vader accidentally gave him and rescues General kota from Cato Nemondia. Later Starkiller tries to find Juno - their meeting is interrupted by Boba Fett and impearial boarding party, who kiddnap Juno and deliver her to Vader. Rebel Alliance attacks Kamino, while Starkiller confronts Vader and his army of clones. Vaders get captured, and thats whole plot. Character levelling system was much simplified - we get points for kills, holocrons and sometimes from destruction - and using them we can increase level of our saber skills or force powers up to level 3. There is a new skill - mind trick, which makes weak enemies either fight for the player, or comitt suicide. As for me - nice.Holocrons are to be found scattered across the maps, they come in 4 different colours - yellow will give more experience points, Red will contain saber crystalls or costumes, green will increase max HP pool, and blue will do the same with force meter. Saber crystalls... yea, they are also much less complex if compared to TFU1 - you have only colour crystals, each colour has it own properties (to compare, in TFU1 you have 2 types of crystals - colour ones with purely cosmetic effects, and ones that gave you specified bonuses like lifesteal or so). While of course, simple, you may end up running with some ugly-colored blades :/ Okay, you can pick different one for each saber (you have two) - two ugly colours instead of one XDQTE - as normally I have nothing against them, here they could have been done a bit better. Yeah, they still look awesome and all.  Sitll we have 4 keys that can be used in QTEs - by default space, LMB, E and Q - but now they appear at the opposite parts of the screen, which means - instead of admiring juicy finishers you look for the key you should press all over the damn screen. Good side is, QTEs are the same for every type of enemy requiring them - so all flamer robots will be finished the same way, all rocket walkers ect.I will also mention some stupid ambiguities. Like eg: go to the engine room and kill imperials before they destroy the engine - yet no problem, destroy some probably important pieces of engine to get through! Or during final fight with Vader (which is - I won't lie - unnecessarily long), Vader knocks Starkiller out and then - ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ESCAPES. No, why should he finish him right there? Okay, it wouldn't be good for the plot - but it would be good for Vader and logics. :/Graphics. Even though the game was out in 2010 i think, it's graphics still amaze me. Wow, just... wow.Ending - to be clear, I picked Light Side ending (yes, you have choice). It was so sugestive... It almost makes me cry after i realise that Disney killed Expanded Universe (YES I WILL NEVER STOP) and there probably will be no TFU3 (instead we have some garbage called Star Wars Rebels, turning Star Wars into some childish things). Too bad...What also bothers me (but only a bit) is that there is no Ultimate Sith Edition Content. Officially. Community alredy figured out how to put use to the files containing Endor duel with Leia. Still something, right?To sum up, TFU2 is a solid but short game. Sure it's good - for theese few hours of gameplay you will have just enough time to savour it - but you will stay hungry. For ever, as there wont be sequel. Still - If you enjoyes TFU1 and want some more - buy it. If you hadn't - still buy it. It's worth it.

Posted: December 7, 2015
												Fun combat, but extremely short game. The gameplay is also incredibly repetitive, and the story may as well not even be there.The story felt like it was trying to be one overarching story split up over two games (with, I assume, the second part being delivered via the third game in the series,) kind of like how Empire and ROTJ did it. However, it ended up being more like if A New Hope ended right as the Millennium Falcon is being pulled onto the Death Star. When it ends, it gives you the choice between a light- and dark-side ending; I chose the dark side ending, and it legitimately made me think they ended the game prematurely on purpose to make players choose the light side, (much like how in Arkham City, when you play as Catwoman near the end, you are able to choose to say "♥♥♥♥ batman" and just leave with the jewels, whereupon you are awarded a lame ending and are then sent back to make the cannon-appropriate decision.) Needless to say, I was pretty surprised when after the credits, the game threw me back to the title screen with no option to pick up where I left off.Moreover, there are really only 3-4 actual levels in the game, all of which, while somewhat distinct from each other, seem to be comprised solely of a few rooms and enemy configurations repeated over and over again until you get to the boss. All of the boss battles are your standard-affair "exploit weakness until boss falls down, then run in for the kill" type, except they are all artificially lengthened to the point that they get kinda boring.The combat outside of boss battles is pretty fun, but there isn’t a whole lot of variety in experience or enemy type. You are able to upgrade your powers with exp, but none of the upgrades really made me feel like they had any impact in my overall combat ability. Same goes for the saber crystals.TLDR: The game wasn’t bad necessarily, but it felt more like a drawn-out expansion of the first game rather than its own distinct entry in the series. The story was dull and didn’t even seem finished, and the gameplay is extremely repetitive. I would recommend passing on this one unless you absolutely loved the first TFU.

Posted: December 2, 2015
												I completed this game in 15 hours making it a fairly short game to beat. However, the graphics, textures, details and overall details of the world are very immersive and the narrative compelling. Exploring Cato Neimodia, Dagobah and being on board the Salvation rebel freighter was rare if ever seen in the expanded universe and was I must say most thrilling. The combat was a little repetitive in the combinations of deadly blows, but surprisingly smooth transitions and very cool action moves make up for it. My only criticism for the gameplay would be that the force speed is set to travel an exact distance which can often make you jump just over your target (despite you wanting to stop) and causing you to expire early from a deadly pitfall into a bottomless canyon. I paid 6 dollars for this on steam sale, and that is why I am not very critical of the game. To be fair, anyone who would have paid the full price would be crushingly dissapointed. In the original Force Unleashed, one had a clear two fold mission, Vader was to use Starkiller as both his inquisitor to hunt down the last remaining Jedi, and then together they would destroy the emperor. His origins on Kashyyyk made him an original character, conceived by the union of two Jedi Knights, a violation of their sacred vow. Galen Marek was a boy when Vader finds him, and he molds him to the Dark Side, but the plot thinkens in a riveting fashion and its conclusion is absolutely surprising, whether you choose light or dark side.The sequel was underwhelming. Yes, we are reunited with General Rham Kota, but it feels empty, almost distracting. We never get to see Captain Juno Eclipse, except extremely briefly and mostly only at the end of the game in a devastatinly dissapointing way. The lack of clear pursuit, and choices makes the Force Unleashed II somewhat less fulfilling. It is a worthy note to mention that the fact that we fight mostly unknowns and over the top monsters (The Gorog sequence felt like I was suddenly playing as a certain God against a certain titan from a certain popular game franchise) make it one of the more unoriginal games I've played and recycled many of the prequels ideas and concepts without really bringing anyhting new.Overall, I would rate this game 6 out of 10 only because the genre was faithful to the universe but I often felt the urge to stop playing from boredom.

Posted: August 24, 2015
												I'm afraid I'm going to have to not recommend this game, which is such as shame after the first one was such a blast.  Whilst fun in parts, everything about this screams "making a sequel for the sake of cashing in on the success of the first".  The first Force Unleashed game is highly recommended in my eyes.  It had a good story, fitting within the cannon.  But this, whilst starting promising, with the whole storyline around cloning which fits well in the Star Wars universe, then fails to go anywhere, and they somehow manage to make the entirety of the game about Starkiller (if you are indeed the original one, and not a clone, though this is never cleared up) hunting down his love Juno, the pilot from the first game.  Oh, and of course foiling Vader in the process.  No real story arc or character development, with the only real other character in the game being general Kota from the first game.  Juno is the stereotypical damsel in distress, and there are a few of the iconic characters from the universe that are crowbarred in for the most unnecessary cameos (including one of the bad guys which seems to imply we were going to face-off against them at some point, but they were promptly dropped and never mentioned again.  Possibly this is potential for another sequel?  Though maybe the developers got a bit of sense as they went along as when the game ends it doesn't really seem to point that way).Okay, so the story is rubbish, how is the gameplay?  Again, this starts by showing promise.  Combat seems fluid, intuitive, varied, challenging and fun, at first glance.  Then you realise you're up against the same array of enemies constantly, with the "tougher" ones being felled by tiresome quick-time events that you have to do nearly every single time and is indeed the quickest way to bring them down.  This gets tiring, especially later only, when you face increasing numbers of them.  I say "tougher" in quotes because as long as you know where the dash key is (there's no stamina, you can dash to your hearts content all day long) you can zip round the battlefield and tear the larger enemies apart with ease.  You're as likely to be felled by them as if you're blindsided by a paltry few troopers.  Speaking of which, if you're quick on the lighting key and pointing vaguely in their general direction you can fell entire legions of the troopers within mere seconds.  And once you've figured out the other enemies weaknesses they go down just as quick.  Unfortunately, you level up to the point you're an absolute killing machine very quickly, so much so that it makes being a badass seem boring.  And as far as I could tell they only introduced 1 new move which was used in the tutorial and then I barely used it again ever.  Basically force lightning and the occasional force repulse is all you need.  Playing on hard was not a challenge and you can breeze through this game in merely half a dozen hours.  This is shockingly brief, even with the ridiculously overlong and padded end boss sequence which wasn't difficult in the slightest, and I wouldn't be an expert, reflexes-wired-to-the-max kinda player by any stretch of the imagination.  To top off the slog, near the end of the battle, a new element is added to the fray without warning which can kill you if you aren't quick and then you have to go back to very near the start of their health bar again!  Such lazy game design by adding a few zeros to a bosses health.  Basically every other boss during the game was more fun than this, even the annoying mechanical spider.  I chose the "good" ending at the end and honestly I've never regretted it so much in my life as it was so hideously saccharine and unexplainable.So, in a nutshell, cheap cashin, which ticks just enough boxes for it to be deemed sellable.  Avoid.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												The Force Unleashed 2 improved in many ways over the first part but still has a lot of flaws. After a good start, it sadly becomes very repetitive so that I can't really recommend this one.Pros:+ Some quite cool finishers for mini-bosses+ Force lighning and grip really feel smooth and badass+ Nice cutscenesNeutral:◯ Story (not bad but there was much more potential)Negative:- Game is locked to 30 fps, it's possible to unlock 60 fps only with hacked .exe but that causes tearing during fast camera turns.- 2 of 3 endbosses are extremely repetitive- way too many QTE; during one endboss you have to press repeatedly one button for what feels like a minute... and that 4 times...- last endboss is just plain boring- very linear levels- barely any enemy variation- short campaign (took me 4-5 hrs); there is an additional difficulty level that is unlocked after the first playthrough and some challenges but I didn't really feel like playing any of them- several bugs that may hinder your progression; had to restart 3 different sections because the game wouldn't trigger the next part or the end of the level.

Posted: June 19, 2015
												UI - Rubbish. The assets don't scale past 720p. You literally get blocky pixelated icons and images on higher resolutions.Story - Rubbish and short.Game Length - 5 hours.Boss fights - Tedious. Not fun. Also, very few of them.Voice Acting - Bad.Writing/Dialog - Cheesy and bad.Combat - Same as the prequel. Same combos, same powers. It's just the game is so short they expedite the powerup process by a huge margin. The only difference is you have 1 more lightsaber so the melee animations are different.I really enjoyed the first one. It had decent pacing and good writing with good set piece moments. It sent you to a variety of locations. It was a pleasant surprise. SW:TFU 2 is the opposite of all those things. There is no equivalent moment of "I'll use the force to send a Star Destroyer crashing into the planet". There is no wow-factor. There is literally nothing to be had here.SW:TFU2 is literally a "Starship Troopers 2"-type sequence. A horrible sequel to a terrific first entry.Do not buy this game, it is a waste of money; not even for $5. You don't need to know what hapened to Starkiller after TFU1 because this sequel does not and will not live up to any form of expectations.

												After playing the first game which i loved, i wanted to try this one out but i never got around to it.Lucky for me it was $5.99 on sale for Steam’s amazing holiday sales.I read most of the reviews and hoped they would not be true but they were.The game feels like a cheap cash grab, i am normally not a stickler for graphics or performance by any means, but the game would get very choppy at moments i wasn't even doing anything. A lot of the in game animations/cutscenes seems like an intern threw them together as a side project. Falling seems to be a recurring theme in this game, along with feats that top anything any Jedi or Sith has ever managed to accomplish. Killing large enemies was extremely repetitive.ProsDismembermentClassic hack & slash SW:FUSome replayability when it comes to collecting itemsConsFrame dropsRepetitivenessOver scaled boss fights (trying too hard to be epic)Cheesy in game moments and featsStory is ok at best.I would not recommend it unless it's free and you have time to kill.

												Another pitiful game, since the animations and art are really enjoyable, and quite improved compared to the first one. For the first 20 minutes, I really enjoyed this game, but after that, I started noticing that they literally make you do the exact same thing 3 times in a row just to add a couple of seconds to the game, which is incredibly short. But when you look at the story, thank God, because I wouldn't of had lasted longer listening to Starkiller's whining. The story is so shallow, the bosses are just annoying, the platform levels are just frustrating, the more you play this, the faster you want the game to end. A real waste. I would not recommend, even if it was free.

Posted: March 13, 2015
Repetitive quick time event fest.Regardless of being a Star Wars fan 2/3 of my life, I couldn't force myself to finish the second level of this game.An hour and half of splicing waves of never-learning imperial forces who make you feel like they are deliberately throwing away they chances to win wasn't THAT bad, but finishing off another freezing robot with the same qte for 20th time made me alt+f4 the game.Here's my bitter list of TFUII flaws: Most repetitive game I've played in months Replaying same quick time events tens of times John Williams memorable score burried under blaster shots It took 30 minutes and 10 re-launches of the game to make x360 controller work Framerate below 30fps on gtx260 (read system requirements)

Posted: July 30, 2015
												The good:Significantly improved graphicsSmoother, more responsive gameplay with some neat new moves (grabs)The bad:QTEs are still as annoying as ever and more difficult than the first game due to the much smaller, much easier to miss indicatorsShort, incomplete story (i.e. this game was severely rushed). Story itself is rather lame compared to the first game.Persisting technical issues and a few new ones and a rude reminder that this is a poorly done console port (if you're using an xbox controller and it disconnects, you have to restart the game for it to work again) (keyboard and mouse control won't work at all if you have certain devices in the windows device manager)The ugly:This game can be easily completed in under 4 hours. Extremely short, even compared to the first game (which I thought was too short already).Conclusion:While this game is an improvement over the original in terms of graphics and gameplay, the persisting technical issues and very short, underwhelming story really undermine this game. Given its length, it really should have been a DLC for the first game (even then the story is pretty pathetic). Unless you really like star wars and can get this for $5, stay away.

Posted: November 10, 2015
												This game gets a lot of hate. No the story is not as compelling as the first game, and it may be short. But it has huge improvements that people want to overlook. The graphics and physics in the game are so much better this time around and the level designs are greatly improved. This game is solid, and feels like a much more cohesive game. If you liked The Force Unleashed, check this game out too. It may not be the amazing game it was hyped for. but it's a fun and satisfying experience, and really that's what gaming is about.

Posted: February 11, 2015
												*Attention:*I have not finished this game yet so take my feedback as is and i will edit the rest of my feedback in when i complete the game 100%. My review:I'm a huge fan of star wars and being the fan that i am, i upped the level of expectations significantly coming into the game. I so far have not been dissappointed. When the game delivers action it delivers non stop action. You go through the game with the whole "Powerful Jedi" vibe running at a high level. You get to use the force to crush other star ships, toss objects around, and even disarm enemy(and yes throw enemy around). It doesn't stop there. You seem to be able to weild both the good and dark side of the force...so naturally...jedi mind tricks and electricity being shot out of your hands  with precision...is apart of that. If being able to weild both the good and dark sides of the force doesn't do it for you...perhaps weilding duel light sabers with full on customization options will. The controls for the light saber combat is ...limited but the display your character will provide while fighting is various and intense. Cinematic at times.*SPOILER ALERT:* Yoda is in the game and so is star killer and darth vadar, but i'm not sure who else at this point. I'm about 2.4 hours into the game thus far but already i can absolutely recommend this to any true star wars fan. If you have a decent graphics card you'll be able to take in the beautiful graphics to boot.Recommend if you can get it for under $14

Posted: February 11, 2015
												Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II, a 3rd person hack and slash platformer with QTE's (quick time events), and a lot of button mashing.Now that the i have that out the way I will delve a little deeper **MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS**.This game is very short, taking me around 4 hours 30 minutes to complete with the 'Light Side' ending. The story is nothing amazing, you are apparantly cloned by Darth Vader who used dna from "Starkiller" of the first game and you are apparantly defective due to the flashbacks you have which are memories from Starkiller's past life, one of the flashbacks reveals the female pilot, Juno from the previous game (who you fall in love with) and you decide to go searching for her  and you kick some♥♥♥♥♥along the way, thats about it so dont expect anything epic. Gameplay is good, but again like the first one its nothing special, another devil may cry hack and slash platformer with an anorexic leveling up system. Some people said its repetetive and it can be, but they also complain saying its the same attacks and QTE's over, and over again, and i know why, button mashing. Instead of timing your attacks to allow variations in your combos and QTE's people are just mashing buttons, I found that timing my attacks and combining force powers in with them resulted in some brilliant combos and finishers and i thoroughly enjoyed doing so for the entire game. The QTE's at first were the same repeated over and over, until i realised they changed depending on how you messed up the enemy, throwing objects at an enemy to start the QTE gave a different result compared to using force lightning to bring up the QTE which resulted in another finishing move, so each QTE to me was different unless it was a mini-boss those were the same. The platfroming side of the game is a big improvement over the first game, its more refined and felt responsive and fluid plus I didnt find myself falling off/out of the level due to poor game mechanics like I did in the first game. So, overall gameplay I found it better, but shorter than the first game.The graphics, that definitive question everyone wants to know, does it look good? YES! it looks nice in 1080p with all settings on max, but has very few graphical options which is nothing new for console ports, it run smooth on my pc with me only having issues with the video cutscenes pausing and crashing the game at first which turned out to be a compatability issue with windows 8.1, but easily fixed by setting compatability to Windows 7. The cutscenes i noticed varied in quality through out the game some being clear then others being blocky, but nothig major.The sound is your typical Star Wars soundtrack always good and what we expect to hear when playing a Star Wars game, but i personally prefered the soundtrack from the first game it felt more dramatic for some reason.Controls, I used a Xbox 360 controller which worked fine no issues at all (it is a console port so thats to be expected) I have read that people say the Keyboard+Mouse is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ to play this game with, but each to their own i say.The game overall was fun to play I really did enjoy it, and im a full on gamer who plays everything and anything and reading the reviews for this game anyone would of thought it was garbage heap material, but its not as bad as people make it out to be. If you have played the first game its the same gameplay just refined and shortened with better visuals and little to no story. It could do with being longer and having more depth not only in storyline but actual character customisation. Its worth playing if you have played the first one but dont pay full price for this try get it in a sale or now from HumbleBundle.com, Its more like an expansion pack for the first game due to the shortness of and the only thing to make you play it again is the challenge mode and alternate endings (load your save chose alternate option, done). Im gonna give this game a 7/10 I liked it, plenty of epic moments just too short.

Posted: February 17, 2015
												Having recentially picked these games up on a humble bundle i as looking forward to getting into them. after completig TFU 1, a game i thought was really fun and had a great story and decent upgredes system and over all even though i thought it was pretty short i liked it and was was looking to any impovements they may have made from the first one.       The second game prettty much takes up where the last left off whithout gettiing to the story you start a good deal more powerful than you did in the first game.Improvements/positives; *Great graphics-better than the last one                                        *Dual lightsabres are just cooler                                         *levels are nicer in some cases with a lot more desuction                                        * combat seems a little more fluid, camera is better.cons                                 *Story is very poor by comparison to the first, its still not that bad but its pretty weak mostly and elements that could have made it much more engaging were kind of ignored after they looked like they would be pivitol. ( the whole clone thing)* Although i really like the titght combat, you can really swing some really cool combos together it can get a little repetetitive as the game goes on( last fight is pathetic in terms of wash rince repeat and the fact that the story doesnt make me even care that im fighting him, as we never really see the love interest thing develop much(even in the first game) , i found myself not caring what happend to her.* Kind of a big one that it seems a lot of people have experienced is the stuttering cutscenes and random crashes, i delt with the cutscenesas there are not that many but it can get bad , and the ridiculous slow down if you wear robes that flow ( this is apparently the reason)OVERALL; I liked the game but i was glad it was short as there was not much there to keep you interested in the campaign. Great graphics great gameplay ok story, god damn kota is annoying in ths one! I d reccomment getting it on sale for 5 bucks if you can and playing it with a 360 pad, at least i found this a lot easier. Nice addition to the first game but to be honest seems like it was put together in a hurry, doesnt do anything different but thats not necessarilly a bad thing .   6.5/10

Posted: February 10, 2015
												Before I even start this, I thoroughly enjoyed the first Force Unleashed game, even though it had it's flaws.This game adds on to the "good" ending of the last one. You know, the one where the rebellion begins and everything?Now, when I say it adds on, I mean it happens after it. Story-wise, this game adds very little. You're essentially chasing someone around the galaxy while you're being chased. No character development, no new characters, just the same old characters from TFU. The entire campaign took me 4 hours, which is way too short for a game that's supposed to be a sequel.Now, this game isn't completely terrible. They fixed a lot of bugs from the first game, made combat a bit more difficult, and made it look pretty. However, this game is just not worth it. Glad I got it in the humble bundle, and didn't have to pay full price for this.

Posted: February 19, 2015
												Upon finishing TFU2, my first thought was "Alright, must've missed something because the game's not over."  Oh boy, was it over.  Clocking in at just over 7 hours of play time, this game feels more like a DLC pack for the first TFU.  I didn't even spend all of my experience upgrading my force powers, because I thought I had more time.  Just one bee in my bonnet- let me take you through the rest.I also thought that it might be DLC because this game is glitchy.  Like, all the glitches.  Clipping during cutscenes, random game-stopping graphical bugs and screen tears, unstoppable cutscenes that lead to character death, character death due to clipping after cutscenes, et cetera, etc.  Bee #2.The repetition.  Oh, the repetition.  I never want to see another QTE-finishing move for the rest of my life.  I am really certain I could've finished this game in four hours if I didn't have to sit through a quick-time event after light-sabering anything bigger than a storm trooper.  And there's a lot of stuff in this game bigger than a storm trooper.  That's the third bee, ladies and gentlemen.I'll stop there, because I could nitpick this game for a while.  I understand that this is someone's best effort, and it really does try to go somewhere with the story of a lonely clone rescuing his damsel in distress.  I wanted more of that, I really did.  But TFU2 just didn't deliver like the first game.  The feeling of being a formidable Sith assassin was fantastic in the first game, extremely fun and empowering.  I hate to sound like a Darth here, but the Light Side presented in this game is a little too vanilla.  Save your money and get TFU1 or Jedi Academy, both excellent games and truer to the Star Wars fanboy (or girl) in all of you.Play this if you enjoy:-having more free time than you originally thought you would-Hayden Christianson's speech inflection-being disappointed in sequels

												First of all, if you are a die hard fan of the first game and absolutely must have a Star Wars fix then this game might be for you, however looking at this from the perspective of a reviewer then this game is a huge disappointment.I really like the first game and the second installment should have built upon an excellent foundation however all this game is is a repetative and boring 4 hours worth of gameplay that leaves you regretting you didn't just play the first game through again.The graphics are really good for a 2010 game and the game runs decently albeit at a capped frame rate. It's a testament to how dull and repetative the game is given that it's so short.All in all I would only recommend this game if it is heavily discounted and even then, only play it if you really liked the first one and wanted to slice up some stormtroopers.

Posted: February 11, 2015
												Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II, a 3rd person hack and slash platformer with QTE's (quick time events), and a lot of button mashing.Now that the i have that out the way I will delve a little deeper **MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS**.This game is very short, taking me around 4 hours 30 minutes to complete with the 'Light Side' ending. The story is nothing amazing, you are apparantly cloned by Darth Vader who used dna from "Starkiller" of the first game and you are apparantly defective due to the flashbacks you have which are memories from Starkiller's past life, one of the flashbacks reveals the female pilot, Juno from the previous game (who you fall in love with) and you decide to go searching for her  and you kick some♥♥♥♥♥along the way, thats about it so dont expect anything epic. Gameplay is good, but again like the first one its nothing special, another devil may cry hack and slash platformer with an anorexic leveling up system. Some people said its repetetive and it can be, but they also complain saying its the same attacks and QTE's over, and over again, and i know why, button mashing. Instead of timing your attacks to allow variations in your combos and QTE's people are just mashing buttons, I found that timing my attacks and combining force powers in with them resulted in some brilliant combos and finishers and i thoroughly enjoyed doing so for the entire game. The QTE's at first were the same repeated over and over, until i realised they changed depending on how you messed up the enemy, throwing objects at an enemy to start the QTE gave a different result compared to using force lightning to bring up the QTE which resulted in another finishing move, so each QTE to me was different unless it was a mini-boss those were the same. The platfroming side of the game is a big improvement over the first game, its more refined and felt responsive and fluid plus I didnt find myself falling off/out of the level due to poor game mechanics like I did in the first game. So, overall gameplay I found it better, but shorter than the first game.The graphics, that definitive question everyone wants to know, does it look good? YES! it looks nice in 1080p with all settings on max, but has very few graphical options which is nothing new for console ports, it run smooth on my pc with me only having issues with the video cutscenes pausing and crashing the game at first which turned out to be a compatability issue with windows 8.1, but easily fixed by setting compatability to Windows 7. The cutscenes i noticed varied in quality through out the game some being clear then others being blocky, but nothig major.The sound is your typical Star Wars soundtrack always good and what we expect to hear when playing a Star Wars game, but i personally prefered the soundtrack from the first game it felt more dramatic for some reason.Controls, I used a Xbox 360 controller which worked fine no issues at all (it is a console port so thats to be expected) I have read that people say the Keyboard+Mouse is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ to play this game with, but each to their own i say.The game overall was fun to play I really did enjoy it, and im a full on gamer who plays everything and anything and reading the reviews for this game anyone would of thought it was garbage heap material, but its not as bad as people make it out to be. If you have played the first game its the same gameplay just refined and shortened with better visuals and little to no story. It could do with being longer and having more depth not only in storyline but actual character customisation. Its worth playing if you have played the first one but dont pay full price for this try get it in a sale or now from HumbleBundle.com, Its more like an expansion pack for the first game due to the shortness of and the only thing to make you play it again is the challenge mode and alternate endings (load your save chose alternate option, done). Im gonna give this game a 7/10 I liked it, plenty of epic moments just too short.

Posted: February 15, 2015
												Game: Star Wars: The Force Unleashed IIFormat: PCReleased: 0ctober 2010With the recent advent of Humble Bundles or at least to me they are newish I decided to buy to star wars bundle. In said bundle I received overall a total of 12 star wars games, I won't bore you with the list but that is a lot of star wars.  The game I want to draw attention to here is Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II. Now  personally I loved the first game other than the levels on Felucia it was a genuinely stellar game. It made you feel powerful, like a real force user out for revenge. The second one? Not so much. It's good and I enjoyed my time with it but my biggest issue is time. I completed the game quit out looked and steam and there it was. FOUR hours of game play from start to finish. Granted I was running through it on medium difficulty but even so should a sequel to a game that had a solid 8-10 story with a♥♥♥♥♥♥tonne of DLC released after the fact last FOUR ♥♥♥♥ing hours? No is the answer to that question. I'll save that rant for later though let's talk about the good first shall we? GraphicsIt was a beautiful game when it first released back in October 2010 and it really does still stand up 4 years later. Weather effects, clothing moving in high winds, the motion capture is genuinely stellar it really shines through. Environments are fantastic and true to the movies, there are really very few games that get as visually close to delivering a star wars experience like Force Unleashed II. The flip side to this is artifacting everywhere all the time. graphical glitches were many and if this were a longer game maybe it would count as less but after FOUR hours there are just far too many graphic glitches. Another thing that ties into that is absolutely no V-syncing options at all and it's constantly stuck at 30FPS no matter the hardware configuration.Game Play/MechanicsThis is another place where I feel the game before was a better example of how to do things.  It had a better level system,  It had the better skill upgrades In the prequel you gain experience, level up, earn talent spheres, and the spend them on abilities. combos, and skills. in the sequel every time you break something or someone you gain force points which you then spend on the 6 skills open to you. This is literally it. you gain minor other bonuses from different Light Saber crystals but it's so insignificant its barely even worth mentioning. The fighting is much the same but with a severe lack of combos (of which there are only about 20 as opposed to the amount from game number one) really limits the flashy combat and pulls you away from feeling like you are a stupidly powerful Jedi/Sith. No real puzzle elements or alternate paths and that really doesn't help it's case of FOUR hours.SoundThis will be a real short one. It sounds like Star Wars. biggest point to note here is like the prequel Mr James Earl Jones returns as the voice of Darth Vader. Voice acting is actually very well don across the board but then again you only ever hear about 5 characters actually speak. whodathunkit?ReplayabilityNOPE. FOUR hours. FOUR hours. On a harder difficulty I might've gone a whopping 5 hours. some challenges await after completing the game and what DLC was released when pulled from sale for whatever reason. Once this game is finished there is NO reason to EVER come back to it.StoryYou play as the clone of Starkiller for game numero uno on a quest for revenge and to save the one he loves. awww isn't that cute? isn't it also the most generic thing ever? I won't rant too much here I did enjoy it even for its generic seen it before storyline the voice acting really helped me trundle through the story. Much like the first game(noticing a theme yet?) you will be required to fight Darth Vader. this is the highlight of any of the bosses but I felt even that may have dragged on a bit too long.Okay rant time. Lucas Arts all you had to do was make the first game again make it look prettier and everyone would have been so happy with the end product but no, like every other developer you decide that you should change one of the fundamentally greatest things from the first game. The progression for Starkiller. you took what made that game great and just♥♥♥♥♥♥all over it with number 2(see what I did there?) I really wish that you had just copy pasted for number 2 and considering that  because of Disney we won't get number 3 there are so many things you left unanswered. is he Starkiller prime? is he just a clone like all the rest? If he is a clone why can he use the force? There is a real simple solution to all of this. DONT MAKE IT FOUR ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS! another 4-6 hours and you could have told the rest of star killers story and fans would have been happy but now all I have is an empty pit of unanswered questions and disappointment for series that could have been so much more.Positives•	Graphically beautiful•	Stellar voice work•	James Earl JonesNegatives•	Story was bland and been there done that•	graphical glitches•	FOUR hours•	No replayability what so ever•	FOUR hoursI wish I could rate this higher but its only worth a 5 out of 10 IF this is your first outing with SW:TFUII then it will be fine and fun but please go back and play the first one it's so much better.

Posted: December 22, 2015
												The Force Unleashed 2 is so much better than the first game in every way.The visuals and art direction for everything (characters, environment, effects) is leaps and bounds better than the first entry. The gameplay itself gets a significant upgrade. You get all your abilities from the start (though you can still upgrade them as you level up), but the levels are integrated with varied enemies and barricades that require you to mix up your tactics at all points in time.The action is fast-paced, and the story feels very much at home in the Star Wars setting. While the first game, you would only really play for the story, this game lets you blow through hundreds of enemies in a short play session that makes you feel like the most powerful Force-user to ever exist in the Star Wars universe.7/10 "Good"

Posted: December 20, 2015
												To oversimplify it, the first one is better.Generally I look at games in terms of Gameplay, plot, systems/stability ('under the hood' judged from outside) and graphics. Usually we like sequels to improve on most of these, but to get only one out of four is slightly disappointing.Graphically: obvious improvements over the first one, pretty good. Generally consistent aesthetic to what I'd expect from Star Wars too. Not many really obvious graphical bugs or anything, a few things fade out of existence from now and then, but that's probably a functional thing so they don't fill your memory with pieces of broken box.Stability-wise, it's a step down from the original. I completed that twice with two crashes (which I think only happened because I was alt-tabbing about). This seems to be crashing every 60-90 minutes on average. Not sure why, sometimes it's in heavy combat, and sometimes it happens when I was lurking at a checkpoint eating a bag of crisps and the game wasn't really doing anything.My computer is definitely powerful enough to handle it. Maybe the backwards/forwards compatibility is causing problems.But aside from occasionally crashing, the game seems fairly well built, technically at least. I've yet to run into any notable bugs.Gameplay: the biggest disappointment.I’ll preface this by saying I’m not very good at this kind of game, I prefer a nice FPS where I can lurk in the distance and shoot people in the head, or an RTS where I can turtle away in some forgotten corner of the map. That said the gameplay was at times boringly easy on its ‘normal’ difficulty, at worst it tended to be awkward.The cut scenes are long and there's just a massive amount of time spent in quick time events. Would calling then ‘slow time events’ be childish? It generally feels like they wanted to make an animated film, but couldn't, so they let you press buttons from time to time and call it a game. Okay, that's an exaggeration, but it annoys me a bit.For example, one of the iconic bits of the first game is when you pull a star destroyer out the sky, you do this by force gripping it, and pulling it down. (You also have to make it face you, for no apparent reason, other than to make it hit you in the face when it lands, but drama.) In a similar sequence in this game you just sort of watch, and when it tells you to, you press a button a few times.Repetition is a bit problem, near the start fighting some giant rancor-eating monster you have to repeat identical game sections several times. While you're doing this, there's someone constantly shouting at you, telling you to do something, you've already sone once. And they complain you haven't done it yet multiple times before the sequence can repeat.I think in this game someone says something like 'A single Jedi can turn the tide of a war', and in the first one I could more or less believe that. In this game it's just odd. I guess it's technically true, given the number of enemies that perfectly resist any attempt to damage them, with anything but one specific power, so you'd need a jedi. But it's sometimes odd. Some enemies need to be hit with a radial force push, a normal straight one doesn't work, but a radial one staggers or outright kills them. Perhaps they are actually invincible, but terrified of circles?Then there's a massive number of force powered people, Sith acolytes or something, that will block your force powers. Some of them have lightsabers and block most melee attacks, so you have to grapple them; annoying I guess, but made more so by the fact there only seems to be one grapple animation. It’s slow, and very specific, and when you’re facing a few of them at the same time it’s incredibly tedious watching the same animation again and again. The only way I’ve found to make it fun is to try and line up the grapples so they fall off things when the animation completes. (You can briefly use powers on them while they’re standing up too.)Then there are the robots. Lots of identical robots, that must be killed in more or less the same way every time. Repetitive and irritating. The only difference I’ve found is which exact buttons is used in the lasts stage of the quick time event. Another animation would make this better, but whatever…The game also seems to forget what sensible people like; random sections turn into platformers where you have to climb things or traverse spaces with a mediocre advanced movement system. Fortunately for most of these, when you inevitably fall off they send you back to the start rather than killing you, which could be worse. But, for example, on Kamino there are airborne robots that are levitating, as they do. But they’re all staying perfectly still for no apparent reason, sitting in just the right place to let you cross places that the people controlling them shouldn’t be wanting you to cross. Plot: (small rant here, sorry) It's a bit odd to be honest. Largely the apparent motivations of Starkiller. For a  large part of the game he seems to have turned into a whiney idiot, totally obsessed with a girl he barely knows, jeopardising the rebel alliance, his own life etc. for no logical reason. Which isn't inherently, I understand love is a strong motivator for people, leading to irrational behaviour, except the barely know each other. After a few mildly suggestive conversations in the first game, and a kiss he's infatuated?That irritation aside, the rest of the plot is weak. Interesting enough to keep me playing, but just barely.Summary:Worse than the first.Gameplay is kind of fun, tearing apart little people, but there are lots of irrationally awkward big things.It likes to crash, for me at least. I’ve yet to figure out why. It's kinda pretty though.

												I try to keep track of which games I own / have played / have finished. It took me a while to remember I'd even played Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II, never mind finished it. And that really sums up the game.Compared to the original Force Unleashed, it's more fun to play, slicker, and has far fewer moments that pretend to be challenging but are actually just annoying (no Purge Troopers here!). But it's also more forgettable, shorter (and yet still repetitive), less rewarding to replay, and the story somehow manages to be tedious despite the short length of the game.I wouldn't recommend this even if you liked The Force Unleashed. I did, for all its flaws. This sequel does get rid of some of those flaws, but what remains is a scant few hours of disposable and unnecessary cruft. If you need to buy every Star Wars game that exists, then maybe consider this a low priority. I don't hate it; I just don't feel much about it at all, on those rare occasions I remember it exists.

Posted: May 22, 2016
												Alright. Take the stage structure of devil may cry 3 and 4, add a delightful combat system that feels like a Chinese combat video with twin swords, add the most cliche get the girl story, impressive graphics, a dumbed down upgrade system, and there's the game. Gamplay wise, this is leagues better than the first, there is a more realistic idea of what lightsaber sword play should be like, with the same amount of fundamentals seen in normal sword play dealing with the leg work. There are very few bosses here, but unlike the first game, these bosses all are fair to fight. You don't have to fling objects at everything to win. But, there are times when it is almost an implicit need to do so. The variety has taken a significant plunge, basically to the point where there's gun guys, a few saber guys, and the atat and the mid sized counterpart. So you're basically Chinese dual blade warlord guy running through the game killing like the same 8 guys. The game is pretty fair on hard mode, enemies who would normally get torn in half, still get torn in half, the guns hurt bad, and the larger enemies serve more as upsets rather than enemies, because just one of them getting their way, or you ignoring them is enough for you to die, a lot. Fortunately by the time you're dying for some balance, you'll be able to throw your saber. So yes. The layout of the game though, is pure poor, you basically play as a runaway, and after you realize there isn't much to do outside, you go right back home. If the combat elements and graphics didn't take such a fantastic leap, I'd really just consider this dlc. There's nothing really here aside from fancy Polish and a very powerful situation bound by Neanderthal basic instinct. If I could have a wish, it would be that the two games trade combat systems, because the first one is abysmal when it comes to combat, but the story elements and pacing are pretty normal, and the RPG elements are very nicely done as well. But the poltergeist combat vision is what destroys that game, where here, it's basically everything but the combat, experience system, graphics. If you're like me, and need a PC 3rd person run around cut stuff find stuff game, but NEED actual combat, get this. It's different, wild fun that will keep you happy for like 4 hours... Just, put it on hard mode. Honestly, because of how star wars is and how rich it is in potential as well as marketing, I don't know how they haven't even begun to put their foot into the market as some actual scenarios that have Jedi doing things like these that isn't only centralized in the militia vs army type of combat. Especially if they're trying to force their way into (The ending of this game). They need to carry over that combat style, and make money, because PC needs more games with satisfying combat.

												I played this game on Xbox when it was "current," and I can assure you that it's a great game. However, this is NOT a PC game. It is incredibly obvious that this is just a shoddily done PC port from a console game. The game itself is locked at 30fps and there is no workaround, and god forbid you play on a screen above 720p.TFUII is a great game... on console. I do not recommend buying it on PC.

Posted: February 8, 2015
Score: 6/10OverviewYou are back at Darth Vaders side training for future missions as the clone of Starkiller. Memories keep flooding back to you from Starkillers past leading Vader to consider you a flawed clone. You escape so that Vader doesn't kill you and begin your journey to find out who you are.PositiveThe combat feels better than the orignal if you ask me. Sure its a bit of a buttom mashup, but honestly who cares when it's fun. The levels aren't as big and less resources were used, but with a more streamlined design comes better playability. The graphics have been increased since the original as well, but that may also be because the levels are smaller. The boss fights in this game are fewer and less challenging, but they feel like boss fights. The boss fights are much more God of War. The PC port is actually playable.NegativeThe game is short. The smaller levels and lack of resources make some zones feel copy and pasted. The story is even more bland then the original and the ending makes you glad you didn't take much stake in it. The game did completely freeze causing me to have to restart twice.ConclusionThis is a better PC port and the way the levels are designed to be played is much smoother then the original. It seems way to obvious that it wasn't developed as long though because the levels are repetitious and for a game that is only about 5 hours that is saying something.ValueConsidering it is a bad port of an ok game I value it at $4.

Posted: March 7, 2015
												Although I recommend this game, I do so cautiously. I purchased this game as part of a bundle and played it immediately after Force Unleased I. The game looks significantly better, and is much less buggy than its predecessor. Hurling baddies across the galaxy is a lot of fun and the force powers work much better in this game than they did before. That being said, there are still a lot of really strange bugs that can hamper gameplay at various times. I had to restart one level because the auto-sequence wouldn't initiate due to one of the troopers getting stuck in a wall. I couldn't eliminate him and the sequence couldn't play out. There are a ton of fun moments in this game. You'll fight giant monsters, use the force in powerful ways and say 'wow' more than once. That being said, the game is highly repetitive. Unlike the first game, there is little variety. For example, in the Force Unleashed, you can trigger a QTE to eliminate certain foes. There was more than one animation for these baddies because I'm sure the developers wanted things to feel fresh. Unfortunately, that variety was not carried over to this game. You fight the same guys over and over again and QTE them to the same animations over and over. It becomes boring and lackluster. The final "boss" battle was extremely repetitive and I simply tuned out. I'm sure if I had had a laser pointer, I could have had a cat jump on the strike button multiple times for twenty minutes and had won. I would have given the game an 7.5 out of 10. After the final fight, I give the game a 6. I couldn't believe how boring it was. Strike, strike, jump, repeat. That's it. And the worse part? It takes forever! I can't believe this got through the various design levels while this game was in development.One thing you'll probably hear is that this game is short. I beat the game in 4 hours. Quite short indeed.Ultimately, I would recommend the game if you can find it for less than $5. I wouldn't pay a penny more than that and even $5 is a bit of a stretch.

Posted: November 26, 2015
												Okay, SIZE MATTERS. TFU 2 is too damn short - completed it in under 5 hours - one day of not-that-intensive playing. But if you have to choose during developement process between long, meh-game and short and awesome one - answer is obvious. Well, maybe not really, but LucasArts picked the right one. I will complain a lot, but still, it was awesome 5 hours.The Force Unleashed 2 continues the story of Darth Vaders apPrentice - Starkiler. In the end of first game, he was believed to be killed. TFU2 starts from this point - reason for protagonist being alive is introduced pretty nicely - Starkiller we are playing as is one of clones of original Starkiller - with all his memories and skills. As Vader prepares himselft to kill the student after failed tests, Starkiller escapes cloning facilites in Vaders own TIE Advanced. Then follows the piece of information that Vader accidentally gave him and rescues General kota from Cato Nemondia. Later Starkiller tries to find Juno - their meeting is interrupted by Boba Fett and impearial boarding party, who kiddnap Juno and deliver her to Vader. Rebel Alliance attacks Kamino, while Starkiller confronts Vader and his army of clones. Vaders get captured, and thats whole plot. Character levelling system was much simplified - we get points for kills, holocrons and sometimes from destruction - and using them we can increase level of our saber skills or force powers up to level 3. There is a new skill - mind trick, which makes weak enemies either fight for the player, or comitt suicide. As for me - nice.Holocrons are to be found scattered across the maps, they come in 4 different colours - yellow will give more experience points, Red will contain saber crystalls or costumes, green will increase max HP pool, and blue will do the same with force meter. Saber crystalls... yea, they are also much less complex if compared to TFU1 - you have only colour crystals, each colour has it own properties (to compare, in TFU1 you have 2 types of crystals - colour ones with purely cosmetic effects, and ones that gave you specified bonuses like lifesteal or so). While of course, simple, you may end up running with some ugly-colored blades :/ Okay, you can pick different one for each saber (you have two) - two ugly colours instead of one XDQTE - as normally I have nothing against them, here they could have been done a bit better. Yeah, they still look awesome and all.  Sitll we have 4 keys that can be used in QTEs - by default space, LMB, E and Q - but now they appear at the opposite parts of the screen, which means - instead of admiring juicy finishers you look for the key you should press all over the damn screen. Good side is, QTEs are the same for every type of enemy requiring them - so all flamer robots will be finished the same way, all rocket walkers ect.I will also mention some stupid ambiguities. Like eg: go to the engine room and kill imperials before they destroy the engine - yet no problem, destroy some probably important pieces of engine to get through! Or during final fight with Vader (which is - I won't lie - unnecessarily long), Vader knocks Starkiller out and then - ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ESCAPES. No, why should he finish him right there? Okay, it wouldn't be good for the plot - but it would be good for Vader and logics. :/Graphics. Even though the game was out in 2010 i think, it's graphics still amaze me. Wow, just... wow.Ending - to be clear, I picked Light Side ending (yes, you have choice). It was so sugestive... It almost makes me cry after i realise that Disney killed Expanded Universe (YES I WILL NEVER STOP) and there probably will be no TFU3 (instead we have some garbage called Star Wars Rebels, turning Star Wars into some childish things). Too bad...What also bothers me (but only a bit) is that there is no Ultimate Sith Edition Content. Officially. Community alredy figured out how to put use to the files containing Endor duel with Leia. Still something, right?To sum up, TFU2 is a solid but short game. Sure it's good - for theese few hours of gameplay you will have just enough time to savour it - but you will stay hungry. For ever, as there wont be sequel. Still - If you enjoyes TFU1 and want some more - buy it. If you hadn't - still buy it. It's worth it.

Posted: February 16, 2015
												Summary: 7/10 - In every way but the story and quantity of content, this game is an improvment on the original. Worth playing, but wait for it to go on sale. Be aware that you may experience crashing while attempting to play the game with a gamepad. Don't worry, it handles relatively well with a mouse and keypad, for a console port.The Force Unleashed II looks better, plays better, controls better, and feels better than the original. Combat is far more satisfying. They did away with some of the more annoying enemies and mechanics, while enhancing the game feel of the rest. However, the storyline has suffered in this sequel. It's not terrible, but it is very short and trite even compared to the first game. Definetly worth playing if you can get it for a few dollars.

												The game is quite different from the original as the game engine has been redone making the game speed faster and very similar in tone to the God of War series. 												This game was a sorry excuse of a sequel. I was really disappointed, having played the first game many times I was expecting a similiar experience with this one. Posted: December 9, 2015
												First of all, if you are a die hard fan of the first game and absolutely must have a Star Wars fix then this game might be for you, however looking at this from the perspective of a reviewer then this game is a huge disappointment.I really like the first game and the second installment should have built upon an excellent foundation however all this game is is a repetative and boring 4 hours worth of gameplay that leaves you regretting you didn't just play the first game through again.The graphics are really good for a 2010 game and the game runs decently albeit at a capped frame rate.  The controls are easy to learn and force powers are less awkward to use that in the first game. The story is ok, I would recommend playing through the first game as the sequel draws heavily from it and you'll have a hard time feeling any sort of emotional connection to the other characters without the help of the first game.  This game is only 4 hours long and you don't really learn anything new about the characters that you couldn't gleem from the first game.Enemy variety is really poor, there are only a few types that will be thrown at you over and over again during the story and after the 50th time of using the same move to pull the shield of a carbonite spraying attack droid I was ready to pull my hair out.  It's a testament to how dull and repetative the game is given that it's so short.All in all I would only recommend this game if it is heavily discounted and even then, only play it if you really liked the first one and wanted to slice up some stormtroopers.

Posted: May 9, 2012
												Star Wars The Force Unleashed II is a third person action game, centered around StarKiller, Darth Vader's "clone" jedi who escapes from his facility and sets out on a quest to save Juno, a rebel commander and former love. The game is only singleplayer and rather linear, but a wide range of combat techniques makes it a blast to playThe Good-graphics; dynamic and unique, this game looks like a CGI cinematic during gameplay.-combat. Feels refined, no odd glitches or overpowered abilities or enemies.-Story. The constant pursuit to rescue Juno keeps the pace of the game quick.The Bad-variety. Not the largest variety of enemies. Trying to keep enemies in-line with the franchise is challenging, but is also restrictive.-quicktime events. Overdone and finishes off tough enemies quickly and easily.-No multiplayer. Given the beautiful maps and sound combat features, why is it only singleplayer?This game is packed with action, nice graphics and very good voice acting.Score: 7.5/10

Posted: July 14, 2014
												Well about this game, lets start with the pro's. Since the first Star Wars the Force Unleashed the combat has massively improved. Starkiller is not only wielding two lightsabers but his powers have majorly increased. For me this was a really good thing, beacause I always wanted to see what starkiller is cable off, and in this game you experience the force at its maximum. Another thing I liked was the upgraded graphics. For its time, SWTFU 2 looked amazing and it still does on PC. Finally, the gameplay was also updated with loads of new moves and a very impressive engine. Nevertheless, SWTFU 2 suffers from a lot of problems. Let's start with the story. The story from the first game was interesting, quite comlicated and offered us a lot of lore. In this game however, the story lacks charater, polish, and doesn't make sense at some moments. This is a big flaw for me, as I enjoy Star Wars games for their story, and SWTFU 2 fails to deliver this at a passable level. Then there is the lenght. I completed the Campaign in a mere 5 hours. 5 ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS. For 29,99 I expected more than pretty graphics and a few costumes. Another HUGE flaw was the easy as balls and forgetable boss battle with, you guessed it, Dark Pops. Overal does this game not what a sequel should do. The campaign is shorter, the story is duller and hard to follow and the price is too high. Lucasarts did a lot of work on the outside (graphics, moveset and engine) that they completly forgot the ambiance, the vibe and the overal experience. A Star Wars game should give the player a memorable experiece instead of a shiny, polygon physics demo. That's why I recommend that you play the first one, buy the ultimate sith edition, and let this one pass. Star Wars The Force Unleashed II Gets a 5,1 out of 10

Posted: December 2, 2012
												For the first time I must say: IGNORE THE METACRITICS. This game excels in both combat, storyline, dialogues, voice acting, graphics and playability. It has verything: combats, puzzles, real-time action, minigames, sequences, and it even tailors the story as you play based on the choices you make.*SPOILER ALERT* When I first started this game and saw the first level was Kamino I knew it was off to a good start, and that I made a wonderful deal buying this. Absolutely gorgeous. I'm a big Kamino fan, and I really hope I get to visit it. *SPOILER FINISHED*But seriously; this game is even better than the first one, which I also recommend. And it looks better than most modern games even though it's relatively old. So, if you read any critics that destroy this game, at least give this game the benefit of the doubt and get it when it's on sale. You may have a sweet surprise around the corner.

Posted: June 19, 2014
												The game looks great, and there are a few really cool setpieces, but almost everything else is a bit of a disappointment compared to the original — not to mention that the first game wrapped up quite nicely, and now LucasArts has added a ton of unresolved plot strings to a series that might never see another entry due to poor reception. If you do decide to play it, your choice of platform will probably depend on whether or not you care about the DLC, which doesn't exist for the PC version. If you really liked the first one and can find the second one for cheap, it's worth considering, but don't expect to be blown away.Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2012/03/star-wars-force-unleashed-ii.html

Posted: March 30, 2016
  PROS CONS   + Good graphics and character animation+ Atmospheric+ Fun and simple combat system+ Relatively good plot (although it assumes you played the previous game)+ Great music+ Hilarious force grip mechanics  - Pretty repetitive, especially during boss fights (that are artifically extended)- 30 fps cap- Very short, absolutely not worth the base price- Low variety of enemies- QTE button prompts do not stand out enough, it's very easy to simply not notice them- Control scheme issues when not using a gamepad- Horribly ugly, low res UI textures- Character progression is way too primitive

Posted: April 7, 2016
												It's fun, the progression is kinda iffy, you get the right skills early and everything is a breeze until mid game where no matter how many holocrons you find the next fight will be difficult. A real downside are the boss battles, they're creative with some fun mechanics but oh boy... THEY-ARE-EFFING-LONG! I'm not kidding the last boss fight took me over an hour counting deaths, my hands hurt after that.The plot is good but it can't be hard to write a story when you have lasers and lightsabres.Oh yeah, it crashed several times, sometimes even twice in the same level so make sure you save the game after you're done with a difficult combat.

Posted: November 26, 2015
												Okay, SIZE MATTERS. TFU 2 is too damn short - completed it in under 5 hours - one day of not-that-intensive playing. But if you have to choose during developement process between long, meh-game and short and awesome one - answer is obvious. Well, maybe not really, but LucasArts picked the right one. I will complain a lot, but still, it was awesome 5 hours.The Force Unleashed 2 continues the story of Darth Vaders apPrentice - Starkiler. In the end of first game, he was believed to be killed. TFU2 starts from this point - reason for protagonist being alive is introduced pretty nicely - Starkiller we are playing as is one of clones of original Starkiller - with all his memories and skills. As Vader prepares himselft to kill the student after failed tests, Starkiller escapes cloning facilites in Vaders own TIE Advanced. Then follows the piece of information that Vader accidentally gave him and rescues General kota from Cato Nemondia. Later Starkiller tries to find Juno - their meeting is interrupted by Boba Fett and impearial boarding party, who kiddnap Juno and deliver her to Vader. Rebel Alliance attacks Kamino, while Starkiller confronts Vader and his army of clones. Vaders get captured, and thats whole plot. Character levelling system was much simplified - we get points for kills, holocrons and sometimes from destruction - and using them we can increase level of our saber skills or force powers up to level 3. There is a new skill - mind trick, which makes weak enemies either fight for the player, or comitt suicide. As for me - nice.Holocrons are to be found scattered across the maps, they come in 4 different colours - yellow will give more experience points, Red will contain saber crystalls or costumes, green will increase max HP pool, and blue will do the same with force meter. Saber crystalls... yea, they are also much less complex if compared to TFU1 - you have only colour crystals, each colour has it own properties (to compare, in TFU1 you have 2 types of crystals - colour ones with purely cosmetic effects, and ones that gave you specified bonuses like lifesteal or so). While of course, simple, you may end up running with some ugly-colored blades :/ Okay, you can pick different one for each saber (you have two) - two ugly colours instead of one XDQTE - as normally I have nothing against them, here they could have been done a bit better. Yeah, they still look awesome and all.  Sitll we have 4 keys that can be used in QTEs - by default space, LMB, E and Q - but now they appear at the opposite parts of the screen, which means - instead of admiring juicy finishers you look for the key you should press all over the damn screen. Good side is, QTEs are the same for every type of enemy requiring them - so all flamer robots will be finished the same way, all rocket walkers ect.I will also mention some stupid ambiguities. Like eg: go to the engine room and kill imperials before they destroy the engine - yet no problem, destroy some probably important pieces of engine to get through! Or during final fight with Vader (which is - I won't lie - unnecessarily long), Vader knocks Starkiller out and then - ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ESCAPES. No, why should he finish him right there? Okay, it wouldn't be good for the plot - but it would be good for Vader and logics. :/Graphics. Even though the game was out in 2010 i think, it's graphics still amaze me. Wow, just... wow.Ending - to be clear, I picked Light Side ending (yes, you have choice). It was so sugestive... It almost makes me cry after i realise that Disney killed Expanded Universe (YES I WILL NEVER STOP) and there probably will be no TFU3 (instead we have some garbage called Star Wars Rebels, turning Star Wars into some childish things). Too bad...What also bothers me (but only a bit) is that there is no Ultimate Sith Edition Content. Officially. Community alredy figured out how to put use to the files containing Endor duel with Leia. Still something, right?To sum up, TFU2 is a solid but short game. Sure it's good - for theese few hours of gameplay you will have just enough time to savour it - but you will stay hungry. For ever, as there wont be sequel. Still - If you enjoyes TFU1 and want some more - buy it. If you hadn't - still buy it. It's worth it.
