Posted: November 29, 2015
												If you're running Windows 10, be prepared not to be able to make it past the LucasArts logo screen before the game freezes up on you. Seems to be a common issue, but tech support for this game no longer exists, so I'd suggest weighing your options carefully and buying something else that works instead. Requested a refund.

Posted: December 2, 2015
												I completed this game in 15 hours making it a fairly short game to beat. However, the graphics, textures, details and overall details of the world are very immersive and the narrative compelling. Exploring Cato Neimodia, Dagobah and being on board the Salvation rebel freighter was rare if ever seen in the expanded universe and was I must say most thrilling. The combat was a little repetitive in the combinations of deadly blows, but surprisingly smooth transitions and very cool action moves make up for it. My only criticism for the gameplay would be that the force speed is set to travel an exact distance which can often make you jump just over your target (despite you wanting to stop) and causing you to expire early from a deadly pitfall into a bottomless canyon. I paid 6 dollars for this on steam sale, and that is why I am not very critical of the game. To be fair, anyone who would have paid the full price would be crushingly dissapointed. In the original Force Unleashed, one had a clear two fold mission, Vader was to use Starkiller as both his inquisitor to hunt down the last remaining Jedi, and then together they would destroy the emperor. His origins on Kashyyyk made him an original character, conceived by the union of two Jedi Knights, a violation of their sacred vow. Galen Marek was a boy when Vader finds him, and he molds him to the Dark Side, but the plot thinkens in a riveting fashion and its conclusion is absolutely surprising, whether you choose light or dark side.The sequel was underwhelming. Yes, we are reunited with General Rham Kota, but it feels empty, almost distracting. We never get to see Captain Juno Eclipse, except extremely briefly and mostly only at the end of the game in a devastatinly dissapointing way. The lack of clear pursuit, and choices makes the Force Unleashed II somewhat less fulfilling. It is a worthy note to mention that the fact that we fight mostly unknowns and over the top monsters (The Gorog sequence felt like I was suddenly playing as a certain God against a certain titan from a certain popular game franchise) make it one of the more unoriginal games I've played and recycled many of the prequels ideas and concepts without really bringing anyhting new.Overall, I would rate this game 6 out of 10 only because the genre was faithful to the universe but I often felt the urge to stop playing from boredom.

												DO NOT BUY FOR WINDOWS 10

Posted: December 7, 2015
												Fun combat, but extremely short game. The gameplay is also incredibly repetitive, and the story may as well not even be there.The story felt like it was trying to be one overarching story split up over two games (with, I assume, the second part being delivered via the third game in the series,) kind of like how Empire and ROTJ did it. However, it ended up being more like if A New Hope ended right as the Millennium Falcon is being pulled onto the Death Star. When it ends, it gives you the choice between a light- and dark-side ending; I chose the dark side ending, and it legitimately made me think they ended the game prematurely on purpose to make players choose the light side, (much like how in Arkham City, when you play as Catwoman near the end, you are able to choose to say "♥♥♥♥ batman" and just leave with the jewels, whereupon you are awarded a lame ending and are then sent back to make the cannon-appropriate decision.) Needless to say, I was pretty surprised when after the credits, the game threw me back to the title screen with no option to pick up where I left off.Moreover, there are really only 3-4 actual levels in the game, all of which, while somewhat distinct from each other, seem to be comprised solely of a few rooms and enemy configurations repeated over and over again until you get to the boss. All of the boss battles are your standard-affair "exploit weakness until boss falls down, then run in for the kill" type, except they are all artificially lengthened to the point that they get kinda boring.The combat outside of boss battles is pretty fun, but there isn’t a whole lot of variety in experience or enemy type. You are able to upgrade your powers with exp, but none of the upgrades really made me feel like they had any impact in my overall combat ability. Same goes for the saber crystals.TLDR: The game wasn’t bad necessarily, but it felt more like a drawn-out expansion of the first game rather than its own distinct entry in the series. The story was dull and didn’t even seem finished, and the gameplay is extremely repetitive. I would recommend passing on this one unless you absolutely loved the first TFU.

Posted: December 3, 2015
												In my experience, this game is straight up better than The Force Unleashed in every way except for game length. Coming in at a paltry 4 hours of campaign and totally missing the DLCs that the consoles got, I was still blown away by the massively improved combat, graphics, story direction and the fact that you can dual wield lightsabers. No, there's no explanation why you wield two now, it's just awesome. Because of the length and lack of content, I would recommend you get this game for under $10 if possible. I can still see the average person not enjoying this though so if you played the first one or think the combat looks nice, I'd say play this one.

Posted: December 6, 2015
												I'm going to recommend this game but only if you can get the game on sale. It's not worth full price so I'll do a little pros and cons list.Pros: -Combat is more fluid than the first game-Force powers are still as fun as ever-Graphics are a nice change from the first game-Cut scenes and story continue the legacy of StarkillerCons:-AI and controls can be a bit weird at times-Game is super short, all hours on record was the time it took to beat the game from start to finish on standard difficulty (compared to 3x that much for TFU I)All in all the game is fun and great to start up shortly after beating TFU I as it really is just a big expansion to the first game honestly. Pick it up during a sale and you won't be disappointed, just don't expect a huge/full game. Like I said, think of it more as an expansion to the original game, like TFU 1.5, than a true sequel.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												I got this as a part of the "Star Wars Humble Bundle" a while back and have only just got around to playing it back to back with its predecesor.  All in all, this is a mixed bag of bits.  If you have played the previous episode, disappointment will set in rather quickly.   Graphically, character animations are much improved from the original, but backgrounds seem to be standard fodder and there is a marked difference in quality of some levels.   Sound and effects are satisfying, and the game doesnt suffer the random volume levels of the previous one where background n arration and music would drop out for no reason.  Satisfying sound a-la Lucasfilm and Star Wars themes a plenty here.  Gameplay wise however the game falls flat on its face.  The game suffers from tedious poor story and level development, making you duplicate the levels backwards in places to act as filler.  Camera focus is annoying and often leads you to wish you could pull the camera back just to see what you are doing.  in other places, the system, works fine, so its not a complete waste, but it could have been better.  All in all, the level design is a bit dull.  This wouldnt be too bad if the general tone of the missions was different but monotonous repetitive grinding gets boring after a while.  Although theres are some nice touches (breakable environments, the occasional heroic cutscene as you destroy a big boss (a-la Gods Of War), and your force powers have a decent effect on the enemies and environments, the bad sides of the gameplay spoil what could have been a great game into a mediocre 3rd person lightsaber grind.  Story wise, this is pretty lame.  without giving too much away, theres one part that was completely un-necessary and was just there to get you from place a to place b.  theres no fluid action in this game.  its stop/start "kill enemies/watch cutscene of new enemies appearing/repeat".  crowbaring other canon characters into the game was stupid as well.  its smacks of desparation as the devs just didnt have any ideas and ended up snatching defeat from teh jaws of victory.  Frankly, if the devs havent learned how to write a decent game yet and are relying on the star wars name and licence to sell it, its no wonder it is held in such revile by fans of the Star Wars universe.Recommended for fans of Star wars and people who are that bored that they need a short game to pass a few hours with some utterly ridiculous plot points, but this is lame in comparison to the original and youll porobably never play it again

Posted: June 15, 2015
												So I just finished the seqeul to one of my favorite games of all time! How did it fare?I am a sucker for games that deliver a cinematic experience and make me feel like an absolute badass. The Force Unleashed 2 does just that. It plays like a movie (both in pacing and and cinematics) and it makes you feel like the most dangerous thing around. You can mash buttons and toss enemies aside like yesterdays jam.The story is nowhere near as deep as the first (not that this is nessesarily a bad thing) and you should pick this game up if you just feel like some mindless fun; because that is exactly what it is.After a few mishaps getting it to launch (compatability mode folks!) it ran ridicuously smoothly, looks great and plays well. It isn't the longest game sitting in at around 5-6 hours but if you can find it cheap, it is well worth the money.A very very enjoyable experence.

Posted: December 20, 2015
												To oversimplify it, the first one is better.Generally I look at games in terms of Gameplay, plot, systems/stability ('under the hood' judged from outside) and graphics. Usually we like sequels to improve on most of these, but to get only one out of four is slightly disappointing.Graphically: obvious improvements over the first one, pretty good. Generally consistent aesthetic to what I'd expect from Star Wars too. Not many really obvious graphical bugs or anything, a few things fade out of existence from now and then, but that's probably a functional thing so they don't fill your memory with pieces of broken box.Stability-wise, it's a step down from the original. I completed that twice with two crashes (which I think only happened because I was alt-tabbing about). This seems to be crashing every 60-90 minutes on average. Not sure why, sometimes it's in heavy combat, and sometimes it happens when I was lurking at a checkpoint eating a bag of crisps and the game wasn't really doing anything.My computer is definitely powerful enough to handle it. Maybe the backwards/forwards compatibility is causing problems.But aside from occasionally crashing, the game seems fairly well built, technically at least. I've yet to run into any notable bugs.Gameplay: the biggest disappointment.I’ll preface this by saying I’m not very good at this kind of game, I prefer a nice FPS where I can lurk in the distance and shoot people in the head, or an RTS where I can turtle away in some forgotten corner of the map. That said the gameplay was at times boringly easy on its ‘normal’ difficulty, at worst it tended to be awkward.The cut scenes are long and there's just a massive amount of time spent in quick time events. Would calling then ‘slow time events’ be childish? It generally feels like they wanted to make an animated film, but couldn't, so they let you press buttons from time to time and call it a game. Okay, that's an exaggeration, but it annoys me a bit.For example, one of the iconic bits of the first game is when you pull a star destroyer out the sky, you do this by force gripping it, and pulling it down. (You also have to make it face you, for no apparent reason, other than to make it hit you in the face when it lands, but drama.) In a similar sequence in this game you just sort of watch, and when it tells you to, you press a button a few times.Repetition is a bit problem, near the start fighting some giant rancor-eating monster you have to repeat identical game sections several times. While you're doing this, there's someone constantly shouting at you, telling you to do something, you've already sone once. And they complain you haven't done it yet multiple times before the sequence can repeat.I think in this game someone says something like 'A single Jedi can turn the tide of a war', and in the first one I could more or less believe that. In this game it's just odd. I guess it's technically true, given the number of enemies that perfectly resist any attempt to damage them, with anything but one specific power, so you'd need a jedi. But it's sometimes odd. Some enemies need to be hit with a radial force push, a normal straight one doesn't work, but a radial one staggers or outright kills them. Perhaps they are actually invincible, but terrified of circles?Then there's a massive number of force powered people, Sith acolytes or something, that will block your force powers. Some of them have lightsabers and block most melee attacks, so you have to grapple them; annoying I guess, but made more so by the fact there only seems to be one grapple animation. It’s slow, and very specific, and when you’re facing a few of them at the same time it’s incredibly tedious watching the same animation again and again. The only way I’ve found to make it fun is to try and line up the grapples so they fall off things when the animation completes. (You can briefly use powers on them while they’re standing up too.)Then there are the robots. Lots of identical robots, that must be killed in more or less the same way every time. Repetitive and irritating. The only difference I’ve found is which exact buttons is used in the lasts stage of the quick time event. Another animation would make this better, but whatever…The game also seems to forget what sensible people like; random sections turn into platformers where you have to climb things or traverse spaces with a mediocre advanced movement system. Fortunately for most of these, when you inevitably fall off they send you back to the start rather than killing you, which could be worse. But, for example, on Kamino there are airborne robots that are levitating, as they do. But they’re all staying perfectly still for no apparent reason, sitting in just the right place to let you cross places that the people controlling them shouldn’t be wanting you to cross. Plot: (small rant here, sorry) It's a bit odd to be honest. Largely the apparent motivations of Starkiller. For a  large part of the game he seems to have turned into a whiney idiot, totally obsessed with a girl he barely knows, jeopardising the rebel alliance, his own life etc. for no logical reason. Which isn't inherently, I understand love is a strong motivator for people, leading to irrational behaviour, except the barely know each other. After a few mildly suggestive conversations in the first game, and a kiss he's infatuated?That irritation aside, the rest of the plot is weak. Interesting enough to keep me playing, but just barely.Summary:Worse than the first.Gameplay is kind of fun, tearing apart little people, but there are lots of irrationally awkward big things.It likes to crash, for me at least. I’ve yet to figure out why. It's kinda pretty though.

Posted: February 7, 2015
												Ok, I'm only two hours into the game and I already can't deal with it. The game just repeats the same mundane tasks over, and over again. Starkiller's voice makes me want to shoot someone. The cliche love story. This COULD have been an amazing Star Wars game, but the designers just didn't do what they did with the first one. The combat system is great in this game, but all the mundane tasks and litle variety of enemies per level...not to mention the quick-time events. The icons for the button you need to press is barely visable at times, which ruins the events. There's just so much wrong with this game compared to the first one. The only reason I'm recommending this game is because of the combat system, which I don't even think that's a good reason to recommend this game. In comparison to the first game, at least the ports I've played of the first game, it lacks in what you can do with the lightsabers. In the Wii port of the game you could replace the lightsaber hilts, and I was hoping to see that in this game. While that didn't appear the dual blades did make up for it. In the PC port for the first game you don't get to customize your hilt, but you do get crashes. This game, surprisingly, crashes a lot less than the first one,Final Rating?5.5/10"It's not bad, but it's not good either..." ~Game Dev Tycoon

												I played TFU1 some time ago and that game was good storywise but the PC port was a buggy mess. I had hoped that this game would be better .. but in many ways it is worse.The story is poor and doesn't immerse you in the inner conflict and ultimate fate of Starkiller, which I thought TFU1 did well. The plot is not really a continuation of the TFU1 story and feels disjointed. On reflection, many of the plot points don't make any sense when compared to TFU1.The graphics are OK and, whilst the locations are visually nice, there is far too much "recycling" of locations. Sadly, this makes the game feel like an expansion pack rather than a full game.The game is very short and has little replay value, apart from choosing a different end path and/or difficulty setting.Overall, it just feels like an incomplete game; rushed out with some random ideas thrown together.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												Force Unleashed II is the phrase "One step forward, two steps back" personified.While the visuals have been improved immensely, it suffers from a sub-par atmosphere and repetitive level layout. The controls have been streamlined and are much more responsive, making for quicker, more engaging swordplay, though there are only a few different units encountered throughout the game, and most can be dispatched using the same one-two lightning saber combo.Force Unleashed II also suffers from being what many would consider DLC length, taking me only three and a half hours to complete the game on "normal", and the threadbare narrative barely keeps what little action there is flowing.If you're a fan of beat-em-ups and a huge Star Wars junkie looking to complete their collection, I'd only recommend purchasing this title if it's on super-sale.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												I try to keep track of which games I own / have played / have finished. It took me a while to remember I'd even played Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II, never mind finished it. And that really sums up the game.Compared to the original Force Unleashed, it's more fun to play, slicker, and has far fewer moments that pretend to be challenging but are actually just annoying (no Purge Troopers here!). But it's also more forgettable, shorter (and yet still repetitive), less rewarding to replay, and the story somehow manages to be tedious despite the short length of the game.I wouldn't recommend this even if you liked The Force Unleashed. I did, for all its flaws. This sequel does get rid of some of those flaws, but what remains is a scant few hours of disposable and unnecessary cruft. If you need to buy every Star Wars game that exists, then maybe consider this a low priority. I don't hate it; I just don't feel much about it at all, on those rare occasions I remember it exists.

												The Force Unleashed 2 improved in many ways over the first part but still has a lot of flaws. After a good start, it sadly becomes very repetitive so that I can't really recommend this one.Pros:+ Some quite cool finishers for mini-bosses+ Force lighning and grip really feel smooth and badass+ Nice cutscenesNeutral:◯ Story (not bad but there was much more potential)Negative:- Game is locked to 30 fps, it's possible to unlock 60 fps only with hacked .exe but that causes tearing during fast camera turns.- 2 of 3 endbosses are extremely repetitive- way too many QTE; during one endboss you have to press repeatedly one button for what feels like a minute... and that 4 times...- last endboss is just plain boring- very linear levels- barely any enemy variation- short campaign (took me 4-5 hrs); there is an additional difficulty level that is unlocked after the first playthrough and some challenges but I didn't really feel like playing any of them- several bugs that may hinder your progression; had to restart 3 different sections because the game wouldn't trigger the next part or the end of the level.

Posted: June 19, 2015
												UI - Rubbish. The assets don't scale past 720p. You literally get blocky pixelated icons and images on higher resolutions.Story - Rubbish and short.Game Length - 5 hours.Boss fights - Tedious. Not fun. Also, very few of them.Voice Acting - Bad.Writing/Dialog - Cheesy and bad.Combat - Same as the prequel. Same combos, same powers. It's just the game is so short they expedite the powerup process by a huge margin. The only difference is you have 1 more lightsaber so the melee animations are different.I really enjoyed the first one. It had decent pacing and good writing with good set piece moments. It sent you to a variety of locations. It was a pleasant surprise. SW:TFU 2 is the opposite of all those things. There is no equivalent moment of "I'll use the force to send a Star Destroyer crashing into the planet". There is no wow-factor. There is literally nothing to be had here.SW:TFU2 is literally a "Starship Troopers 2"-type sequence. A horrible sequel to a terrific first entry.Do not buy this game, it is a waste of money; not even for $5. You don't need to know what hapened to Starkiller after TFU1 because this sequel does not and will not live up to any form of expectations.

Posted: July 23, 2015
												Loved it. I like that in both TFU I and TFU II you feel like you're participating in a movie plot. The mix of videos, game scenes etc works well. Posted: March 18, 2015
												Star Wars the Force Unleashed II improved upon all the things that I found nagging in the first game, the graphics are much improved, the game flows much smoother, combat, while still repetitive, is fluid, fast, and fun. Yet, for all these things, it is a dissapointment of a game.The story is shoehorned in with a plot that clearly was thought up when the Lucasarts team was told they needed a sequel, and the game clocks in at just about 4-6 hours, depending on the difficulty you play on, and whether or not you decide to do any of the challenges.At the end of the day, while it is certainly a fun game, it is not what it should've been, and i'm forced to ask if we ever really needed a sequal to TFU.

Posted: February 8, 2015
Score: 6/10OverviewYou are back at Darth Vaders side training for future missions as the clone of Starkiller. Memories keep flooding back to you from Starkillers past leading Vader to consider you a flawed clone. You escape so that Vader doesn't kill you and begin your journey to find out who you are.PositiveThe combat feels better than the orignal if you ask me. Sure its a bit of a buttom mashup, but honestly who cares when it's fun. The levels aren't as big and less resources were used, but with a more streamlined design comes better playability. The graphics have been increased since the original as well, but that may also be because the levels are smaller. The boss fights in this game are fewer and less challenging, but they feel like boss fights. The boss fights are much more God of War. The PC port is actually playable.NegativeThe game is short. The smaller levels and lack of resources make some zones feel copy and pasted. The story is even more bland then the original and the ending makes you glad you didn't take much stake in it. The game did completely freeze causing me to have to restart twice.ConclusionThis is a better PC port and the way the levels are designed to be played is much smoother then the original. It seems way to obvious that it wasn't developed as long though because the levels are repetitious and for a game that is only about 5 hours that is saying something.ValueConsidering it is a bad port of an ok game I value it at $4.

												First off to start off this review, I had Star Wars The Force Unleashed 1 on my Playstation 2 and loved the game. Star Wars The Force Unleashed 2 I'm kind of indifferent about it. Hear are my pros and cons.ProsThe Force Abilities Good story lineAlot of cosmetic custimizationChallenges give good replay valueSupports Console Controls (This worked perfectly)ConsBeat the whole game in 6-7 hours on my first ever playthroughLevel Design isn't the greatest. SWTFU1 is far superior to this game. I would highley recommend any Star Wars fan to try out the first game. This game I would only recommend buying if you can get it for under 5$ on a sale. My overall final impressions on the game is it felt like a beta so I wouldn't recommend buying it at full price. The game is enjoyable but not as fun as the first one.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												Force Unleashed II is the phrase "One step forward, two steps back" personified.While the visuals have been improved immensely, it suffers from a sub-par atmosphere and repetitive level layout. The controls have been streamlined and are much more responsive, making for quicker, more engaging swordplay, though there are only a few different units encountered throughout the game, and most can be dispatched using the same one-two lightning saber combo.Force Unleashed II also suffers from being what many would consider DLC length, taking me only three and a half hours to complete the game on "normal", and the threadbare narrative barely keeps what little action there is flowing.If you're a fan of beat-em-ups and a huge Star Wars junkie looking to complete their collection, I'd only recommend purchasing this title if it's on super-sale.

Posted: February 7, 2016
A short enjoyable game that’s better designed than part 1Surprisingly, this is a better game than its predecessor. Although there is only one real moment in the game where you feel you’re unleashing the force, the enemy types are much more varied, and the level design is much better this time around. The CGI scenes are still unskippable, but gone are the countless frustrating moments of plunging to your death. In contrast to part 1, Stormtroopers can now be dismembered, which fits the dark story more.The story’s quite short (you’ll have finished it within 5 hours), and doesn’t really add much more than a happy ending to part 1. You’re a clone (or are you?) who’s out to find some answers and your long lost love. There is some darker story hidden in the challenge levels, which hints at cut content. The game would have been much more interesting had those cut voice-overs and storyboard art actually been translated into parallel game scenes.One consistent minor point are the small icons for the quick time events; you will often have to redo them, because you simply didn’t spot the tiny icons hidden over the screen. It’s not a game breaker, but it does get frustrating at times.Finally, be aware, the PC version is missing the Endor DLC that came out for consoles, which reinforces its short length.It’s a good game, but it still doesn’t come close to the Jedi Knight series.7/10

Posted: January 8, 2016
												This is a Sale-grab for sure, ESPECIALLY because there will be no follow-up game. You will be hanging off the cliff forever with that ending. It is also damn short; easily half the length (or more) of the first game. This isn't a sequel; it's DLC and should be priced as such.Like the first game, it has problems with plot and pacing, but I rather enjoyed this game a lot more! Combat was equally entertaining and there are some different enemy gimmicks which were well-designed. Quick-Time-Event combat resolution is still annoyingly present, but since it's usually optional or reserved for boss fights, I'll gloss over that. There are some minor glitches (mostly carry-overs from the first game) but they are not game-breaking.If you liked the first game, it's worth it to play this one. It is not much of an improvement; it's just more of the same.

Posted: January 7, 2016
												I honestly don't know why so many people hate this game. Yes, it's a port, yes it has some issues running on PC, but not that many and it's not unplayable. Maybe people are expecting Knights of the Old Republic 3 or some damn thing. This, isn't that. I think the director of the game said it best, it's about kicking♥♥♥♥♥with the Force. It's about actually using the Force in combat to throw a beat down, as apposed to all the stuff we see in the movies, like moving crap and falling really far. How easy to defeat would the droids in the Clone Wars have been if the Jedi were throwing around Force Lightning? Or using Force Grip to crush some droid tanks? How much more exciting would the cartoon and movies have been if the Jedi acted like the Super Heroes they were supposed to be, instead of emotionless droids with glowy sticks that can move and push things?If you are looking for a RPG with a deep, interesting story, buy KOTOR 1 and 2. If you're looking for a action game where you play as a Jedi, buy Jedi Outcast and Jedi Academy. If you want to kick some serious♥♥♥♥♥with the Force, and defeat entire armies all by yourself, and show what real warriors who command the Force can do, buy this and Force Unleashed 1.

												Ok so I have only played a few hours of the game. I like it but it does have some issues. The thing that I really liked about the first game was the cinematics. There where lots of them that gave me a good context of what each level was about and added to the story. With this game you start off by escaping from darth vador or some water planet, then all of a sudden youur in a cloud city with no explanation as to why. No cinematics, not even a text screen to move the story on. It just finish one level then right on to the next which I find to be very iritating and jaring.However the gameplay itself is the same. You get the same feeling as with the first although the combat is little bit dumbed down. The light saber customization has been drastically changed to where you can change the colour of your saber, but each colour has a specific power to it so no gold light saber and extra shock damage power crystal.The same can be said for the force upgrade tree. Not nearly as much  upgrades. No life expand, no combos to unlock just force powers. And even then the way you unlock them is changed. Instead of leveling up your charecter and earning ords you collect points which you can spend on to upgrade your force abilities.I am playing this on windows 10 with a pretty beast setup, there seems to be a few performance glitches witch I can only attribute to the operating system and the game not being patched for the new OS. I have the same issues with the first gasme but apart from that the game works well. The game looks gorgeous. I just wish the developer put as much effort into the story as they did the asthetics of the game.Over all its not a bad game. Its just been let down by the lack of story I feel. Also as of yet I am to have a light saber duel with a baddy. So far lots of clones, lots of those guys with the long cattle rods and lots and lots of mechanical freezing terminators. To the developer I say this. The first game was epic, and this game could of been epic....if only you had improved on your last game and not shipped a half completed game to fill a quota. If I my voice had any effect I demand that you go back to the game and make it better. Fill it out with the story I came here to play, The reason why I recomend this game is this. It isnt a bad game as I have said. It is still fun but its jusk lacking. £15 is a bit steap for this game, I would wait for a sale. I will get back to you on my final verdict of the game when I complete it..

Posted: December 20, 2015
												To oversimplify it, the first one is better.Generally I look at games in terms of Gameplay, plot, systems/stability ('under the hood' judged from outside) and graphics. Usually we like sequels to improve on most of these, but to get only one out of four is slightly disappointing.Graphically: obvious improvements over the first one, pretty good. Generally consistent aesthetic to what I'd expect from Star Wars too. Not many really obvious graphical bugs or anything, a few things fade out of existence from now and then, but that's probably a functional thing so they don't fill your memory with pieces of broken box.Stability-wise, it's a step down from the original. I completed that twice with two crashes (which I think only happened because I was alt-tabbing about). This seems to be crashing every 60-90 minutes on average. Not sure why, sometimes it's in heavy combat, and sometimes it happens when I was lurking at a checkpoint eating a bag of crisps and the game wasn't really doing anything.My computer is definitely powerful enough to handle it. Maybe the backwards/forwards compatibility is causing problems.But aside from occasionally crashing, the game seems fairly well built, technically at least. I've yet to run into any notable bugs.Gameplay: the biggest disappointment.I’ll preface this by saying I’m not very good at this kind of game, I prefer a nice FPS where I can lurk in the distance and shoot people in the head, or an RTS where I can turtle away in some forgotten corner of the map. That said the gameplay was at times boringly easy on its ‘normal’ difficulty, at worst it tended to be awkward.The cut scenes are long and there's just a massive amount of time spent in quick time events. Would calling then ‘slow time events’ be childish? It generally feels like they wanted to make an animated film, but couldn't, so they let you press buttons from time to time and call it a game. Okay, that's an exaggeration, but it annoys me a bit.For example, one of the iconic bits of the first game is when you pull a star destroyer out the sky, you do this by force gripping it, and pulling it down. (You also have to make it face you, for no apparent reason, other than to make it hit you in the face when it lands, but drama.) In a similar sequence in this game you just sort of watch, and when it tells you to, you press a button a few times.Repetition is a bit problem, near the start fighting some giant rancor-eating monster you have to repeat identical game sections several times. While you're doing this, there's someone constantly shouting at you, telling you to do something, you've already sone once. And they complain you haven't done it yet multiple times before the sequence can repeat.I think in this game someone says something like 'A single Jedi can turn the tide of a war', and in the first one I could more or less believe that. In this game it's just odd. I guess it's technically true, given the number of enemies that perfectly resist any attempt to damage them, with anything but one specific power, so you'd need a jedi. But it's sometimes odd. Some enemies need to be hit with a radial force push, a normal straight one doesn't work, but a radial one staggers or outright kills them. Perhaps they are actually invincible, but terrified of circles?Then there's a massive number of force powered people, Sith acolytes or something, that will block your force powers. Some of them have lightsabers and block most melee attacks, so you have to grapple them; annoying I guess, but made more so by the fact there only seems to be one grapple animation. It’s slow, and very specific, and when you’re facing a few of them at the same time it’s incredibly tedious watching the same animation again and again. The only way I’ve found to make it fun is to try and line up the grapples so they fall off things when the animation completes. (You can briefly use powers on them while they’re standing up too.)Then there are the robots. Lots of identical robots, that must be killed in more or less the same way every time. Repetitive and irritating. The only difference I’ve found is which exact buttons is used in the lasts stage of the quick time event. Another animation would make this better, but whatever…The game also seems to forget what sensible people like; random sections turn into platformers where you have to climb things or traverse spaces with a mediocre advanced movement system. Fortunately for most of these, when you inevitably fall off they send you back to the start rather than killing you, which could be worse. But, for example, on Kamino there are airborne robots that are levitating, as they do. But they’re all staying perfectly still for no apparent reason, sitting in just the right place to let you cross places that the people controlling them shouldn’t be wanting you to cross. Plot: (small rant here, sorry) It's a bit odd to be honest. Largely the apparent motivations of Starkiller. For a  large part of the game he seems to have turned into a whiney idiot, totally obsessed with a girl he barely knows, jeopardising the rebel alliance, his own life etc. for no logical reason. Which isn't inherently, I understand love is a strong motivator for people, leading to irrational behaviour, except the barely know each other. After a few mildly suggestive conversations in the first game, and a kiss he's infatuated?That irritation aside, the rest of the plot is weak. Interesting enough to keep me playing, but just barely.Summary:Worse than the first.Gameplay is kind of fun, tearing apart little people, but there are lots of irrationally awkward big things.It likes to crash, for me at least. I’ve yet to figure out why. It's kinda pretty though.

Posted: January 18, 2016
												Before I explain why I am recommending this game to you I will first offer the following disclaimers: Do not buy this game at full price. You should feel comfortable with your purchase if it is between $5 and $10.While others are reporting performance issues and crashes I have not experienced this at all. Beyond running the executive file in windows xp service pack 3 compatibility mode I have done no further tweaking to get the game to run on windows 10. I am running the game at 2715x1527 with all graphics settings set to high. While the game does run at 30fps I have not experienced any dips in fps or anything of this nature. I expect the stability of the game in my experience to be due to my specs - gpu: nvidia gtx 780ti, cpu: intel core i7-4820k and 16gb ram.The game is very short. If you were to only play through the campaign once you would get roughly four to five hours of play. There is a challenge mode offered, which can be a handy way to test out your abilities and skill in a variety of game modes ranging from merely practicing combos in a timed environment to timed wave based elimination modes. The game offers two distinct endings and four difficulty settings so your mileage will depend on whether you are a completionist or just out for a short but sweet Star Wars experience.So given the above disclaimers why am I recommending this game to you? The simple answer is because I found the game to be a short, yet enjoyable Star Wars experience.While the game does nothing ground breaking, it doesn't have the most varied combat and enemies can be bland and uninspiring at times - this game does do a number of things right that make up for these flaws. First, it captures the 'look and feel' of the Star Wars Universe. The graphics do an admirable job of capturing the style of the movies and although others have criticised them, I personally think they are perfectly adequate and at times quite beautiful. Not ground breaking, but sufficiently emersing. In particular, I *really* enjoyed the character design for Starkiller. Some of the costumes you unlock throughout the game can only be described as design porn. The repurposed Tie Fighter Uniform provides a memorable example. While there is nothing particularly deep about Starkiller's character, I enjoyed listening to Sam Witwer's voice acting and found him to be interesting enough to carry the story from start to finish. Although, there appears to be very little to his character development beyond chasing after a love interest and questioning his origins.Second, the combat is fun enough that you will likely enjoy the four to five hour journey to the story's conclusion. The game tries to switch up enemies although for the most part you will be fighting familiar enemies and watching the same kill animations for the mini-bosses you will fight on the way. The bosses themselves can be challenging at times, but not so difficult that you want to put the game and never return. They also offer some variety to the combat and often require you to use your force abilities and skills to successfully overcome your foes. It should be stressed that there is some handholding in the boss sections and generous checkpoints that refill your health but not the enemies detracts from the difficulty.Third, using some of the force powers really recaptured the feeling of playing Jedi Academy as a child. In particular the force grab skill can be a lot of fun to use and play around with and brings back a lot of fond memories of levelling up force chock in Academy and sadistically toying with the Stormtroopers. The force powers you are provided and the game’s use of them does do a good job of making you feel like a complete badass and a powerful force user.For these reasons, I enjoyed the Force Unleashed II and would recommend the game to others. I want to give an extra special mention to that Tie Fighter Uniform again, because it is seriously cool.So in summation: The game is short so only purchase it when it is on sale. While it won't be the best Star Wars game you have played (or third person action game for that matter), it will be enjoyable while it lasts. In my humble opinion it does a good job of capturing the spirit of the Star Wars Universe and this feeling lasts for the entirety of the campaign. The combat finds a middle ground between fun and uninspired, but I is still enjoyed it for the length of the game.If you want to play a Star Wars game for a couple of hours and feel like a powerful Jedi then this game is worth a purchase. I would explore Jedi Academy first, but this game is certainly worth a try.

Posted: January 17, 2016
												If you haven't played The Force Unleashed 1, ignore this game and go play TFU1 instead. It has a lot more content, the story is better, the levels and enemies are more varied, and it takes a lot longer to complete.If you have played TFU1 and want more, then this game should be approached like a DLC: no gameplay innovation, a few new enemies, 4 new levels, 1 new power, a lame story.The game has many flaws, but I don't regret the time spent.PROS+ solid gameplay: you feel very powerful, the controls are responsive and intuitive+ graphics and sound (voice acting, sound effects, environments, ...)+ Jedi Mind Trick is funny (but not very powerful)+ controller support (I played the whole game with a 360 controller)CONS- story is thin and nonsensical- game is short. A LOT shorter than TFU1- cinematics hang. Game fails to launch 4 times out of 5 because of that.- QTE (quick time events): maybe there's a game out there where QTEs make sense. I haven't found any, and this is certainly not that game. I HATE QUICK TIME EVENTS. Like TFU1, this game throws QTEs at you in the middle of fights, killing my immersion.- camera is frustrating if you have enemies all around youTHUMBS UP only if you have played TFU1 and want to play more of the same.THUMBS DOWN if you haven't played TFU1. Or you have played TFU1 but expect a sequel. This feels like a DLC, not a sequel.

												Game: Star Wars: The Force Unleashed IIFormat: PCReleased: 0ctober 2010With the recent advent of Humble Bundles or at least to me they are newish I decided to buy to star wars bundle. In said bundle I received overall a total of 12 star wars games, I won't bore you with the list but that is a lot of star wars.  The game I want to draw attention to here is Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II. Now  personally I loved the first game other than the levels on Felucia it was a genuinely stellar game. It made you feel powerful, like a real force user out for revenge. The second one? Not so much. It's good and I enjoyed my time with it but my biggest issue is time. I completed the game quit out looked and steam and there it was. FOUR hours of game play from start to finish. Granted I was running through it on medium difficulty but even so should a sequel to a game that had a solid 8-10 story with a♥♥♥♥♥♥tonne of DLC released after the fact last FOUR ♥♥♥♥ing hours? No is the answer to that question. I'll save that rant for later though let's talk about the good first shall we? GraphicsIt was a beautiful game when it first released back in October 2010 and it really does still stand up 4 years later. Weather effects, clothing moving in high winds, the motion capture is genuinely stellar it really shines through. Environments are fantastic and true to the movies, there are really very few games that get as visually close to delivering a star wars experience like Force Unleashed II. The flip side to this is artifacting everywhere all the time. graphical glitches were many and if this were a longer game maybe it would count as less but after FOUR hours there are just far too many graphic glitches. Another thing that ties into that is absolutely no V-syncing options at all and it's constantly stuck at 30FPS no matter the hardware configuration.Game Play/MechanicsThis is another place where I feel the game before was a better example of how to do things.  It had a better level system,  It had the better skill upgrades In the prequel you gain experience, level up, earn talent spheres, and the spend them on abilities. combos, and skills. in the sequel every time you break something or someone you gain force points which you then spend on the 6 skills open to you. This is literally it. you gain minor other bonuses from different Light Saber crystals but it's so insignificant its barely even worth mentioning. The fighting is much the same but with a severe lack of combos (of which there are only about 20 as opposed to the amount from game number one) really limits the flashy combat and pulls you away from feeling like you are a stupidly powerful Jedi/Sith. No real puzzle elements or alternate paths and that really doesn't help it's case of FOUR hours.SoundThis will be a real short one. It sounds like Star Wars. biggest point to note here is like the prequel Mr James Earl Jones returns as the voice of Darth Vader. Voice acting is actually very well don across the board but then again you only ever hear about 5 characters actually speak. whodathunkit?ReplayabilityNOPE. FOUR hours. FOUR hours. On a harder difficulty I might've gone a whopping 5 hours. some challenges await after completing the game and what DLC was released when pulled from sale for whatever reason. Once this game is finished there is NO reason to EVER come back to it.StoryYou play as the clone of Starkiller for game numero uno on a quest for revenge and to save the one he loves. awww isn't that cute? isn't it also the most generic thing ever? I won't rant too much here I did enjoy it even for its generic seen it before storyline the voice acting really helped me trundle through the story. Much like the first game(noticing a theme yet?) you will be required to fight Darth Vader. this is the highlight of any of the bosses but I felt even that may have dragged on a bit too long.Okay rant time. Lucas Arts all you had to do was make the first game again make it look prettier and everyone would have been so happy with the end product but no, like every other developer you decide that you should change one of the fundamentally greatest things from the first game. The progression for Starkiller. you took what made that game great and just♥♥♥♥♥♥all over it with number 2(see what I did there?) I really wish that you had just copy pasted for number 2 and considering that  because of Disney we won't get number 3 there are so many things you left unanswered. is he Starkiller prime? is he just a clone like all the rest? If he is a clone why can he use the force? There is a real simple solution to all of this. DONT MAKE IT FOUR ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS! another 4-6 hours and you could have told the rest of star killers story and fans would have been happy but now all I have is an empty pit of unanswered questions and disappointment for series that could have been so much more.Positives•	Graphically beautiful•	Stellar voice work•	James Earl JonesNegatives•	Story was bland and been there done that•	graphical glitches•	FOUR hours•	No replayability what so ever•	FOUR hoursI wish I could rate this higher but its only worth a 5 out of 10 IF this is your first outing with SW:TFUII then it will be fine and fun but please go back and play the first one it's so much better.

Posted: August 17, 2016
												Star Wars - The Force Unleashed 2 was slightly dissapointing, but a cool, short game to play nonetheless.I am a Star Wars fan, which is the main reason I liked this game. I have played the first Force Unleashed on XBOX 360 and PSP years ago, and I definitely enjoyed it as a kid. It was very intruiging and I completed the games many times, over and over. I have been looking to get this second one upon release as well, but that never ended up happening, and I kind of just forgot about it... But I finally decided to get it, 6 years after its release.Overall, this isn't that good of a game. It doesn't have the best graphics (released 6 years ago, understandable, but even so, many graphical glitches, and Juno looks ugly af in this game), the storyline is horrible (unlike the first Force Unleashed, which I would say had a great storyline!), the game itself is very short (only took 6 hours to complete, collecting all holocrons + both endings + most force upgrades), and the gameplay is also repetitive.I definitely enjoyed the first game tons more, and only mildly liked this game because I liked the first one and because I am a Star Wars fan. They definitely could have made this a much better sequel to the first game. But ehhhey.. story doesn't matter now anyway because its not canon THANKS DISNEY!I don't recommend this game to people who are not big fans of Star Wars.BUT HEY - YOU CAN CHANGE THE COLOR OF YOUR DUAL LIGHTSABERS SO BUY! BUY! BUY! 23/10!but really... 6/10

Posted: July 30, 2015
												The good:Significantly improved graphicsSmoother, more responsive gameplay with some neat new moves (grabs)The bad:QTEs are still as annoying as ever and more difficult than the first game due to the much smaller, much easier to miss indicatorsShort, incomplete story (i.e. this game was severely rushed). Story itself is rather lame compared to the first game.Persisting technical issues and a few new ones and a rude reminder that this is a poorly done console port (if you're using an xbox controller and it disconnects, you have to restart the game for it to work again) (keyboard and mouse control won't work at all if you have certain devices in the windows device manager)The ugly:This game can be easily completed in under 4 hours. Extremely short, even compared to the first game (which I thought was too short already).Conclusion:While this game is an improvement over the original in terms of graphics and gameplay, the persisting technical issues and very short, underwhelming story really undermine this game. Given its length, it really should have been a DLC for the first game (even then the story is pretty pathetic). Unless you really like star wars and can get this for $5, stay away.

That's about it.The gameplay is basically that of a beat-em-up - you go through, you kick the♥♥♥♥♥♥outta your enemies. Unfortunately, this game suffers most from the same flaw most beat-em-up's have, which is "Repeat, ad Infinitum and ad nauseaum." And don't forget the QTE (Quick Time Events). While flashy and awesome the first time, it gets rather annoying when you see the same finisher for the same enemy over and over again. You'd think there'd be more than one way to finish them - but nope. Same QTE finisher, same boring moves.

Posted: September 20, 2013
												Sequel to the most amazing Star Wars game of the action genre. Sadly the game is shorter than the original but this game is still awesome. You now are dual wielding light sabers as Starkiller with new powers like mind trick -- make a stormtrooper fight for you then jump out a window and get sucked into space -- now with better graphics. This game is a beautiful and looks beyond a 2010 game.Just like the first one, it uses the same physics engine only seen in games like GTA IV and V, LA Noire, and Red Dead Redemption. Ragdoll physics where bodies look like they actually have bones instead of falling down like noodles. Your force powers are better, the controls are better, kicka$$ story, everything is very well done... for the most part.+ Great graphics+ Excellent physics+ Great writing+ Sam Witwer and cast+ All the extra costumes and other collectables+ Dual wielding lightsabers+ Incredible combat+ Amazing animations+ Soundtrack+ Force powers including the new mind trick+ Fighting hologram Darth Maul+ Boss battles+ Dismemberment+ Euphoria Engine- Way too short- Poor port- Feels kinda like a cash grab with how poor some parts of the game are- Skill point system is considerably worse than Force Unleashed 1, and way too simplified- Repetitive enemies

Posted: December 31, 2016
												This game has problems, but I still love it. Let's get down to the details of what makes this game good and what makes it bad.PROS:- Fun and fast Combat (A bit like Metal Gear Rising with less blood and gore)- Easy to Learn- Makes you feel like a really powerful Jedi- Pretty Good Voice Acting -some dismemberment-Cutscenes are pretty niceCons:- Repetitive Level Design at times- The game is really short if you aren't dedicated to collecting everything- The story is pretty weak-Occasional crashes-Not the best portVerdict:This game has many flaws and if you are trying to play for the story you really shouldn't buy it as the story is very weak or maybe even closer to nonexistant. If you want a fast and fun action game with a star wars feeling then you should buy this game. Keep in mind that the game is really quite short so you should get it on sale if you can.RatingA loving 7/10

And it took me only 7 hourd to complete, which includes some extremely long, boring and meaningless bossfights, couple of retrys and being lost and not knowing where to go next.. 												This game has problems, but I still love it. Let's get down to the details of what makes this game good and what makes it bad.PROS:- Fun and fast Combat (A bit like Metal Gear Rising with less blood and gore)- Easy to Learn- Makes you feel like a really powerful Jedi- Pretty Good Voice Acting -some dismemberment-Cutscenes are pretty niceCons:- Repetitive Level Design at times- The game is really short if you aren't dedicated to collecting everything- The story is pretty weak-Occasional crashes-Not the best portVerdict:This game has many flaws and if you are trying to play for the story you really shouldn't buy it as the story is very weak or maybe even closer to nonexistant. If you want a fast and fun action game with a star wars feeling then you should buy this game. Keep in mind that the game is really quite short so you should get it on sale if you can.RatingA loving 7/10

												Great game, the port isn't too bad with a few tweeks. The story isn't too much to be hyped over and my only complaint is the game is REALLY short, I finished it in just under 5 hours.
